FinalFireReportNarrative: Hikers reported fire near a backcountry campsite.  Hikers put water on the fire to contain it.  Next day two firefighters hiked in to suppress the fire.

Type 3, long duration fire managed under a point-zone protection strategy successfully, included 80 acres of defensible space treatments utilizing personnel and masticators in the Old Faithful development.

8/11/20 Report of an abandoned campfire in the Divide Pass day-use area.  Dispatched Old Faithful RVP staff with structure fire engine to investigate report and take initial action if warranted.  Troy Shaffer reported…The fire was located approximately 100 feet from the loop road for the picnic area. The fire was located in the duff behind a log away from the designated picnic sites. No sign of a fire being intentionally built or a fire ring being created. Myself, Michael Curtis, and Eric Wight doused the fire with water and dug up the dirt and duff to ensure it was completely out. The closest guesses I have to guess the cause would be either someone smoking while using the bathroom or lighting their TP on fire after completing their business. Seem like an out of place location for a fire. I looked for any possible evidence of a cause or exact origin and was unable to locate anything of significance.

8/11/20 1730 hours Fire is declared controlled and out.
Fire detected by a highly reliable backcountry Ranger.  UTL after detection event and presumed natural out.

Backcountry rangers reported smoke.  Helicopter recon sized up the fire as a few logs mid slope with low spread potential.  No values at risk and over a mile from a trail. Did not suppress that day due to wet weather forecasted the next day.  Put in monitor status letting wet weather put the fire out.
Fire location in at West Yellowstone, MT along Boundary Street just inside Yellowstone NP .  Single burning log.  Hebgren Lake fire department put the fire out.
Fire started 8/2 and disappeared. Appeared again 8/15.  Helitack with helicopter bucket drops suppressed the fire.
Single tree snag in open grass and sage brush. Response was day after ignition. 4 person engine crew suppressed the fire.

On July 1, 2021 a smoke report came in from an off duty sheriff and trustworthy source flying
the western boundary of the park. The reporting party saw smoke just east of Divide Lake. 2TC
was launched from Mammoth Helispot. A grizzly was spotted on the Quadrant Plateau. First orbit over the approximate spot no smoke was visible but we could smell it. After a second orbit we were able to locate the smoke on the lower ⅓ of a north facing slope. Called in a fire size up to dispatch from
the front seat. He ordered the Jumpers out of West for backup. Jumper 13 was flying to the west
on a daily detection flight. 700 Fox informed us D.O. named the fire, Divide Springs. At
1100, 2TC located a helispot and we unloaded 2TC and we set up the bucket. We got lined
out established LCES while 2TC hit the Divide Springs Fire with buckets. With the Gallatin
River just to the north of the fire, 2TC had a very quick turnaround time. 
1115 we arrived at the fire. At 1130, Jump 13 arrived with 8 jumpers.
By 1240 2TC was sent back to Swan Flats to refuel, take a lunch, and remain on standby. Bucket was contaminated by Yellowstone Aquatic Invasive Species Staff later in the day. The Divide Springs was called contained at 1420. All personnel cold trailed the fire. Weather had been building throughout the afternoon and it did not make sense to have 2TC pick up personnel or sling cargo. At 1515, all forestry technicians left the fireline and the fire was called controlled. Jumpers had to make two trips to hike their gear out. By 1710 both the West Yellowstone Smokejumpers and Yellowstone Helitack were loaded up and headed home.

7/1/2021 – from ICT5(t) …”After flying and getting an initial size up at 18:45 from the LZ at 44 28.4915 N 110 35.0724 or the Arnica Turnoff we waited for the AIS individual to clear the bucket for use.  Using the Lat Long we got from the recon we found a suitable pullout spot nearest to the fire at approximately 2010. The location of the fire 44 28.4600N 110 33.5474 W.
The hike in took around 20 min and when we got there we I checked in with dispatch and we proceeded to dig line around the hottest parts of the fire, the fire is very much a mosaic with fingers of green throughout. It is approximately .1 acres in size with slow creeping and smoldering in the duff and in some heavy down logs, we worked the fire using helmets to dip out of the creek at the heel of the fire and in about 45 min we had a line around the hottest areas and the majority of the fire. There is one large, tall snag in the fire that is of concern as a hazard tree, it had smoldering around 15 feet up it. I marked it with orange flagging. 
At around 2120 we hiked out and flagged our route out to the road. This should be used to access the fire again unless there is a better route. I recommend a team of 6 with one saw and a trash pumps with 4 rolls of hose to fully mop up. The small stream could support the pump and is right next to the heel of the fire.

At 1330, a report of torching trees ⅛ of a mile west of Fishing Bridge came in. Rangers were on the fire attempting to contain it with a fire extinguisher. 2TC responded with 3. 1410 we located the fire from the air. Local ground resources were already on the .1 acre fire using various hand tools. 1415 we landed and tied in with them and
had them stage in the parking area to the north while 2TC put 10 buckets on the fire. 1415 
spoke with some of the rangers and asked them to keep a presence at the parking lot and to
make sure no public came up to the fire. 1420 LCES, and crew briefing took place.   1530 Called 700 Fox to have the fire listed as contained. .
Then the fire was called contained, we loaded up 2TC and headed back to Mammoth
Fire reported by public.  Yellowstone helitack responded and suppressed the fire.

On July 22, 2021 Helicopter 2TC launched to IA a new start on the west border of the park near highway 191. There were several storm heads tracking through the area. Upon arrival on the incident and an aerial recon it was determined that we could handle the fire with resources on scene. Due to the gusty outflow winds finding a Helispot took some time. We ended up landing about 1.5 miles out and begand to hike in. 2TC tried to do some bucket work but with no values at risk and little spread the decision was made to set down and wait for the storms to pass. Nearing the fire a helispot we had spotted in the air was on the hike, we improved the helispot and continued to the fire. 2TC was able to lift at this time due to the storm passing and start doing bucket work. On arrival on the fire we found a split stump dead tree that had been hit by lightning the ground fire was from a large branch off the tree. 2TC left scene for West Yellowstone for fuel, and we cut down part of the tree that had smoke inside due to rot and cut hand line. 2TC returned for some more spot drops. End of shift there was a small smoke up on the main stock of the tree so the plan was to return on 7/23/21.  On 7/23 two returned to find some small smokes in the black and fell the rest fo the tree along with 4 to 5 more buckets. The fire was called controlled. on 7/24/21 at 0800 the fire was called out.

Fire reported by person boating on Yellowstone Lake near Gull Point.  Helicopter with three firefighters, LEO and structure fire responded. Small fire burning just off the beach.  Unable to determine cause.

Around 7:30 PM on 7/25/21 near a bear jam north of Roaring Mountain, a visitor flagged an LEO down to report a fire at the Beaver Lake Picnic Area.  The visitor indicated his family had attempted to put water on the fire, but had run out.  LEO responded to the area and found a smoldering fire (2’x2’) west of the picnic area in a green grassy meadow near a social trail.  LEO poured more water from on the fire and utilized a shovel from the vehicle to assist in putting the fire out.  No cigarettes or obvious signs of cause were observed in the area and the picnic area was empty.

Corral Fire Narrative Summary 
7/31/21
Initial attack took place on Saturday the 31st with 2TC dropping off two firefighters, they started sawing and utilizing buckets. At this time we were on the way from Mammoth. When we got there it started raining heavily with thunder and lightening in close proximity. The ship set down for safety and resources pulled back off the fire for about 45 min. After the heaviest rain had subsided we hiked back in which was when the fire was handed off to me. I made the decision to use 2 saws and start cutting out heavies and trees around the perimeter of the fire. After about 45 min 2TC felt safe in re-engaging with the bucket and I directed drops on parts of the fire that were of highest concern. I released the ship back to Mammoth so that he could be back by 8pm. At about 8:50 we had tied in the saw line around the perimeter and had established a line around the North flank of the fire. I ordered an engine and a hand crew for the next operational shift. All resources were off the line by approximately 9:00 pm.
8/1/21
Jumpers arrived on scene at 8am and hiked into the fire and started saw work to improve the effectiveness of the saw cut. Heavies interior were also bucked and snags were removed. By 9am we had a hand line around the perimeter of the fire and began bone piling. After scouting for closer access for the engines we began the hose lay from the parking area at 1030 and had water flowing by 1130. Mop up with water proceeded. At 230 2 jumpers were pulled for a new start in the park. At 330 we began pulling hose off the line. At 4 I released the remaining jumpers back to West Yellowstone. We continued to monitor for smoke and shortly after 5 headed back to Mammoth.

August 1, 2021 Mid afternoon fire reported by fire fix wing recon. Remote location. Two smokejumpers were picked up from the Corral fire by helicopter and flown into the fire.  Helicopter put numerous bucket drops on the fire.  Firefighters were able to cut containment line around 2/3 of the fire and cup trench.  Upper part of the fire went into a rocky area.  Very steep location. Jumpers were picked up by helicopter and flown back to West Yellowstone.
August 2. Fire in monitor status and received rain.

August 1, 2021 Late afternoon fire helicopter from the Forest Service reported the fire at half acre.  Eight smokejumper jumped the fire and worked till midnight to contain the fire.  Old growth lodge pole and lots of heavies.
August 2.  Jumpers call the fire out late morning.  Gear was hauled out by helicopter sling load.  Jumpers hiked out two miles to hwy 191 just before the rain started.

August 2, 2021 Late afternoon fire report south of Buffalo Ranch across the Lamar Valley.  Rain obscured viewing the fire.
August 3  Three firefighters waded across the Lamar river and hiked into the fire. 1135 began digging line around the fire. Hiked out end of shift.
August 4 Three firefighters hiked back in. Few smokes. Called controlled mid afternoon.

A smoke report came into dispatch that a small fire was spotted by park visitors near campsite 4E2. The reporting party said they did their best to contain the fire and used water bottles to cool down the fire. The reporting fire hiked 1.5 hours to get cell service to report the fire to Yellowstone Dispatch. 1520 700 Fox called the Helitack crew on the radio and informed of us the fire with approximate coordinates and a description of the fire activity. By 1535 launched 2TC with 3 onboard. Headwinds made for slow progress as we crossed the Washburn Range. We made several passes over the coordinates we were given but no hints of fire activity. At 1405 we set down in a meadow on the west bank of Cascade Lake. We unloaded and grided the hillside looking for the fire, but we were unable to locate it.  called 700 Fox for any more information and we learned the fire was 150 yards southwest of campside 4E2 across the meadows. This immediately changed our search location. We got back on the Cascade Lake Trail as we thought it was most likely where the reporting party spotted it from. At 1620, spotted it across the marsh, and with a gust of wind the smoke was gone. We got to the single tree fire at 1625. It was evident the 15 foot stovepipe tree needed to come down. made quick work of it. We gridded the green for any embers that might have come off the stovepipe, none were found. The only heat was found in the strike tree. We dry mopped, and used water bottles to cool the heat.  At 1715, the fire was called contained. The fire was cold as we walked off the line at 1725.

Fire was spotted by a West Yellowstone Smoke Jumper driving on Hwy 191 between MM17 and MM18 on the night of August 16th. Fire appeared to be in the Telly Meadows area. A T6 Engine out of the Hebgen Ranger Station and a T3 CWN Helicopter were dispatched on the morning of the 17th. Firefighters were able to locate the incident burning in brush and timber with no active flame but with some interior heat. At time of Sizeup the fire was about 10' x 10' and the Engine crew was instructed to fully suppress the incident. The IC Contained and Controlled the incident at 14:42 that afternoon.

This was a lightning caused fire that was put into a natural fire management strategy with a specific prescription. Once the weather conditions were no longer in prescription, the park had to actively suppress the fire.  This fire was also entered into WFMI as a type 48 (prescribed fire). This record was deleted by B. Smith on 3/29/2018 once it was determine there was only one Plateau fire in 1992, and it was started by lightning.

THE FIRE WAS      FLOWN AT 0900 BY DICK BAHR TO VERIFY THAT IT WAS INDEED A FIRE INSIDE THE PARK AND DETERMINED ITS POTENTIAL TO SPREAD ONTO THE GALLATIN NF. THE EVALUATION BY AIR AND AERIAL PHOTOS SHOWED THAT THE FIRE HAD THE POTENTIAL TO BRUN INTO THE  GALLATIN NF ABASAROKA/BEARTOOTH WILDERNESS, WHICH ALSO HAS A PNF PROGRAM.       THE FMO FROM THE GALLATIN WAS CONTACTED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE FIRE    HAD THE POTENTIAL TO BURN ACROSS AGENCY BOUNDARIES AND THAT WE SHOULD BEGIN TO WORK THROUGH OUR FIRE PLANS AND EVALUATE IF THIS FIRE SHOULD BE DECLARED A PNF OR A WILDFIRE. THE YELLOWSTONE FIRE COMMITTEE MET AND WENT THROUGH ALL THE     CRITERIA AND DETERMINED THAT ALL OF THE PRESCRIPTION CRITERIA COULD NOT BE MET FOR THIS FIRE TO DECLARE A PNF. THE FIRE WAS DECLARED A WILDFIRE AND INITIAL   ATTACK TOOK PLACE AT 1015 BY ASHLEY SITES AND RICK STRATTON. THE FIRE WAS      CONTROLLED AT 1115 AND DECLARED OUT AT 1700 ON 7/2/94.

THE SUPRISE FIRE WAS A FOLLOWUP TO A REPORT ON 9/8/1994 BY THE NATIONAL CIVIL  DEFENSE DETECTION NETWORK TO A HEAT SOURCE BEING DETECTED IN YELLOWSTONE       NATIONAL PARK, 5 TO 8 MILES EAST OF MOUNT SHERIDAN. The Robinson Fire was a lightning-caused fire detected by a Targhee NF         detection flight at 1302 on 9/9/94.  Due to the extreme fire season, all fires were in a suppression mode in Yellowstone.  The fire was initial attacked by   4 smokejumpers out of West Yellowstone jump base at 1339 and they were         supported by a heavy air tanker out of West and by the 6 person Sandia         Helitack crewthat was stationed in Yellowstone at the time.  The fire was 3    acres at report and was 5 acres and growing rapidly at initial attack.  The    fire escaped the IA efforts and a Type II IMT was ordered.  Ernie Johnson's    Blue Ridge IMT from R-6 was assigned.                                           The IMT was successful in containing the fire at about 4,000 acres and the     fire was transitioned back to the park.  The park crew assigned to the fire    continue to mopup but unfortunately began to also rehab some of the fireline.  Due to the mopup not being 100% complete, the Robinson fire esaped             containment and massive suppression efforts had to be undertaken once again.   Helitack and jumpers again were called in but the fire quickly escaped and a   second Type II IMT was called in.  Tim Hancock's Eastside IMT was assigned.    A large effort was once again undertaken to suppress this fire, mainly at the  urging of the Targhee NF, as they were concerned the fire would burn back into their forest.                                                                   The Team flanked the fire and was supported by the Yellowstone Helitack crew   shooting FLE along the NW flank to secure that flank.  Precip was received on  several days with a significant snowstorm on 10/2/94.  The fire was declared   contained and all suppression forces were demobed.  The fire was controlled    on 10/14/94 at 1800 at 8,482 acres and was declared out on 10/31/04.

DUE TO    THE TIME OF DAY AND THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE THE FIRE WAS NOT JUMPED UNTIL THE  MORNING OR 9/11/94.  THE FIRE WAS LINED ANDMOPPED UP THAT DAY AND CHECKED THE  FOLLOWING MORNING.  THE JUMPERS REMAINED ON THE FIRE UNTIL THE MORNING OF 9/13 /94.

The Cascade Fire was reported by a visitor to 814 at 2116 on July 6, 1995.     Lightning struck a standing dead stump which fell over and was consumed.  The  site was very wet and the grass was very green and had a high moisture content due to the wet year.  The fire was monitored daily until it burned out         naturally on July 20, 1995.  Final size was approximately 6 ft. X 10 ft.

The Exhibit Fire was reported by a visitor to 314 at 2100 on July 11, 1995.    Lightning blew the top out of a pine tree that ignited a small area of ground  fuels, mainly duff.  The fire had little potential for growth due to its       proximity to 1988 burned area.  The fire was monitored daily until it burned   naturally on July 7, 1995.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. ACRES DISCOVERED: 0000000.0 - Changed to 0000000.1 End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The fire was reported to 312 after the fire was out and not seen again.        People at the Black Butte Ranch reported lightning igniting a single tree fire to the northeast of the ranch.  The storm that started the fire rained it out. The fire was not seen again.  The fire was declared a natural out as of July   12, 1995.

The Huckleberry Fire was reported as three miles east of the South Entrance    at 1900 by the Bridger-Teton National Forest.  The Bridger-Teton fire          helicopter flew the fire and placed it approximately one mile inside the park  burning in a single tree near a small meadow.                                  122 flew the fire area on July 30 and did not find the fire.  The Huckleberry  Fire was not seen again after the initial report.  It was declared out at .1   of an acre on August 1, 1995.

122 Sites discovered the fire from the highway at 1315 on August 4, 1995.      123 Hafer and 123 Kreutzer joined 122 Sites in hiking to the fire.  The        determined that the fire was human caused and began suppression operations.    77T flew in a Mark III pump and hose to assist in mop up efforts.  122 Sites   re-checked the fire on August 5 and declared it out.

The Cub Fire was discovered by a Park County Wyoming deputy sheriff at 1800    on August 6, 1995.  He attempted to suppress the fire by discharging a fire    extinguisher on it.  613 was dispatched to determine exact location, size and  potential for a prescribed natural fire.  It was found to be 50 feet west of   the East Entrance highway, having  burned a 6'x 6' area on the ground while    fire was burning in the tops of two trees.  It was determined to declare the   Cub a wildfire and suppress due to the potential for it to burn to the road    and cause alarm to visitors and road construction workers.  The fire was       initial attacked by two Lake Rangers, Wes Miles and Jeremiah Smith at 2030.    A Federal Highway worker reported the Cub Fire actively burning again at 1057  on August 7.  121 contacted 612 who dispatched Lowell Baltz, Jeremiah Smith    and Don Springer with the Lake engine to finish suppression efforts.  The fire was declared out at 1400 on August 7, 1995.

The Bear Fire was a lightning-caused fire that was reported by 525 at 1800 on  08/06/95 near the Lake Butte.  The fire was declared a PNF and managed as such until it went out naturally on 09/01/95.  122 Sites and 123 Sites initially    monitored the fire on 08/07/95 and determined the size to be /75 of an acre in size.  The fire was burning in LP3, but had low potential for growth due to    the green grass and high fuel moisture contents of all size classes of fuels.  The fire was continually monitored by fire lookouts and by the fire cache      monitors as well as the prescribed fire burn team.  In spite of heavy rains on 08/07/95 the fire did grow to 1/3                                              1.25 acres.  122 Sites and 121 Redman visited the fire on 09/01/95 and         declared it out at that time.

The Douglas Fire was reported by the smokejumper spotter on board the USFS     Twin Otter from West Yellowstone. They reported the fire while enroute to a    fire in the Bridger-Teton                                                      National Forest. They reported the fire as two to three trees burning at 1424  as they traveled south and updated the report on their trip home. At 1650, the fire had grown to approximately one acre total size and had spotted from one   group of trees to another due to strong winds. There was little fire spread on the ground. The fire was burning in sparse lodgepole pine and had little       potential for further growth without strong winds. The fire was monitored by   the fire lookouts and never reported again, as more rain was received the same night as it started. The fire was flown on 08/16/95 and no activity was noted. The fire was declared dead and out following the flight.

The Bighorn Fire was reported by a visitor to 178 Glenn on 08/17/95.  312 rode to the fire location just off the Bighorn Pass cutoff trail and reported fire  in the base of a tree that had been burned in 1988.  There was low potential   for growth due to the 1988 burns and tall, wet, green grass. The fire was      declared a p                                                                   PNF and managed as such until it was declared out on 08/30/95.  The fire        la                                                                            any larger.  122 Hendrix declared the fire out on 08/30/95.

The Hot Spring Fire was reported by 517 at 1411 on 08/21/95. The location of   the fire was near a campsite in the Snake Hot Springs area and it was decided  that a fire monitoring team would be sent to the fire to determine if the fire was human or lightning-caused. 123 Kreutzer, 122 Hendrix and 121 Burgard were  dispatched in helicopter 28G to the fire location. The monitoring team         reported that the fire was lightning-caused and the fire size was 25 ft. X     15 ft. and that the base of the tree that had been struck by lightning was     still smoldering. The fuel cover was spruce/fir with an understory of grouse   whortleberry and huckleberry. The fire was declared a PNF and managed as such  until it was rained out. The potential for the fire to grow was low due to the green grasses in the area and a wet fire year. Fire monitors visited the h     Hot Spring Fire again on 8/23 and reported that heavy rainfall had been        received in the vicinity of the fire and that the fire was cold out. The fire  officially declared out at that time as a natural out PNF.

The Meadows Fire was visited and investigated by Dick Bahr, Assistant Fire      Management Officer, to determine cause and exact location.  The fire was       located from the helicopter at 1415 hours with smoke visible.  The fire was    located 30 ft. west of the Bechler Meadows bypass trail with one snag having   burned through at the base and fallen across the trail.  The helicopter landed and Dick walked to the fire to determine cause and take an exact position      using G                                                                        GPS.  Examination of the area showed signs of camping by a stock party with    numerous piles of horse shit present east of the trail, as well as evidence of stock being tied to trees in that area, and a matted down area 20 feet south   of the fire origin where extensive foot traffic was evident.  Further evidence found on scene include paper from a container label red in color, one tin can, steel container top, found in the original fire pit.  In addition, a partially burned egg carton found approxiamately 20 ft. southwest of the fire origin     along side a pile of broken dead branches and dried needles and a medium sized 1.5 in. diamater branch with dead needles still attached.  Photos were taken   of the area and human use items were removed.  The helicopter then departed    for Mammoth to pick-up two initial attack firefighters, pump kit, and chainsaw initial attack began on this fire at approximately 1700 hours with two initial attack personnel.  123 Kreutzer and 122 Sites were the initial attack crew     andhad the fire under control at 2000 on 08/30/95.  Mop up thenbegan and the   fire was declared out at 1200 on 08/31/95.

The fire was monitored by Mount Sheridan, but was  not seen smoking up again.  Monitors flew the fire on 09/11/95 and located the fire.  The fire was still smoldering in several large logs and in the duff.    Potential for spread was low.  tT                                               The fire was visited again on 09/13/95 and declared out at that time by 123    Bundren and 123 Kreutzer.

The Cottonwood Fire was reported to Dan Krapf by Mark Harrellson of the IGBT   at 1810 on 09/10/95.  The fire was located on the first main branch to the     northeast of Cottonwood Creek.  Dan reported extensive lightning in the area   fire was initially declared a PNF.  The fire was visited on 09/11/95 by tow    (2) fire monitors, 123 Petrick-Underwood and 122 Hendrix.  They found evidence of a human-caused fire and returned to Mammoth.  103 was notified and 217 sent to investigate.  After the investigation was completed, 123 Petrick-Underwood  and 122 Hendrix began suppression operations.  Later that day 123 Bundren and  123 Sites assisted along with bucket drops from 28G.  The fire was visited on  09/14/95 and declared out by 122 Hendrix.

THE SPEAR FIRE WAS DETECTED AT 1900 ON 06/21/96.  LIGHTNING STRUCK A LARGE     DOUGLAS FIRE TREE NEAR ROOSEVELT CORRALS, BLOWING THE TREE APART INTO SEVERAL  SPLINTERS AND STARTING A SMALL FIRE IN THE DUFF.  THIS FIRE DID NOT SPREAD DUE TO THE GREEN GRASS SURROUNDING THE FIRE.  THE ONLY FIRE ACTIVITY WAS           SMOLDERING IN THE DOWNED TREE BRANCHES WHICH BURNED FOR OVER A MONTH.  THE     FIRE BURNED ABOUT A TENTH OF AN ACRE AND WAS DECLARED OUT ON 08/04/96.

The Crevice PNF was discovered by visitors and reported to rangers on 07/02/96 at 2210.  Mammoth rangers made the initial assessment on it at 0100 on         07/03/96.  Three fire monitors hiked to the fire on 07/03/96 and conducted a   complete fire monitoring evaluation which included taking a full range of      vegetative samples.  The PNF was flown on the same day to determine the        potential for spread.  The fire burned in a down and dead Douglas Fir, but did not spread on the ground due to sparse fuels and rocks and green grass.  The   fire was monitored daily by the Mt. Washburn lookout, ranger and fire          management staff. The Crevice PNF was declared out on 07/22/96 after being     visited by fire monitoring staff.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. NFDRS FUEL STATION: GP12 - not a valid value, set to null End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Divide Fire was discovered by a USFS employee at 2040 on 07/11/96.  The    fire was reported as a single snag burning 1/4 mile west of Hwy 191 near the   north end of Divide Lake.  The snag fell over and the only heat was in the     stump hole of the snag and was reported as having low potential for spread     through the green grass surrounding the fire.                                  The fire was declared a PNF and the Gallatin NF was advised of this fire and   location.  An MMA of 5,000 acres was set, to be kept on the park, as the Lee   Metcalf Wilderness had not been signed, so no options for burning onto the     wilderness were in place.                                                      123 Noggles monitored the fire on 07/14/96 and declared the Divide Fire out at 1500.  He reported that it  burned about 8 feet in diameter and did not spread out any further from the base of the lightning hit snag.  The Gallatin NF was  notified.

THE PELICAN FIRE STARTED ON 8/11/96 AND WAS REPORTED BY LAKE RANGERS TO 700    FOX AT 1800.  PHIL PERKINS AND REGIONAL FMO DAN O'BRIEN WERE AT THE COYOTE     FIRE AND FLEW A RECON OVER THE PELICAN FIRE AT APPROZIMATELY 1900.  THE FIRE   WAS BURNING IN OLD GROWTH LODGEPOLE AND DOUGLAS FIR WITH TALL GREEN GRASS      SURROUNDING THE FIRE AREA JUST NORTH OF LAKE YELLOWSTONE AND HIGHWAY AND WEST  OF THE PELICAN VALLEY TRAIL.                                                   THE FIRE COMMITTEE WAS ASSEMBLED AT APPROXIMATELY 2000 AND THE PELCIAN FIRE    WAS DECLARED A PNF.  THE PELCIAN BURNED ACTIVELY ON 8/12, GROWING TO ABOUT 50  ACRES.  THE FIRE WAS NOT FLOWN DUE TO A VISIT BY PRESIDENT CLINTON WHO WAS     ABLE TO VIEW THE FIRE AS HE HIKED FROM MT WASHBURN TO CANYON BUT FIRE MONITORS WERE ASSIGNED AND MONITORED THE FIRE DAILY UNTIL LATED SEPTEMBER.              THE PELICAN WAS INACTIVE MOST OF ITS DAYS BUT GREW ABOUT 40 ACRES ON 8/14 AND  MAINLY CREPT IN DOWN AND DEAD FUELS TORCHING OUT SINGLE OR SMALL GROUPS OF     TREES FROM 8/15-8/27.  ON 8/27 STRAONG THUNDERSTORMS CAUSED THE FIRE TO SPOT   ACROSS PELICAN CREEK TO THE NW INTO THE LOWER SULPHUR HILLS AREA.  THE PELICAN FIRE MADE A MAJOR RUN ON 8/31, BURNING TO THE NE AND GROWING BY 1015 ACRES     FOR A TOTAL ACREAGE OF 1265. THE PRESCRIBED OVERHEAD TEAM TOOK OVER MANAGEMENT OF ALL PNF'S IN THE PARK ON 9/1 UNTIL 9/15.                                    THE PELICAN WAS MANAGED SUCCESSFULLY AS A PNF FOR ITS DURATION AN THE FINAL    ACREAGE WAS 1570.  THE PELICAN PNF WAS DECLARED OUT ON 10/28/96 AFTER          RECEIVING A SIGNIFICANT SNOWPACK.

THE HELLROARING FIRE WAS DISCOVERED BY THE YELLOWSTONE Rx TEAM WHILE           MONITORING THE COYOTE PNF AT 1013 ON 08/16/96.  IT WAS LOCATED HIGH ON THE     RIDGE LINE SOUTH OF HELLROARING PEAK.  SINCE IT WAS WITHIN THE COTOTE MMA, IT  WAS DECLARED A PRESCRIBED NATURAL FIRE AND MONITORED BY THE YELLOWSTONE Rx     MODULE.  IT GREW TO 25' X 15' IN SIZE AND WAS DECLARED OUT ON 09/09/96.

THE MARY FIRE WAS STARTED BY LIGHTNING ON 8/24 AND REPORTED TO 700 FOX BY MT   SHERIDAN LOOKOUT AT 1246. THE MAIN CONCERN ON THE MARY FIRE WAS THE HISTORIC FIRE LOOKOUT TOWER ON TOP OF MARY MOUNTAIN.                                         FIRE MONITORS WERE ASSIGNED ON 8/27  AND STRUCTURE PROTECTION WAS SET UP TO    TO PUMP OUT OF AN EIGHTEEN GALLON PROTABLE TANK.  THE MARY FIRE WAS NEVER      VERY ACTIVE, MAINLY SPREADING FROM DOWNED TREE TO TREE WHILE TORCHING OUT AN   OCCASIONAL TREE OR TWO.  IT WAS MONITORED UNTIL 9/12 WHEN RAIN SHOWERS SLOWED  THE FIRE ACTIVITY AND THE FIRE MONITORS WERE DEMOBBED AND STRUCTURE PROTECTION REMOVED.                                                                       THE FIRE CONTINUED TO SMOLDER IN THE HEAVY DOWN AND DEAD FUELS WITH A LAST     PROBEYE FLIGHT CONDUCTED ON 10/2.  THE FINAL SIZED WAS 13.4 ACRES WITH THE     FIRE BEING DECLARED OUT ON 10/28/96 AFTER A PARKWIDE SNOWSTORM OF 8-18" FELL.  A MORE DETAILED DAILY NARRATIVE IS AVAILABLE IN THE FIRE MANAGEMENT OFFICE.

THE CHICKADEE FIRE WAS A LIGHTNING CAUSED FIRE THAT WAS REPORTED BY MT         SHERIDAN LOOKOUT AT 1534 ON 8/27/96. THE FIRE POSED NO THREAT  TO ANY VISITORS OR TO THE HIGHWAY CORRIDOR RUNNING   FROM WEST THUMB TO LAKE AND WAS NOT VISIBLE MOST OF THE TIME. While enroute 114 reported that she saw lightning start this fire and that it  was approximately 2 acres burning across the two trails, about 1/2 mile north  of the trailhead.  121 called for additional support requesting 121 Petrick/   Underwood and 121 Perkins to assist in the suppresion effort.                  The fire was initial attacked at 1830 by 121 and 121 Hobby.  The fire size was about 5 acres. the lamar ford fire was reported Sunday JUNE 14, 1998. It was reported to 700  and relayed to 121 at 1815.  The reporting party was employee Jed VanDyke from YCR. He reported seeing a single Aspen Tree smoldering near the Lamar Ford.    Jed was not available for an interview.  The decision was made to talk to Jed  then try and fly the fire Mon.  226 was notified of the fire and its approxima te location.                                                                   Monday June 15 121 interviewed jed and was able to get an exact location and   probable cause of lightnim                                                      lightning. The fire was confirmed as a single aspen tree with no other trees a round it. The plan was to fly the fire since it was located on the south side  of the Lamar River and there is no bridge access an no safe ford area. The wea ther was rainwith low clouds and flight plans were cancelled.                  The plan was to fly Tuesday June 16, 1998 but rain snow and low clouds preclud ed any flight operations today.  The status of the fire is probably out due to the amount of rain and snow received overnight.  The cause and status of the f ire will be determined when the fire is flown.                                 On Wed. June 17 inclement weather prenented any flight out once again.  The ar ea continues to receive rain each day and is probably out.  The fire will be c hecked when the weather breaks.                                                On Thurs. June 18, 1998 the Lamar Ford fire was investigated and monitored at  1430 by 121, 121 noggles and123 McClure.                                       They flew to the fire in Helicopter N57948 due to being located on the SW side of the Lamar River with no bridge and unfordable.  The fir ewas lightning caus ed when it struck a dead aspen and burned an area of approximately .1 acres in the grass and down and dead aspen trees.  Fuel samples were taken and the fire declared out at 1500.

The Coyote fire was reported by 223 on 7/11/98 at 1700 near Coyote Creek.  The fire was a single green Douglas Fir, the fire burned mainly the downed portion of the tree and some of the duff. The grass was very green and lush and did no t carry the fire.  The fire was visited by 121  and 123 Graff to determine the exact cause and and sixe up the fire as a potential natural fire.  The potenti al growth was minimal and risk was determined to be low due to the green fuels , very little vegetation to spread fir ethrough and no down and dead carrier f uels.                                                                          The fire was declared a natural fire and was managed as such untol it was decl ared out on 7/22/98.  The fire was monitpred daily by the MT. Washburne Lookou t who had a direct visual on the fire.  Monitors visited the fire on 7/14 and  again on 7/22 when it was declared out.  The fire remained with in prescriptio n and burned only the single Douglas Fir tree.

A MOTORIST REPORTED THE SNAKE FIRE TO 516 AT 1450 ON 07/27/98.  THE MT SHERIDA N LOOKOUT CONFIRMED THE FIRE AS A LIGHTNING CAUSED FIRE DUE TO RECENT LIGHTNIN G IN TH AREA.  THE INITIAL FIRE REPORT WAS SMALL, PUTTING UP ONLY A LOW VOLUME OF SMOKE.  THE FIRE AREA RECIEVED MODERATE RAIN BY 1900, THE FIRE LOOKOUT COUL D NOT SEE ANY MORE SMOKE FROM THE FIRE.  THE FIRE WAS DECLARED A NATURAL FIRE  AND WAS VISITED BY FIRE MONITORS ON 7/28/98.   THE MONITORS REPORTED THAT TWO  TREES HAD TORCHED OUT IN SUBALPINE FIR AND THAT THE FIRE WAS SMOLDERING IN THE 100 HR FUELS AND CREEPING IN THE DUFF.  THE GRASS WAS VERY GREEN AND THE MONIT ORS STATED THAT THE FIRE HAD VERY LOW POTENTIAL FOR MODERATE GROWTH.  FUEL     SAMPLES WERE TAKEN FROM THE SITE.  THE LOOKOUT DID NOT SEE ANY MORE SMOKE FROM THE FIRE.  IT WAS VISITED TWICE MORE BY FIRE MONITORS AND DECLARED OUT ON      8/10/98, BURNING NO MORE ADDITIONAL AREA.

The Beaverdam fire was reported by boat Ranger Chuck Wagner at 1600 on         7/28/98.  The fire smoked up for about one hour then received some rain.       The fire was reported to the Mammoth fire Cache on 8/2/98.  The fire was       declared a natural fire and the fire area was flown on 8/4.  No sign of the    fire was noted and the fire was not seen after the initial report by the       boat ranger or the Mt. Sheridan lookout.  The fire was declared out on 8/4/98.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. ACRES DISCOVERED: 0000000.0 - Changed to 0000000.1 End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Bison fire was reported at 0900 by a super cub on a research telemytry     flight (359).  The fire was reported at one log smoldering in heavy unburned   fuels.  Tower was notified and the fire monitors were dispatched to size up    and report on the fire.  Fire monitors 122 Hobby, Sorbel, and Miller arrived   at the fire at 1637 and confirmed the fire as lightning caused.  The fire was  declared a WFURB and the WFA documentation process begun.                       The initial fire report was a fire size of .1 acre, one large down and dead    tree smoldering with some burning through the ground fuels.  The fire behavior was low at that time and fuel samples were taken.  The live fuels are still    very green and are inhibiting fire spread.    The fire has the potential to    burn several hundred acres perhaps several thousand before it would run into   the 1988 burned area.  The fire was monitered daily by the fire mngmt monitors the Tower rangers and the mt. Washburn Lookout.  The fire was visited on 725   121 and several fire monitors anfd the fire was warm but had almost burned     itself out.  The fire had not grown from the initial assesment.                The fire was visited again on 08/06 and declared out.  The final fire size was .1 of an acre.

The Mt. sheridan Lookout discovered the continental fire at 1555on 07/24/1999  It was reported as smoking up moderately about 4 miles west of the Shoshone    Geyser basin.  512, 313, and 411 were contacted and the helicopter from the BT was lined up to fly 512 on a recon of the fire.  The weather conditions were   very hot temperatures, low humidities and strong gusty winds.  The fire recon  showed a fire about .25 acres in size, and torched about 6 trees and was       burning in the jackpots.  The fire was declared a fire use fire and allowed    to burn naturally with daily monitoring.                                       121 and 121 Sorbel flew the fire on the morning of 7/25 to size it up and get  a better location on the fire.  121 later hiked in to the fire and moniterd it in the afternoon.  He found the fire to be smoldering in the duff and it had   torched about six trees in two distinct spots thatwere jackpots of fuel.  He   said that he encountered snowbanks on the hike in and this fire being          located just off the continental divide at 8500 feet, the fuels were still on  the wet side and would need to dry out before any growth could occur.  The     fire was monitered  daily by the Mt. sheridan Lookout but never smoked up      enough to be seen again.  The fire was visted by fire monitors on 08/04 and do declared out on that date.  The final fire size remained at .25 of an acre.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. The fire was reported as a spot putting up a moderated amount of smoke near    the Red Mountains. South Entrance was notified and 512 concurred that all the  prescription elements allowed this fire to be declared a Wildland Fire Use     Fire. 517 was dispatched to look for the fire along the south entrance road.   He was unable to spot the fire, so helicopter 948 was dispatched at 1502 along with two fire monitors to locate and montior the fire.                          The fire monitors were unable to locate the fire but did set down and gather   fuel samples from the area. The Red Fire was never seen again and was          determined to be rained out. The fire was declared out on 08/14/99 with the    final fire size being .1 of an acre.

Ranger 22B reported the Abiathar Fire at 0915 burning SW of Abiathar Peak.     The volume of smoke was small.  Three fire monitors were dispatched and flew t o the fire location to determine the cause of the fire.  They determined the   fire was lightning caused and completed the full monitoring process.  120 disc ussed the fire with 225, 110 and Superintendent Finley.  The decision was made to allow the fire to burn as  a natural fire, now called a Wildland Fire Use   Fire.  The Wildland Fire Assesment documentation was begun and Stages I and II were completed on Saturday.  The risk analysis determined that the fire danger and potential to burn to a size that would impact the Northeast area, Silver   Gate or Cooke City was low.  The fire can be seen from the highway wand will   be monitered daily by the NE Ranger staff and periodicaly by the fire moniters  The fire smoked up for 2 days after it was spotted then no further activity    was noted.  The area received several days of rain and was visited on 08/17/99 by on site fire monitors.  The fire was cold trailed by 120 and declared out.  The final fire size was .1 of an acre.

The Beula lake Fire was reported to Fire Dispatch at 1730 on 08/09/1999.  The  report came via teton dispatch. The visitor had tried to put the fire out but  was unable to.  He then hiked out to his vehicle and called the report in from Flagg ranch.  700Fox notified district and subdistrict personnel and formulate d the plan to send 3 firefighters in on 8/10/99 to check the cause of the fire  The 3 person crew reached the fire at 1100 on 08/10/99 and determined that the fire was human caused.  They suppressed the fire and declared the fire out at  1700.  They were able to suppress quickly being close to the lake andable to   use lots of water.  The crew remained on the fire to cold trail it and departe d later that evening.

THE STONETOP FIRE WAS REPORTED TO FIRE DIPATCH AT 1200 ON 8/10/99.  MOUNT      WASHBURN LOOKOUT REPORTED THE FIRE AS 1/4 TO 1/2 ACRE AT 1208 AND GROWING      RAPIDLY.  THE FUEL TYPE WAS HEAVY OLD GROWTH LODGEPOLE PINE.  THE FIRE         ACTIVITY CONTINUED OT INCREASE AS IT WAS BEING DRIVEN BY SOUTHWEST WIND.       HELICOPTER 948 WAS ON A PROJECT ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE PARK AND WAS SENT TO  RECON AND PROVIDE AN UPDATE.  THE UPDATE PUT THE FIRE SIZE AT 2-3 ACRES AND    BURNING ACTIVELY.  FIRE MONITORS WERE SEN TO FISHING BRIDGE HELISPOT AND FLOW  IN TO MONITO THE FIRE AND GATHER MORE INTELLIGENCE AND GATHER FUEL SAMPLES.     THE WFA DOCUMENTATION PROCESS WAS BEGUN AND THE FIRE DETERMINED TO BE LIGHTNIN CAUSED AND WAS DECLARED A WFU FIRE.  THE FIRE MONITORS COMPLETED THEIR INTIAL  MONITORING AND GATHERED FUEL SAMPPLES THAT WERE PUT IN THE OVENS THAT EVENING. THE PLAN WAS TO HAVE THE MONITORS VISIT THE FIRE AGAIN ON 8/11, MAP THE FIRE   GROWTH AND GATHER MORE FUEL SAMPLES.                                            THE FIRE HAD ABOUT TWO DAYS OF MODERATE ACTIVITY, GROWING TO 3 ACRES ONE DAY   AND FINALLY TO 6 ACRES BEFORE HEAVY LOCAL WET THUNDERSTORMS HIT THE FIRE ON    8/20.  AFTER 8/20 NO ADDITIONAL GROWTH WAS OBSERVED AND THE FIRE RECEIVED MORE RAINFALL DURING AUGUST.  THE FIRE CONTINUED TO SMOLDER, WAS MONITORED DAILY    BY LOOKOUTS AND WAS DECLARED OUT ON 9/15/99.  FINAL FIRE SIZE WAS 6 ACRES.

The wrong fire was reported by the Mt. Washburn lookout at 1455 on 8/20/99.    The fire was lightning caused from a storm that had just passed through. The Wrong Fire did not grow after the initial burning period because of rain t that fell the evening of 8/20.  The fire continued to smolder and was checked  by monitors several times and was monitored daily by the lookouts.  The fire   The fire area continued to receive significant rain during august and was decl ared out on 9/15/99.  The final fire size was .1 acre in about 8 separate smal l spots.

This event occurred 08-18-2000.                                                 The Moose fires were contained on the south and east flanks by 1988 burns.     Put monitors out on this fire to install plots and collect fire behavior data.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 2: R - Mapped to T End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Plateau fire was a lightening-caused fire reported by fixed-wing aircraft  14 JF                                                                          at 1500 on8/16/2000.  The fire was 3                                           to 5 acres in size at the time of first report and growing rapidly.            Suppression action was taken due to teh extreme fire season and a national     preparedness level of 5.                                                        Initial attack was 4 helitack with bucket support from the Park contract       helicopter.  An additional 6 firefighters were flown in.  The fire was         approximately 10 acres in size at IA.                                           The fire escaped IA and since it was in a remote area of the park and in a     Fire Use zone, a containment strategy was selected as the appropriate          management strategy.  This action reduced firefighter exposure, did not        require a massive suppression resource response, and saved considerable        dollars.  The Plateau fire was monitored for the remainderof the fire season   with no additional suppression action taken.                                    The fire was declared controlled on 9/20/00 at 2760 acres and was declared out on 10/10/00.  The final fire size was 2,760 acres.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: U - Mapped to Y End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Knothead fire was a human-caused fire started by a RV that over heated its brakes and pulled off the roadway into the grass in the Gibbon Meadow area,    starting a small grass fire.  Park visitors reported the fire at 2000 on       8/16/00.  Two visitors were able to take quick action and suppress this fire,  stopping the spread at 0.1 of an acre in size.  Ranger patrol checked the fire later that night and reported no fire activity.  The fire was visited by 2     Yellowstone helitack on 8/17/00 who declared the fire controlled and out at    0900 on 8/17/00 at 0.1 acre in size.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: S - Mapped to W End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Stone fire was reported by 36B, a research Super Cub at 1334 on 8/19/      00.  The fire was located in the middle of the Pitchstone Plateau and was      reported as a spot fire.  Due to the extreme 2000 fire season a preparedness   level of 5, the fire was put in a suppression strategy.                         The fire was flown later that afternoon but was not found.  Subsequent flights never found the fire again.  The fire was declared controlled on 9/1/00 and    declared out on 9/20/00 at 0.1 acre in size.

The Hancock fire was reported by research aircraft 36B at 1423 on 8/23/2000.   The fire was located NW of Mt. Hancock and was reported as only a spot fire.   The fire was flown later that afternoon and was not found.  The fire was       placed in a confinement strategy.  Subsequent flights never detected the fire  again.  The fire was declared out on 9/1/00 at 0.1 of an acre in size.  No     personnel were assigned to the fire.

The Basin fire was detected by the Mt.Sheridan lookout at 1400 on 8/23/2000.   The initial report of the fire was small in size burning in Basin Creek, SW    of the Mt. Sheridan lookout.  This fire was declared a suppression fire and    initial attack was at 1503 with 4 helitack supported by 6HP.  The fire was     controlled at 1900 at 0.1 of an acre and mopped-up.  The fire was monitored    for several days and declared out on 9/1/00 at 0.1 of an acre.

At approximately 1105 on 06/07/01 while disposing of old explosives by         detonation at Frog Rock including VERI Pistol rounds, eleven small fires       were started by the rounds landing several hundred feet beyond the blasting    zone.  The fires were in grass and sage brush the largest of which was         8'x8'.  the firese were quickly extinguished.  The engine was requested for    patrol purposes and for future need.  The area was patrolled later in the      day and no addistional smokes were found.  The fire was checked on 6/8.  No    smoke or heat was found and the fire was declared out at 1500.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 2: U - Mapped to Y End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  A fire that burned out of an employee campfire was reported by a NPS           maintenance worker at 0930 on 6/26/01.  Two firefighters, Richard Jones and    Shawn Jackson, were dispatched to the fire and arrived at 1000.  The fire had  escaped the fire ring burned two large down logs that are used to sit on and   also into the wiland fuels beyond the logs encircling the fire ring.  The      firefighters piled the burning logs in the fire ring, then dug line around the fire cooling down the perimeter with bladder bags.  The fire was controlled at 1100.  Mopup was continued with additional water used to cool down the fire    throughout the afternoon. The fire was declared out at 1600.                    Ranger Adam Purcell investigated the fire and cited the employees that were    responsible for starting the fire.

THE LITTLE FIRE WAS DISCOVERED BY THE MT HOLMES LOOKOUT AT 1428 ON 9/10/01.    THE FIRE MET ALL CRITERIA AND WAS DECLARED A FIRE USE FIRE.  THE FIRE WAS      MONITORED DAILY BY ON-SITE MONITORS OR THE MT HOMES LOOKOUT.  THE FIRE MADE    SEVERAL SMALL RUNS WHICH CAUSED THE CLOSING OF TWO CAMPSITES NEAR OLD FAITHFUL AND THE TRAIL THAT CONNECTS MYSTIC FALLS TO FAIRY FALLS.                       A STAGE II ANALYSIS WAS COMPLETED BY A FUMA (T) ASSIGNED TO BILL ADAMS FUMT    THAT WAS BROUGHT IN TO MANAGE THE SULPHUR FIRE.                                THE FIRE BURNED ACTIVLY UNTIL 10/10, BURNING A TOTAL OF 430 ACRES AND REMAINED IN PRESCRIPTION THE ENTIRE DURATION OF THE FIRE.  THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT    ON 11/12 AT A TOTAL OF 430 ACRES.

THE      FIRE WAS REPORTED TO BE DUE TO A DOWN POWERLINE. AT 1645 814 RESPONDED WITH 1  ADDITIONAL PERSON AND AN ENGINE. 814 ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 1704 AND REPORTED THE FIRE WAS OUT AND A STANDING GREEN TREE HAD BEEN HIT BY A POWERLINE AND HAD     SUSTAINED A SIX INCH BURN ON THE TRUNK. 814 CONFIRMED THE FIRE WAS OUT AND ALL UNITS WERE RELEASED AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT ON 6/18/02.

The Broad Fire was detected at 1518 on 6/27/02 by the Mt. Washburn lookout.    The fire smoked up for a short period of time and then died down and was not   located or seen again until the afternoon of 7/5.  The fire was flown by the   Park FMO and AFMO and jumpers and air tankers were ordered.  The wx conditions were too windy to jump so all IA operations were psotponed until 7/6.  On 7/6, the AFMO plus 5 ff IA'd the fire and cut an operational helispot.  Retardant   was dropped but the fire grew steadily all day to about 240 acres.  On 7/7 the IA crew shot 3200' of FLE and made good progress even though winds were strong Additional resources were secured for 7/8 and 20 ff were flown into thefire    but a passing cold front with winds over 35mph created unsafe conditions for   the extended attack to continue.  All ff were demobed and a fire Use team was  ordered.                                                                        The fire was monitored on 7/9 and 7/10.  The FUMT reconned the fire on the     afternoon and began making their fire behavior calculations and long-term      analyses.  At 0710 on 7/11 with the fire at approx 2500 acres, Cook's FUMT     recommended that a Type I team be ordered.                                      The Type I Team (Frye's) arrived the afternoon on 7/12 and were briefed.  The  fire was approx. 5,000 acres.  A safe operational plan was developed and       implementation began on 7/13 with direct attack at the SW corner of the fire   tieing into the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone and using Type I helicopters   to drop water on the fire burning in the canyon and threatening to cross to    the west side of the Yellowstone river.  The direct attack was immediately     successfl and steady progress was made working counter-clockwise around the    fire and leap frogging spike camps and crews.  Some afternoon rain showers     assisted the suppression efforts until the fire was contained and the Type I   team was demobbed on 7/26.                                                      The Park assumed command again on 7/26 with a Type 3 organization that         continued to hit the hot spots and smokes and monitoring the fire until        significant rain was received in early September.  The fire continue to        smolder in the interior portions and the fire was monitored by the Mt.         Washburn lookout and overflights unti it was declared out.  The final          acreage was 9,140.

THE ARM FIRE WAS REPORTED ON 6/21/02 BY A PATROL RANGER ON THE EAST ENTRANCE   ROAD.  6HP WAS SENT IN WITH 2 INTIAL ATTACK PERSONNEL, KEVIN DOOLEY AND ART    TRUMAN.  THEY LINED THE FIRE AND REQUESTED 4 ADDITIONAL FIREFIGHTERS FOR THE   NEXT DAY.  ON 06/22/02, 4 ADDITIONAL FFT2'S WERE SENT IN AND SOME BUCKET WORK  WAS DONE.  THE CREW CONTINUED TO WORK THE FIRE IN 12" DEEP DUFF AND HEAVY      1000 HOUR FUELS.  ON 06/24/02, THE CREW WAS REPLACED WITH 6 FIRECACHE HELITAK  EFFECTS, AND MONITOR PERSONNEL.  THEY WORKED THE FIRE FOR A FEW MORE DAYS      UNTIL IN WAS PUT INTO PATROL STATUS.  THE FIRE WAS IR'D ON SEVERAL OCCASIONS,  BUT DUE TO THE HEAVY FUELS AND HOT AND DRY WEATHER PATTERNS IT WAS MONITORED   OFTEN AND WAS CALLED OUT ON 08/01/2002.

The Buff fire was reported at the same time as the Stonetop on 6/27/02.        3 fire fighters were sent in via the park helicopter. They walked the fire the rest of the day and were pulled off that night. The fire was checked the next  day with no heat or smoke noted. The fire was IR on7/21. No heat was found and the fire was declared out.

The Stonetop was reported on 6/27/02. The park helicopter and 3 helitac were   dispatched. The fire was lined and the crew pulled for the night. The fire was worked all day on 6/28 by 3 firefighters. The fire was monitored daily from    6/29 by the Washburm lookout and frequent fly overs by park helicopter. The    fire was IR on 7/21 . No heat was found and the fire was declared out.

On 6/27 an NPS employee observed a lightning strike and a smoke between Fawn   Pass and Bacon Rind. Helicopter 6HP was dispatched w/ 3 helitac. The fire was  lined and supported by bucket drops. All personnel were pulled off that evenin On 6/28  the fire was cold trailed and mopped up.The fire was IR on 7/21. No   heat was found and the fire was declared out.

At 1945 on 6/27/02 225 Rathman reported the fire North of Lamar River TH.It    was reported 3/4 mile away and near the base of Druid Pk. Helicopter 7CH       with 121 Sites and 122 Miller were dispatched to the fire and arrived at 2048. 123 Sites reported the fire in a small Doug Fir surrounded by meadow. At 2128  123 Sites reported that the tree was down and a line put around it. Miller     and Sites spent the night on the fire monitering it. At 1300 hrs the next day  both left the area. The fire was IR on 7/21/02. No heat was found and it was   declared out.

The Divide Lake fire was reported on 7/6/02 at 2056 by a visitor. Gallatin     patrol checked on the fire but were unable to locate it. No smoke was seem     again on 7/7.An occasional puff of smoke was seen on 7/8. A Gallatin F.S.      crew and engine were dispatched but still were unable to locate the fire. On   7/9 the fire flared up and the park helicopter was able to locate the fire at  1410. The fire was reported between 5-10 acres in mixed heavy fuels. Lead 73   and tanker 555 were diverted from West Yellowstone. A load of jumpers was      ordered. 6Hp did bucket work supported by F.S. dip tanks. The fire was lined by  2201 and both crews remained on the fire over night.Crews were released o      7/10 and hotshots were released on 7/11. The fire was patrolled by NPS         personnel and it was IR and declared out on 7/21.

The Lahardy fire was reported on 07/09/02 by a Northeast Energy Employee. A    powerline was down and had started a down tree on fire. They checked the fire again that evening and twice the next  day. No heat was noted and the fire was declared out.

THE DUCK FIRE WAS REPORTED ON 08/27/2002.  A POWERLINE HAD FALLEN ON A TREE    AND STARTED A SMALL FIRE.  THE PARK ENGINE WAS AT GRANT TO SUPPORT BLIVIT WORK AND WAS DISPATCHED WITH TWO CREW MEMBERS.  THE FIRE WAS WORKED UNTIL 1215.     IT WAS CHECKED AGAIN AT 1700, NO HEAT WAS FOUND.  THE FIRE WAS CHECKED AGAIN   ON 08/28, FOUND TO BE COLD AND CALLED OUT.

THE DRAINAGE FIRE WAS REPORTED AT THE SAME TIME AND WITHIN A SHORT DISTANCE    AWAY FROM THE DOANE FIRE.  BOTH FIRES WERE PUT INTO FIRE USE.  THE AREA        RECEIVED SIGNIFICATN PRECIPITATION AND VERY LITTLE FIRE ACTIVITY WAS NOTED ON  THE DRAINAGE FIRE.  THE FIRE WAS IR'D ON 09/10, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE DOANE AND DRAINAGE FIRES WERE DISCOVERED AT THE SAME TIME AND IN THE SAME  AREA.  THE DOANE WAS THE LARGER OF THE TWO AT ONE ACRE.  LITTLE FIRE GROWTH    AND ACTIVITY WERE NOTED AFTER THE INITIAL SIZE UP.  BOTH FIRES WERE PUT INTO   FIRE USE.  THE FIRE WAS MONITORED DAILY BY THE SHERIDAN LOOKOUT WITH VERY      LITTLE ACTIVITY NOTED.  THE FIRE WAS IR'D ON 09/10, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE  FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE HUMPHRIES FIRE WAS DISCOVERED ON 08/28/02.  DUE TO THE LOCATION AND FUELS, IT WAS PUT INTO FIRE USE.  THE FIRE WAS MONITORED DAILY BY THE SHERIDAN LOOKOU T AND FREQUENT OVERFLIGHTS.  VERY LITTLE ACTIVITY WAS NOTED AFTER THE INITIAL  START.  SIGNIFICATN PRECIPITATION WAS ALSO NOTED IN THE AREA.  THE FIRE WAS    IR'D ON 09/10, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE PEBBLE FIRE WAS DISCOVERED ON 08/28/2002 BY A PATROL RANGER.  THE PARK     HELICOPTER AND TWO HELITAK WERE DISPATCHED.  THE FIRE WAS WORKED UNTIL DARK.   THE NEXT DAY THE FIRE WAS CHECKED AND NO HEAT WAS FOUND.  THE FIRE WAS IR'D ON 08/31, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE PHANTOM FIRE WAS REPORTED ON 08/28/02.  AFTER ANALYSIS OF THE FIRE, IT WAS PUT INTO FIRE USE.  THE FIRE WAS MONITORED DAILY BY THE SHERIDAN LOOKOUT WITH  VERY LITTLE ACTIVITY NOTED.  THE FIRE AREA RECEIVED SIGNIFICANT PRECIPITATION  SHORTLY AFTER THE INITIAL START AND ON SEVERAL DAYS THEREAFTER.  THE FIRE WAS  IR'D ON 09/02, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE FOUNTAIN FIRE WAS DISCOVERED ON 9/4/02 BY A VISITOR.  THE PARK HELICOPTER  6HP, AND 4 HELITAK WERE DISPATCHED.  THE FIRE WAS REPORTED TO BE 1 ACRE IN     SIZE.  THE FIRE WAS WORKED UNTIL 1800 THAT DAY BY THE HELITAK CREW WITH BUCKET SUPPORT FROM 6HP.  THE FIRE WAS COLD TRAILED AND MOPPED UP THE NEXT DAY.  THE  FIRE WAS IR'D ON 9/10, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE ROCKY FIRE WAS DISCOVERED ON 09/05/2002.  AFTER ANALYSIS OF THE FIRE       POTENTIAL AND THE FIRE AREA, IT WAS PUT INTO FIRE USE.  THE FIRE WAS MONITORED DAILY BY THE SHERIDAN LOOKOUT WITH VERY LITTLE ACTIVITY NOTED.  THE FIRE       RECIEVED SIGNIFICANT PRECIPTATION OVER THE COURSE OF A FEW DAYS.  THE FIRE WAS IR'D ON 09/10, NO HEAT WAS FOUND AND THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT.

THE FREIGHT FIRE WAS REPORTED BY NORTHWEST ENERGY EMPLOYEE JACK ALTIMUS AT     1915 ON 5/16/03.  THE FIRE WAS CAUSED BY A DOWNED POWERLINE.  RANGER TIM       TOWNSEND AND VOLUNTEER BRANDY BRANSTETTER ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 1925 HOURS.      THE FIRE HAD BURNED THROUGH DEAD DRY GRASS THAT HAD GROWN ABOVE A DAMP MARSHY  AREA.  THE FIRE APPEARED TO HAVE MOSTLY BURNT ITSELF OUT WITH THE EXCEPTION    OF ONE EIGHT FOOT LONG SNAG THAT WAS STILL BURNING.  THE LOG WAS BROKED UP AND PUT INTO A SMALL RUNOFF STREAM ADJACEMT TO THE FIRE.  ALL UNITS WERE CLEAR AT  1941. THE CAVE FIRE WAS REPORTED TO BECHLER RANGER KEN HUFFARD BY A HIKER WHO        WITNESSED THE LIGHTNING STRIKE NEAR CAVE FALLS ON FRIDAY AFTERNOON JUNE 14, 2  2003.  THE REPORT WAS TAKEN AT 1433 ON 6/14/03.  121(MITCHELL) AND 123 (HAFER) FLEW TO THE REPORT AREA AND LOCATED THE CAVE FIRE AT 44:08:59 X 111:00:32. THE FIRE WAS REPORTED AS ABOUT 1/4 ACRE IN SIZE WITH SOME ACTIVE FLAME OFF OF THE  DOWN AND DEAD 1000-HOUR FUELS AND CREEPING IN THE DUFF AND LITTER LAYER.  THE  FIRE WAS DETERMINED TO BE LIGHTNING-CAUSED AND WAS DECLARED A WFU FIRE.  FMO   PERKINS COMPLETED THE WFIP STAGE I AND II ANALYSIS.                             THE CAVE FIRE WAS RECONED ON 6/15 AND FUEL SAMPLES WERE TAKEN FROM THE FIRE    AREA.  THE FIRE WAS SMOLDERING IN THE 1000-HR FUELS AND IN THE DUFF AND LITTER RAINFALL WAS RECEIVED AT THE BECHLER RANGER STATION LATER THAT AFTERNOON.       THE CAVE FIRE WAS VISITED BY 120(PERKINS) AND 122(KLUKAS) ON 6/18 AND NO HEAT  WAS FOUND IN THE BURNED AREA.  AN ADDITIONAL SET OF FUEL SAMPLES WERE TAKEN    AND THE FIRE WAS DECLRED OUT, THE FINAL FIRE SIZE WAS 0.3 ACRES.

The fan fire was reported by 93                                                The Fan fire was reported by 93A - super cub ,while on an animal tracking      flight at 1013 on 07/12/03.  The report was a small fire burning in the 1988   Fan burn area.  The fire was declared a WFU in order to observe fire behavior  further in 1988 burned areas.  The fire was monitored and fire ecologist       Eric Miller with the fire effects crew and put in fire effects pilots in the   area.  The weather turned hotter, drier and windier and holding action was     taken on 07/15.  At the continued urging from the regional office, the fire    was converted to a suppression action on the 7/16.  Eight helitack dug line    around the fire but did not mop the fire up.  A WFSA was also completed.  The  fire received some rain on 7/25 and the fire was checked on the ground w/      a pal IR and declared out on 7/26/03 at 3.2 acres in size.

The Amethyst Fire was a lightning-caused fire that started at 1700 on 7/15/03  and was reported first by the Mt. Washburn lookout as 5.0 acres in size.  IA   forces were in other locations in the park and smokejumpers were requested.    8 jumpers were dropped at 1830 with the fire at approximately 20.0 acres in    size by that time.  These 8 jumpers were reinforced by 4 additional jumpers    and several retardant drops were made.  The fire was exposed to strong SW      winds being at the top of Amethyst Ridge and the fire was spreading by long-   range spotting.  The jumpers were reinforced by 8 more jumpers at 0700 on      7/16 with the fire at 20-25 acres.  The winds picked up during the day and     it was determined that the jumpers would not catch the fire.  The jumpers      were demobbed at 1600 by the park helicopter, the FMO flew the fire and a      WFSA was completed.  The WFSA called for 2 crews with local helitack and 2     additional helicopters to support the fire to keep it on the south side of     Specimen Ridge and out of the Lamar Valley.  Tim Klukas took over as ICT3 on   7/17 with 2 20-person crews, 1 light, 1 light and 1 heavy helicopter for       support.  Direct suppression efforts were taken and with the help of some      rainfall these resources were successful in containing the fire on 7/28/03     at 315.0 acres.  The crews were demobbed and the fire was put in patrol/       mopup status until the fire was PALMIR'd and declared out on 8/5/03.

OUTFITTER TOM HEINTZ REPORTED LIGHTNING UP SLOUGH CREEK EAST OF ELK TONGUE     CABIN AT APPROX 1500 ON 07/14.  THE FIRE WAS NOT FOUND UNTIL 0730 ON 7/16/03   BY JUMPER 13 WHILE DROPPING JUMPERS ON THE AMETHYST FIRE.                       THE FIRE WAS SIZED UP AT .1 TO .25 ACRES IN DENSE TIMBER.  5 JUMPERS OUT OF    WEST YELLOWSTONE JUMPED THE FIRE AT 0911.  THEY LINED THE FIRE BY 1200 AND     BEGAN MOP-UP.  THE FIRE WAS CALLED CONTROLLED AT 1900 AND DECLARED OUT ON      THURSDAY MORNING, JULY 17TH, 2003.  THE FINAL FIRE SIZE WAS 0.3 OF AN ACRE.     THE JUMPERS WERE DEMOBED BY 6HP AT 1200 ON 7/17.

THE PUMICE FIRE WAS REPORTED BU 521 AT 1245 ON 7/18.  THE LOCATION GIVEN WAS   ON ELEPHANT BACK MOUNTAIN 2 MILES NORTH OF BRIDGE BAY.  MINUTES LATER THE MT   SHERIDAN LOOKOUT REPORTED THE CORRECT LOCATION.                                 HELICOPTER 7CH WAS SENT WITH INITIAL ATTACK CREW.  THEY WERE UNABLE TO LAND    CLOSE SO HELITACK LOADED UP THE BUCKET AND BEGAN DUMPS AND SMOKEJUMPERS WERE   REQUESTED FROM WEST.  THE HEAVY HELICOPTER, 94, A VERTOL WORKING THE AMETHYST  FIRE WAS DIVERTED AND WAS ABLE TO WASH THE FIRE DOWN.  8 SMOKEJUMPERS WERE     DEPLOYED SOON AFTER.                                                            A TYPE III IC, CHAD FISHER WITH 9 HIAWATHA NF CREW HIKED INTO THE FIRE ON 7/20 THE CREW GRIDDED AND MOPPED UP ALL DAY.  THE FIRE WAS FLOWN WITH A PALM IR     FROM 7/21-7/25 NO HEAT WAS FOUND.  THREE MEMBERS OF THE YELLOWSTONE FUM AND 7  HIAWATHA CREW MEMBERS CHECKED THE FIRE ON 7/26 AND USED THE PALM IR ON THE     GROUND.  NO SMOKES, HOTSPOTS OR HEAT WAS FOUND.   THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT ON 7/26/03.

THE ARNICA FIRE WAS REPORTED BY THE MT SHERIDAN LOOKOUT AT 1201 ON 7/19.       HELIFOPTER 508, A 212 WAS DISPATCHER, THEY WERE UNABLE TO LAND SO 7CH WAS      DISPATCHED WITH 2 YELLOWSTONE HELITACK, SEIFERT AND HOAK.  THE IA'D THE FIRE.  THE FIRE WAS FOUND IN A LIGHTNING STRUCK LOG ON THE GROUND.  THEY WERE ABLE TO KNOCK THE FLAME DOWN QUICKLY WITH BUCKET SUPPORT.  THE FIRE WAS CONROLLED AT   0.1 ACRES AND THEY DEMOBED AT 1900.  THE FIRE WAS FLOWN WITH THE PALM IR, NO   SMOKE OR HEAT WAS FOUND.  THE FIRE WAS DEVLARED OUT ON 7/26/03.

The Boundary fire was reported by Mt. Sheridan lookout as being 3 acres. It    was initial attacked by 8 smoke jumpers from WYS and a light helicopter with   bucket drops.  Bobby Sutton was the IC.  The jumpers were off WYS at           approximately 1815 and arrived at the fire at 2015.  They had no radio         communications with dispatch but were able to use a cell phone.  The ordered   a saw and a sat. phone which were cargo-dropped on 7/22 at 0930.  They worked  until 0100 on 7/22 and at 0600 continued constructing line, finishing the line at 0910.  They improved the line and mopped up, and departed the fire at       approximatley 1700 on 7/23.

The Signal fire was reported by Mt. Sheridan lookout.  A size-up pr            reported that it was burning in 2 trees and was receiving rain.  It was        identified as a suppression fire due to the fact that it had significant       potential and was not located inside a r                                       previously burned area.  It was suppressed using a helicopter buckets.         Case Martin and Doug Hoak were assigned to the fire.

The Judo fire was reported by a park employee to the park comm center at 1607  on 08/02/03.  The fire was located near the Frisbee Golf course in the         vacinity of the canyon developed area and the canyon water treatment plant     /sewage plant.  The cause was a cigarette.  Initial attack was by the          canyon fire dept. w/ 5 personnel.  they stopped the spread of the fire and     put 50 gallons of water on the fire. They were supported by 2 helitack person- nel in 7CH had also dropped buckets of water onto the fire.  The fire was con- tained/controlled at 1900 and mopping continued until dark.  The fire was      checked by the Canyon Rangers on 08/03/03 and declared out.  the fire size was at .25 of an acre.

The Grizzly Fire was reported by the Mt. Sheridan lookout at 1739 on 8/2/03.   The fuel type near the point of origin was primarily fule model 8.  There was  a 1919 fire burn area to the north which was a fuel model 10.  A WFSA was      completed and a modified suppression action was chosen (confine/contain).From  8/2-8/4 the fire was monitored under the confinement strategy with holding     actions taken on 8/5 by the fire use module with some line construction and    burnout to hold the fire on a well defined ridgeline.  This strategy was       working well until significant IA activity began on 8/11 with over 30 starts   occurring within the next few days.  All of the new starts except for one were successfully contained/controlled in IA.  The one exception was the East Fire  which was beyond all IA abilities from the fire's start and this fire burned   over 18,000 acres and burned into the Grizzly fire with both of these fires    being managed by a Type 2 team (Gardner) from the NW area.  The Type 2 team    managed the fires from 8/14-8/31 with the fire being turned back to the park   at about 90% containment and 18,500 acres for the East fire and 5,000 acres    being burned by the Grizzly fire.  Tim Klukas took over on 8/31 as ICT3 until  9/9 when rain and snow reduced the fire activity and all crews were released.  The fire continued to smolder and smoke up and was patrolled on a daily basis  by park firefighters until 10/28 when Yellowstone received its season ending   moisture event.  The fire as PALMIR'd and declared out on 11/05/03 at 5,000    acres in size.

The midway fire was the result of an airplane crash in the Midway Geyser       Basin that occurred at 1837 on 08/04/03.                                       A/C NX2584, an experimental airplane, a replica of the Hughes 1-13 was re-     ported having engine problems when it flew over the Old Faithful developed     area.  The plane crashed approx. 5 miles NW of Old Faithful landing on the     west side of the Firehole River 100 yds south of the Grand Prismatic Thermal   feature.  The crash started a small fire between the Firehole River and the    park boundary.  The fire was extinguished by 4 members of the Old Faithful     structure fire department at 2000 o 08/04/03.  The fire burned approx. 0.1     of an acre.

The Sportsman fire was reported by pilot Doug Chapman in 55Z while on a        research tracking flight.  The fire was reported at 0804 on 08/05/03.  The     fire was near Sportsmans Lake cabin, burning in heavy timber.  Smokejumpers    were ordered in and over the fire at 0932 4 jumpers were on the ground at      1003 and initial attacked the fire which was estimated at 0.2 acres in size. The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: U - Mapped to Y End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  The Daly fire was discovered by Doug Chapman 235Sierra at 1444 on 08/06/03.    There were no jumpers available at West Yellowstone.  Three people were drop-e ped in by helicopter 6HP: Blake Chartier, Doug Hoak, Case Martin.  They re-    ported that it was caused by lightning and skunking around the ground in       heavy thousand hour fuels in subalpine fir/spruce.  The helicopter worked      the fire w/ bucket drops and the firefighters constructed a fire line.   The   helicopter also inserted 2 blivets. Ranger Justin Ivory found an unattended campfire at campsite 8CI while on      patrol on 07/3/03 at 1600.  The campfire had a dry 6" OBH log into the fire    pit w/o cutting the log, so it extended outside the fire ring.  The campers    did not extinguish the fire properly and the fire burned down the log,out-     side the fire ring igniting an area 10'x5' in size.  The fire was burning      in grass and the forest duff and better.  The fire was lined and water was     carried from the Snake River to cal the fire down.  Ranger Ivory checked       the fire again on 07/05/03 and reported the burned area was still hot, so he   applied more water and continued mopping up.  He checked the fire on 7/10/03   and reported the area was still hot and again applied more water.  He checked  the fire again on 7/17/03 and the fire was cold and he declared out at that    time.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: S - Mapped to W End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  First off this is a WFU, a 49 fire and this worthless program made me enter    all the parameters for a prescribed burn.  If you really read these            narratives, I suggest you correct this program fro a 49 fire use action and    quit wasting my time on inof that is not relevant.                              The Frank fire was reported by the Mt. Sheridan lookout at 1358 on 8/8/03.     This was the first of 12 fires reported on 8/8/03, the start of the 2003       lightning bust.  This fire grew very quickly as Frank Island, and island of    638 acres had not burned in over 300 years.  The Park FMO witnessed the        initial growth of this fire while on the Grizzly Fire and immediately          declared this fire a WFU, as it was located on an island in the middle of      Yellowstone Lake.  It was not safe to attempt to suppress this fire because    the terrain was flat with no escape routes.                                     The fires spread quickly in the dense fuels, driven by strong,gusty thunder-   storm winds.  The fire burned intensely for 4-5 days, smoking in much of the   southern part of Yellowstone Lake, as well as the Lake and Grant Village       developed areas.  The fire was monitored by the Lake Rangers, boat patrol      rangers, the Mt. Sheridan lookout and fixed-wing overflights.                   The fire burned throughout August and September as it was burning in the       1000-hour fuels.  The fire was declared out on 10/01/03, burning 600.0         acres.

THE EAST FIRE WAS REPORTED BY MT. SHERIDAN LOOKOUT AT 1650 ON AUGUST 11.       HELICOPTER 6HP REPORTED AT 1702 THAT THERE WAS A LARGE SMOKE COLUMN, 300 -FT   FLAMES, AND IT WAS TOO WINDY FOR MEDIUM OR HEAVY HELICOPTERS TO WORK THE FIRE. AT 1714, 6HP SAID THAT THE FIRE WAS 50 ACRES, CROWNING AND SPOTTING IN HEAVY   TIMBER (SPRUCE/FIR AND SPRUCE), AND WAS MAKING A RUN TO THE RIDGE TOP.  NO AIR TANKERS WERE AVAILABLE.  THE FIRE BURNED 1900 ACRES IN THIS FIRST BURNING      PERIOD.  THE NEXT DAY IT BURNED AN ADDITIONAL 700 ACRES, NEARLY 2 MILES IN 6   HOURS, CROSSING INTO THE CROW CREEK DRAINAGE TO THE EAST AND THE BEAR CREEK    DRAINAGE TO THE NORTHWEST.  A TYPE II TEAM WAS ORDERED ON AUGUST 12 BY AFMO    A. MITCHELL AT THE CLOSE OF THE OPERATIONAL PERIOD.                             THE HEAVY CONCENTRATIONS OF DEAD AND DOWN LODGEPOLE PINE MADE IT A FUEL-DRIVEN FIRE.  EXTREME DROUGHT WAS A MAJOR CONTRIBUTOR TO THE LARGE WOODY MATERIAL AS  AVAILABLE FUEL.                                                                 DALE GARDNER'S PACIFIC NORTHWEST TYPE 2 TEAM ASSUMED COMMAND OF THE FIRE AT    1900 ON AUGUST 14 AND RECEIVED A DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY FROM BOTH THE PARK    AND THE SHOSHONE NATIONAL FOREST.  THE ICP WAS SET UP AT FISHING BRIDGE,       BEHIND THE YELLOWSTONE GENERAL STORE.                                           THERE WAS A TREMENDOUS AMOUNT OF MEDIA ATTENTION FOCUSED ON THE INCIDENT.  THE EAST ENTRANCE ROAD WAS CLOSED FOR A LENGTH OF TIME BY THE FIRE ACTIVITY, WHICH LIKELY ALTERED PLANS FOR MANY VACATIONERS (8/14- 8/28).                         THE FIRE MADE A PLUME DOMINATED CROWN FIRE RUN ON AUGUST 15, ALMOST 4 MILES    LONG AND 1 MILE WIDE, OUT OF CUB CREEK DRAINAGE TO THE EAST EDGE OF            YELLOWSTONE LAKE JUST NORTH OF LAKE BUTTE.  FOUR PRIVATELY OWNED VEHICLES PARK ED AT SEDGE CREEK ON THE BANK OF YELLOWSTONE LAKE WERE BURNED DURING THIS RUN. THE FIRE GENERATED ENOUGH FORCE TO TOPPLE TREES SOUTH OF THE 9 MILE TRAILHEAD  DURING THIS RUN.                                                                AT FULL MOBILIZATION OF RESOURCES ON AUGUST 25, 20 CREWS, 11 ENGINES, 7 WATER  TENDERS, AND 7 HELICOPTERS WERE BEING UTILIZED IN THE SUPPRESSION EFFORT.       MARC ROUNSAVILLE'S AREA COMMAND TEAM RE-DELEGATED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE FIRE   FROM AREA COMMAND BACK TO GARDNENER'S TEAM ON AUGUST 22.                        A TYPE 3 ORGANIZATION LED BY IC TIM KLUKAS RECEIVED A DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY  FROM THE SHOSHONE NATIONAL FOREST AND THE PARK TO MANAGE THE INCIDENT AS OF    AUGUST 31 AT 0700 HOURS.  THE ORGANIZATION IN PLACE USED 2 HANDCREWS, 2 T6     ENGINE, 2 TYPE 2 AIRCRAFT, 1 TYPE I AIRCRAFT, AND LOCAL OVERHEAD TO MANAGE THE COMPLEX.  THE TYPE 3 ORGANIZATION MANAGED THE FIRE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 11.         REHABILITATION AND MOP UP WERE COMPLETED IN SEVERAL AREAS OF THE FIRE.  DIVS D AND O WERE THE ONLY AREAS LEFT WITH REHAB NEEDS.  THE EAST FIRE WAS PATROLLED/ MOPPED UP UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30.  INTERIOR FIRE ACTIVITY ALONG CLEAR CREEK AND    PELICAN VALLEY PROMPTED ARIAL PATROLS UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30.  PRECIP EVENTS ON    OCT 7 AND 10 FINALLY SLOWED THE SMOKE REPORT CALLS.  THE LAST DAY OF           SIGNIFICANT FIRE ACTIVITY OCCURRED ON OCTOBER 10 IN CUB CREEK AND ON THE       GRIZZLY FIRE IN CLEAR CREEK.  SNOW THAT CAME ON OCTOBER 28 FINALLY PUT THE     FIRE OUT ON OCTOBER 31.

The Rocky fire was reported by helicopter 7CH at 0955 on 08/14/03.  7CH began  doing bucket work on the fire at 0958 and smokejumpers (Martin Mitzkus and     Charles Savoia) were dropped at 1130 and began work on the fire.  Mitzkus was  IC on the fire.  The fire was small and they called it controlled at 1800 that night.  the jumpers completed the mop-up and called the fire out on 08/15/03   and were demobbed.  The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The fire was caused by lightning and detected by network of lookouts within the Park.  Aerial reconnaisance indicated no immediate threats to structures or the public were present.  Later, a trail closure was put in effect in the area until mid September.  Incident Commander, A. Mitchell from YNP placed the fire in a confine, contain, strategy.  The fire was managed with minimum impact suppression techniques.  Personnel monitored fire via fixed wing, lookouts and a hobo weather station.  A micro RAWS was later put in.  No camps were placed on the fire.  The fire was monitored through its duration.  No suppression occured.  No rehab was needed.  The fire was successfully managed as a fire use fire under a suppression management title due to planning level 5 and local area fire work load considerations.  Fire had regular growth and activity upto 9-06-2003 after receiving .20 inches of rain.  Smokes and smoldering activity continued into October.  Initiation of fire occured under 97% conditions for the BI, and 1000 hr t.l. fuels from the Bechler RAWS data, 9%.

The fire had 2 spot and      was about 1/2 in size.  The jumpers controlled the fire at 2200 on 8/17.       Mop-up continued during the morning on 8/18 and they called the fire out late  in the day on 8/18 and they demobbed that night.  The final fire size was      0.5 (1/2).

The Pebble Fire was reported by Helicopter 7CH at 1725 on 9/24/03 while on a   fire mission for the Gallatin NF.  7CH landed at Mammoth and transported 2     helitack (Blake Chartier and Shawn Jackson) to the fire for a size up.
