A plan was     developed for 9/25 to fly in 8-10 ff with a Mark III pump.                      8 helitack were flown to the Pebble Fire on 9/25 with Chartier as ICT4.  About 10 snags were dropped and the crew set up the Mark III, dug line and mopped up the fire.  Brian Chan (226), Lamar Sub-District Ranger hiked in and            investigated the fire.  It was determined to be human-caused from burning      toilet paper near campsite 3P3.  The crew controlled the fire at 1800 at 0.3   acres.                                                                          On 9/26, 3 ff were flown in with Eric Miller as ICT4.  They used the PALMIR    to cold trail and found 3 hotspots.  They mopped up and continued cold         trailing.  They declared the fire out at 1430, rolled hose and netted the pump and were flown out.  The final fire size was 0.3 of an acre.

THE FIRE WAS  MONITORED BY AERIAL RESOURCES, THE WASHBURN LOOKOUTS AND LAMARR RANGERS FOL-   LOWING THE REMOVAL OF CAMP.  THE COOLER WEATHER DID NOT ALLOW THE FIRE TO      MOVE OUT OF ITS PERIMETER FOLLOWING PRECIP EVENTS.  THE FIRE WAS SIGNIFICANT   FOR MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL BECAUSE THIS WOULD BE ONE OF THE FIRST WFUS ON BIG    GAME RIDGE THAT WOULD NOT RECEIVE A SUPPRESSION ACTION STATUS AT THE ONSET.    HISTORICALLY FIRES ON THE RIDGELINE HAVE BEEN SUPPRESSED DUE TO THE ALIGNMENT  AND PROXIMITY OF THE SODA BUTTE DRAINAGE.  MANAGERS RECOGNIZED THE IMPORTANCE  OF LETTING THIS FIRE BURN UNDER MODERATE CONDITIONS WOULD BE OF GREATER BEN-   EFIT FOR RESOURCES, PERSONNEL,AND FINANCIAL CONSIDERATIONS.  ON 9/29, A IR     FLIGHT OVER THE AREA CONFIRMED THE FIRE OUT.  NMAPS AND FILES FOR THE INCIDENT

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. ACRES DISCOVERED: 0000000.0 - Changed to 0000000.1 End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  TOWER RANGER ED FOLTS REPORTED THE JUNCTION FIRE AT 1652 ON 8/16/04.  THE FIRE SMOKED UP LONG ENOUGH FOR ED FOLTS TO PROVIDE A LEGAL LOCATION.  DUE TO THE    PROXIMITY TO THE HIGHWAY AND THE TOWER/ROOSEVELT DEVELOPED AREA AND THE COM-   MITMENT OF RESOURCES TO THE PROMONTORY AND BROKEN ANKLE FIRES, THE DECISION    WAS MADE TO SUPPRESS THIS FIRE.  SMOKEJUMPERS WERE ORDERED AT 1700 AND RE-     SPONDED BUT WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE THE FIRE.  ROY RENKIN CONDUCTED AN AERIAL    FIRE RECON FLIGHT ON 8/17 AND WAS ALSO UNABLE TO LOCATE THE JUNCTION FIRE.     THE FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT AT THAT TIME ON 8/17 AND RULED A NATURAL OUT FIRE.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: U - Mapped to Y End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  BACKCOUNTRY RANGER GEORGE KITRELL REPORTED THE HIGH LAKE FIRE THROUGH RANGER   BONNIE GAFFNEY AT 1730 ON 8/16/04.  RANGER WAS ON BACKCOUNTRY PATROL FROM      THE SPORTSMAN LAKE CABIN AND REPORTED A SIGNIFICANT LIGHTNING STORM DURING     DURING THE NIGHT OF 8/15/04.  THE FIRE WAS LOCATED SOUTH OF HIGH LAKE AND EAST OF CAMPSITE WD6.  RANGER KITRELL SUPPRRESSED THE SMALL FIRE THAT WAS ABOUT 2'X 3' IN SIZE AND CONFIRMED IT WAS LIGHTNING-CAUSED.  HE FINISHED WORK ON THE     FIRE AT 1845.  THE PLAN WAS TO RE-CHECK THE FIRE ON 8/17.                      RANGER KITRELL CHECKED THE HIGH LAKE FIRE AT 1000 AND DECLARED IT OUT AT THE   TIME.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. TYPE INIT ATTACK 1: U - Mapped to Y End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  RANGER GEORGE KITRELL REPORTED THE SOGGY SNAG FIRE AS HE WAS RE-CHECKING HIS   SUPPRESSION EFFORTS ON THE HIGH LAKE FIRE AT 1545 ON 8/17/04.  THIS FIRE WAS   LOCATED ABOUT 15 YARDS FROM THE HIGH FIRE AND WAS A SINGLE-SNAG FIRE THAT      WAS SMOLDERING AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. RANGER KITRELL SUPPRESSED THIS FIRE   AND HAD EXTINGUISHED ALL SMOKE AND HAD COOLED IT DOWN BY 1645.  TH PLAN WAS    TO RE-CHECK THE TWO FIRES AGAIN ON 8/18.                                       RANGER KITRELL RODE TO THE AREA OF THE TWO FIRES AGAIN ON 8/18 AND DECLARED    BOTH FIRES OUT AFTER FINDING THEM OUT COLD.

TOWER RANGER ED FOLTS REPORTED THE BUTTE FIRE AT 1600 ON 8/17/04.  THE FIRE    WAS LOCATED SOUTH OF JUNCTION BUTTE ABOUT 3-4 MILES NORTH OF THE HIGHWAY AND   SOUTH OF THE JUNCTION FIRE REPORTED ON 8/16 BY ED.  THE INITIAL FIRE REPORT    PUT THE FIRE AT 1/4 TO 1/2 ACRE AND SMOKEJUMPERS WERE ORDERED TO SUPPRESS THE  FIRE DUE TO THE DISTANCE FROM THE HIGHWAY AND LACK OF PARK RESOURCES AT THAT   TIME.                                                                          TWO SMOKEJUMPERS WERE DROPPED ON THE FIRE AT 1720 AND HAD CONTROLLED THE FIRE  BY 2000.  THE FIRE ACTUALLY WAS ABOUT 5'X5' IN SIZE, MUCH SMALLER THAN FIRST   REPORTED.  THE FIRE RECEIVED SOME RAINFALL THAT EVENING WHICH ASSISTED THE     SUPPRESSION EFFORTS.  THE JUMPERS CAMPED OUT OVERNIGHT AND COMPLETED THE MOP-  UP OF THE FIRE THAT MORNING AND DECLARED THE FIRE OUT.  PARK HORSE PACKERS P/U 'D THE JUMPERS AND THEIR GREA AND TRANSPORTED THEM TO THE TOWER RANGER STATION THE JUMPERS WERE MARK DUFFY AND CHAD SCHUSSELL.

The following changes were made to this Fire Report as part of the conversion from SACS to WFMI on 05/14/2005. ACRES DISCOVERED: 0000000.0 - Changed to 0000000.1 End of SACS to WFMI conversion notes.  THE HAY MEADOW FIRE WAS REPORTED BY A PARK VISITOR AT 1640 ON 08/17/04 TO THE  LAMARR RANGER STATION.  THE LAMARR RANGER STAFF CHECKED OUT THE FIRE REPORTED  APPROXIMATELY 2 MILES EAST OF THE ENTRANCE INTO THE SLOUGH CREEK AND EAST OF   THE DIRT ROAD LEADING INTO THE SLOUGH CREEK CAMPGROUND.  SMOKEJUMPERS WERE     REQUESTED AND FLEW THE REPORTED FIRE AREA WHILE LOOKING FOR THE BUTTE FIRE.    THEY WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE THIS FIRE.  THE FIRE AREA WAS AGAIN CHECKED BY      LAMARR PATROL RANGERS AT 1740 AND WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE ANY SMOKE OR FIRE.     THE FIRE AREA RECEIVED SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL SHORTLY AFTER THE FIRE WAS REPORT- ED.  THE FIRE AREA WAS CHECKED BY LAMARR RANGERS AND ALSO BY A FIXED-WING      RECON FLIGHT ON 8/10/04.  THE HAY MEADOW FIRE WAS DECLARED OUT AFTER THESE     EFFORTS WERE UNABLE TO FIND THIS FIRE ON 8/18/04.

The Cascade fire was reported by Bill Malick, a construction worker contracted by the Bureau of Reclamation while working on the Grassy Lake Dam.  The fire was reported at 1600 on 6/21/05 following a lightning storm.  The reporting party stated that the fire was puffing up for a few minutes and then dying down.  He also stated that a heavy rain shower accompanied the lightning that started the fire.  The fire was declared a WFU and Tim Klukas was designated the FUMA and completed the Stage I WFIP analysis as per the Yellowstone FMP.  The report was completed at 1649 on 6/21/05.  The fire remained in Stage I until it was declared out.  The fire area was flown at 1230 on 6/22/05 by Eric Miller and Blake Chartier in helicopter N230US.  The fire was not located.  Checking weather records at the Bechler RS we noted that 0.16" of precip fell on 6/22 and an additional 0.57" of rain fell on 6/23.  After one week of no further report of any fire activity, the Cascade fire was declared out on 6/28/05 at 1800 by FMO Phil Perkins.

The Chickadee Fire was discovered by the Mt. Sheridan lookout at 1618 on 7/14/05.  The fire was located NW of Chickadee Lake in the Central Plateau FMU.  All parameters were met for WFU designation and a Stage 1 WFIP was completed.  The Mt. Sheridan lookout has an excellent view of this fire with hs spotting scope and will be able to monitor this fire all day, each day.  7/15/05 @ 1026 Miller and Moss flew the fire and reported the size at 0.25 of an acre, smoldering in thick lodgepole.  7/16/05 @ 1013 Miller and Moss landed at the Chickadee Fire for on-the-ground monitoring and set up a HOBO station.  Fuel samples were colledted.  The fire had grown to 1.5 acres by end of the monitoring day.  The Chickadee fire received over 3" of rain during the summer and made its last major run on 9/8/05.  The park received heavy rain and an early snow the first week of October and was declared out on 10/04/05 at 90.0 acres.

The Mt. Sheridan lookout reported a small fire near the Phantom fumarole on the east end of the Pitchstone Plateau at 1630 on 7/16/05.  The fire met all conditions and was declared a WFU and the WFIP Stage 1 analysis was completed.  The fire smoked up for several hours the evening of 7/16.  The FUM2 and a fire monitor flew an aerial recon flight over the fire area on 7/17 at 1113.  The landed at the report of the coordinates and were unable to find the fire.  From 7/17 - 7/20 the Mt. Sheridan lookout monitored the fire area.  On 7/21 the Park FMO flew a recon flight over the fire area.  The fire was not found and was declared out at 1400.  Final size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Red Fire was reported by the Mt. Sheridan lookout at 2105 on 7/22/05.  The fire was lightning-caused and was started just south of the Mt. Sheridan lookout in a 1988 burned area.  All conditions were met for a WFU and the Stage 1 WFIP analysis was completed.  The fire was flown on 7/23/05 and was reported as burning a single snag that had burned in 1988.  The fire continued to burn until 7/26 when the Mt. Sheridan lookout hiked down to the fire and declared it out.  The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Hills fire was reported by Lake Patrol Boat Ranger George Monroe on 8/1/05 at 2030.  The fire met all criteria and the Stage 1 WFIP was completed.  The fire smoked up on the Sulphur Hills for approximately one hour and then died down.  The fire area was flown by helicopter recon on 8/2 but the fire was not found.  The fire wa reported smoking up several more times after 8/2 by Lake Rangers but the fire was not found after a second recon flight.  The fire was declared out on 8/10/05 with the final fire size at 0.1 of an acre.

A contract employee from the road construction crew reported the Cody Peak fire on 8/2/05.  The smoke died down and then was reported to the Fire Management Office from an East Entrance employee at 1445.  The fire was located north of the East Entrance station and very close to the boundary with the Shoshone NF and near to Pahaska Tepee.  The WFIP analysis was run and it was determined that this should be a suppression fire due to its proximity to the park/forest boundary and potential for negative impacts to life and property.  The smokejumpers were ordered up and 2 jumpers from West jumped the fire at 1710, Wetzel & Rock.  The fire was burning in heavy down and dead trees and duff.  The fire was controlled at 1000 on 8/3 and declared out at 1200 on 8/3 at 0.25 acres in size.  The jumpers hiked out to the highway and were transported back to the West Yellowstone jump base.

The Bacon fire was reported by a UPS driver at 1215 on 8/3/05. The fire was located just off Highway 191 approximately 22 miles north of the town of West Yellowstone, MT. The fire was burning in a single snag and had involved some green grass at the base of the tree that was struck by lightning.  The WFIP analysis was completed and it was determined that this fire should be suppressed due to its proximity to Highway 191 and the potential to put smoke across this busy highway.  Assistance was requested from the Gallatin NF who sent an engine with 2 firefighters from West Yellowstone.The initial attack was at 1400 and the fire was controlled at 1800.  The engine crew returned to the fire on 8/4/05 and declared the Bacon fire out at 1500.  The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The J Loop was started by lightning in the J Loop of the Bridge Bay Campground.  The fire was reported by Ranger 7L15 at 1730 on 8/8/05.  The lightning strike blew a single tree apart but was followed by a heavy local rainstorm.  The tree smoldered for a few minutes but was extinguished totally by the rain.  Ranger 7L15 checked the fire at1749 and stirred the fire around with hand tools and declared the fire completely out at 1758.

The Butte Fire was reported by a park visitor to the Comm Center at 1719 on 8/8/05.  Ranger 7E30 was dispatched to the Lake Butte area and reported a single snag had been struck by lightning in the 2003 East Fire area and was smoldering.  This met all paramenters for a WFU fire and the Stage 1 WFIP was completed by Tim Klukas, FUM2.  The fire was monitored again on 8/9 with fire monitors who were unable to find the fire.  The fire area was monitored for a few more days with no smoke or fire activity noted.  The fire was declared out on 8/13/05 at 0.1 of an acre.

The Vermillion Fire was reported by Lake Patrol staff at 1745 on 8/8 shortly after the Butte fire was reported.  This fire was also lightning-caused by the same storm.  The fire smoked up for several hours and then died down.  The fire was located about 4 miles NE of the Hills fire. All parameters were met to declared this fire a WFU and the Stage 1 analysis was completed.  The fire area was flown by fire monitors in helicopter 7CH at 1129 on 8/9 and the fire was not found.  The fire area was monitored daily but was nver found again.  The fire was declared out on 8/22/05 at 0.1 of an acre.

The Elk Tongue fire was discovered by an employee from the Silver Tip Ranch at 1130 on 8/10/05.  The fire was reported burning east of the Elk Tongue cabin very high on the slope with cliffs above the fire.  All parameters were met to declare this fire a WFU and the Stage 1 WFIP analysis was completed.  A recon flight was conducted in 23S at 1609.  The fire was reported as a single tree smoldering with no visible flame.  The fire was burning in heavy spruce with continuos fuels to the north until it runs into 1988 burned area.  The potential is for burning several hundered acres.  The fire was monitored by the Mt. Washburn lookout and recon flights on a daily basis.  The fire was also monitored on-site by smokejumpers from the West Yellowstone jump base to gain experience as fire monitors.  The fire remained small until 9/8 when strong winds on a hot & dry day pushed the fire up slope and caused several spot fires to propogate.  Fire Management monitors (Miller & Moss) were flown to the Elk Tongue cabin on 9/9 for onsite monitoring under red flag weather conditions.  The Elk Tongue fire was flown and updated acreage put the fire size at 33 acres.  The fire began receiving heavy rain and snow on 9/11 and no further fire growth occurred.  The fire was monitored daily until declared out on 10/4/05 at 33 acres in size.

The Meldrum Fire was reported by George Kittrell and Bonnie Gafney while on backcountry ranger patrol in the West District.  They reported seeing smoke on the southern portion of Meldrum Mountain at 1420 on 8/27/05.  Helicopter 230US was dispatched with two helitack to locate and size up the fire.  The recon was over the fire area at 1507 but could not find the fire.  All parameters were met to declare the fire a WFU and the Stage 1 analysis was completed.  The fire was monitored by the Mt. Holmes lookout and flown again on 8/28 and 8/29 with no smoke seen or fire found.  The fire was declared out on 9/5/05 with the final fire size at 0.1 of an acre.

The Sabbath Fire was reported by a hiker at 1420 on 9/4/05.  Helicopter 0WY was dispatched with 2 monitors to recon the fire.  They reported a small fire burning in 2-3 dead trees in the 1988 Storm Creek fire.  There area was heavily burned in 1988 and there is no other vegetation close by to burn.  The fire met all parameters to be declared a WFU and approval was received from Regional FMO Len Dems.  A stage 1 WFIP analysis was completed.  The Sabbath fire was monitored by the Mt. Washburn lookout and aerial recon flights but no additional fire activity was noted.  A major storm impacted the fire on 9/9-9/12 with the fire area receiving rain and snow.  A aerial recon flight with the PALM IR camera flew the fire on 9/13.  There was no sign of any smoke or fire activity and the fire was covered with several inches of snow.  The fire was declared out on 9/13 with the final size of 0.1 acres.

The Tardy Fire was caused by lodgepole pine trees falling across a park powerline near Otter Creek.  The fire was discovered by Ranger boone Vandzura at 1450 on 10/1/05.  The fire was reported to Fire Dispatch.  There were no fire resources available at that time as the contract helicopter had terminated on 9/30/05 and all funding for seasonal personnel as well.  Assistant FMO Andy Mitchell was notified and traveled to the fire location with a Northwest Energy employee on the morning of 10/2/05.  The weather was rain mixed with snow at the time of initial attack.  The fire was 0.1 of an acre in size and Andy cut up the downed trees off of the powerline and exposed them to the elements.  The powerline was repaired.  The fire was controlled at 1200.  There was good accumulation of snow the remainder of the day and fire personnel checked the fire again on 10/3 and found no fire activity.  The fire was checked again on 10/6/05 and declared out at that time at 0.1 of an acre in size.

The Summit Fire was reported by the Mt. Sheridan lookout on 6/25/06.  The location was near Summit Creek half-way between Shoshone Lake and Lewis Lake burning a single snag in the 1988 burned area.  The fire was monitored by the lookout that night and flown by 3 fire monitors on 6/26/06 (Eric Miller, Chris Roy and Kyle Stetler).  The fire was not found and the Mt. Sheridan lookout did not see any smoke from this fire after the initial report.  The Mt. Sheridan lookout continued to monitor the fire daily but did not see it smoke up again.  The fire was declared out at 1400 on 7/1/06.  Final size wa 0.1 of an acre.

The Hellroaring Fire was reported by park employee Randy Baum at 1445 on 6/27/06 to Fire Dispatch.  The location was 0.3 of a mile east of the Hellroaring overlook on the south side of the highway.  Lightning blew the top out of a fir tree.  At 1501 Engine 1570 with Tim Klukas (FUMA2) plus Rehmer & D. Mitchell were dispatched to this fire.  Klukas and crew arrived at 1611 and began sizing up the fire.  It was determined that all parameters were met to declare this fire a WFU.  Klukas and crew monitored the fire until dark.  6/28/06 - fuel samples were gathered and a Hobo wx instrument was set out.  Smoke signs and Natural Fire - do not report were set up in a turnout near the fire.  The fire was monitored daily until it was declared out. The period this fire burned was a wet period in Yellowstone with the Mammoth wx station receiveing over 1 3/4" of rainfall.  The fire was visited by Eric Miller and Sean McEldery on 7/20/06 and they used the PALM IR camera to check the fire.  No heat or hot spots were found and they declared the fire out at 1000.  The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Sandy WFU was reported by the West Zone AFMO from the Gallatin NF, Anna Anderson on 7/3/06 at 1830.  The fire was reported aproximately 2 miles due east of highway 191, 8 miles north of West Yellowstone, MT.  The fire appeared to be lightning-caused and had hit a large Doug fir tree and was burning the tree and some ground fuels.  Three Yellowstone fire staff flew into the fire on 7/4/06 (Klukas, Tanuscu and Nagashima)in helicopter 7CH at 0930.  The monitors confirmed that the fire was lightning-caused, burning in a single Doug fire tree and smoldering in some green ground fuels.  Weather and fuel samples were taken.  The fire was monitored again on 7/7/06 by two Yellowstone monitors and 2 smokejumpers monitors from the West Yellowstone jump base.  The fire had not grown and several hot spots were detected.  Additional fuel samples were taken.  Two smokejumper monitors hiked into the fire on 7/12/06 and declared the fire out at 1100 after cold-trailing and finding no smokes or hot spots.  The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Bison Peak fire was reported by outfitter Phillip Bowers to backcountry ranger Kevin Dooley at 1351 on 7/12/06.  The weather precluded a flight and Ranger Dooley traveled up Slough Creek via horseback with Sheena Osgood and Chris Roy on 7/13/06.  At 1000 the fire was located and the monitors hiked to the fire and verified that it was lightning-caused, got an accurate GPS location, sized up the fire and gathered fuel samples.  The fire was burning in DF/SF and was about 0.1 of an acre in size.  The fire was declared a WFU and the Stage I WFIP was completed.  The fire was monitored daily by the Mt. Washburn lookout and had several visits by on-the-ground monitors and via aerial recon flights.  The fire did not grow appreciably over its lifespan.  Blake Chartier and Mike Wagner visited the fire on 8/18/06 and cold trailed the fire and used the PALM IR camera.  No heat or any hotspots were detected and they called the fire out at 1600. The final fire size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Magpie Fire was discovered by the Mt. Sheridan lookout on 7/17/06 at 1845.  The WFIP Stage I analysis was completed by FMO Phil Perkins who also flew the fire in 7CH on 7/18/06 at 0745.  This fire met all the parameters for a WFU and was managed as such until being declared out on 10/23/06 at 3,235 acres.  The FMO completed a WFIP Stage II analysis on 7/18/06 as the fire made about a 100 acre run that afternoon.  The Magpie Fire was located in the Central Plateau FMU and was surrounded by heavy 1988 burned area.  Andy Mitchell and Tim Klukas also served as FUMA's during the management of this fire and Andy completed the Stage III WFIP analysis with assistance from Roy Renkin who did the LTAN fire behavior analysis including RERAP and FARSITE runs.  Roy was able to be signed off as an LTAN this summer with assistance from Chip Collins from GRTE.  Roy Hall's SW FUMT reviewed Andy's Stage III as well as the IMR office and it was approved. The fire behavior did not warrant going into a Stage III management and the fire was managed as a Stage II WFU it's entire duration.  The Mary Mt. cabin was wrapped with fire shelter material and a WUI and hazard tree work was done in conjunction with the management of this fire.  The Yell helitack crew, fire monitors and FUM were involved in all aspects of managing this fire.  Ryan Tripp developed a remote starter pump system, to remotely start the portable pump located at the cabin via remote start from the helicopter so as not to place firefighters at risk to start the pump and fly or hike out from the cabin.  This is the first fire a Stage III analysis was completed and kudos are to be given to Andy, Tim, Roy and the entire Yell staff for the successful management of this fire.

The Alice Fire was reported by boat patrol ranger George Monroe at 1715 on 8/6/06 in the Sulphur Hills area, 4 miles north of the north shore of Yellowstone Lake.  The Mt. Sheridan lookout saw the fire briefly and provided coordinates.  A smokejumper aircraft traveling through the park did not locate the fire and the storm that started this fire rained it out.  This fire was not detected again after the initial reporting period.  It was delcared a natural out by the Park FMO on 8/18/06.

A thunderstorm blew a lodgepole pine tree across the powerline in the Lake area along the Natural Bridge road.  The fire was reported to 700 Fox by Lake maintenance staff on 8/11/06 at 1400.  The Park Type 6 engine was dispatched with Engine Foreman Ryan Tripp and helitack crewmember Damon Mitchell at 1600 from Mammoth.  They arrived on scene and hiked into the fire (this old road is closed to vehicle traffic for reclamation reasons) with 2 bladder bags, arriving at 1800.  Northwest Energy stabilized the scene and Ryan and Mitchell suppressed and mopped up the fire.  The fire was controlled at 1800 and declared out at 1900.  They returned to Mammoth.

The Stinky Fire was located by smokejumpers from West Yellowstone on a patrol flight in J-13 at 1705 on 8/15/06.  Due to the proximity to the Shoshone NF and their reluctance to take on anymore fire due to the Little Venus and the Purdy Fires, this fire was put into the Appropriate Management Response (AMR)category of suppression and confined to Yellowstone NP.  This fire was monitored closely each day and monitoring crews were placed on the fire on and suppression actions were taken using aerial retardant, smokejumpers, helitack and fire monitors to halt the fire spread and keep it within the pre-establlished containment lines and the Park boundary.  The fire was well managed and valuable fire effects and fire behavior informaiton was gathered in the portions of the fire that had previously burned in 1988.  Andy Mitchell and Tim Klukas did an excellent job of managing this fire while the Magpie WFU was also burning over 3,000 acres.  All the goals of this containment effort were accomplished.  The fire received moisture in mid-September and a PALM IR flight on 9/27/06 did not detect any smokes, only a few areas of heat.  Additional rain and snow were received and the fire was declared out on 10/23/06 with the final acreage at 1,010 acres burned.

The Big Thumb was reported by a park visitor at 1407 on 8/16/06.  The Grant Village fire department was called and when they arrived a park visitor was trying to put the fire out.  The engine crew hit the spot fire with their deluge gun and basically put the fire out.  Two helitack, Ryan Tripp and Kory Rehmer were dispatched from Mary Mt. cabin to the Grant Village helispot and were transported to the fire location for fire investigation and to make sure the fire was out.  The fire was located 150' west of the main park highway, 1 mile north of the Grant Village Ranger Station.  Ryan could not detect any lightning struck tree and determined that the cause resulted from a tossed cigarette.  The fire was called controlled and out at 1630.  Final size was 0.1 of an acre.

The Pumice Fire was discovered by the Mt. Sheridan lookout at 1310 on 8/21/06.  Three helitack were dispatched to meet the helicopter but due to no landing spot, they hiked into the fire.  Ryan Tripp served as ICT4 along with Phil Hayes and Vince Nagashima.  The fire was approximantely 1/2 acre in size and they received some bucket drops from OUS.  Five smokejumpers jumped the Dryad Fire to the north of the Pumice and 3 of them hiked in at 1630 and 2 more jumpers hiked in at 1700 after suppressing the Dryad Fire.  A fireline around the fire was completed at 2330.  8/22 - a spot fire was discovered at 0700 and lined and mopped up.  The main fire was contained at 0900.  Mopup continued the rest of the shift.  Four additional Yellowstone firefighters hiked into the fire to assist mopup efforts.  OUS flew blivets into to assist.  8/23 - Mopup all day with blivet support.  Fire suppression continued on 8/24, with the fire declared controlled at 1600 on 8/24.  All hose and blivets were pulled and all gear slung out.  All firefighters hiked out to the Park highway.  The fire was flown on 8/31/06 and the PALM IR camera did not detect any heat on the entire fire.  The fire was declared out on 8/31/06 at 1700.

The Dryad Fire was discovered by Wendy Hafer in helicopter OUS while enroute to the Pumice Fire.  The fire was discovered at 1357 on 8/21/06 at 0.1 of an acre.  The helicopter landed and the bucket was hooked up and bucket drops were made on the fire.    Smokejupers were ordered for the Pumice Fire but could not jump it, so 5 jumped into the Dryad Fire.  2 jumpers mopped up and suppressed the Dryad Fire with bucket support while 3 jumpers were flown near the Pumice Fire and walked into that fire.  When the 2 jumpers controlled the Dryad Fire, they were flown near the Pumice Fire and also hiked into that fire.  The Fire was controlled at 1600.  The Drayd Fire was flown on 8/31/06 with the PALM IR camera.  The flight did not detect any heat and the fire was declared out on 8/31/06 at 1630 at 0.1 of an acre.

The Sefton Fire was caused by Xanterra workers putting hot ashes from campfires on a pile of scrap wood in the Lake Transfer station yard, approximately 400 yeards behind the Bridge Bay campground, D-Loop.  The Lake Rangers were notified and dispatched the Lake Fire Department to the scene.  The Lake Fire Engine knocked the fire down on the initinal response.  A small sprinkler system was set up over the debris pile for 3 days.  This effort was successful and the fire was declared out on 8/28/06.

The Falling Fire was caused by one of the fire cache fire effects employees dropping a tree on the powerline near the Norris Junction.  The trees were being cleared in preparation for the planned Norris Prescribed Burn.  Employee Chris Roy was felling trees and dropped a tree on the powerline, causing a small fire.  NW Energy was notified and de-energized the powerline so Chris and Phil Hayes could suppress the small fire.  The fire was controlled at 1800 on 8/24/06.  The fire was mopped up and checked daily until it was declared out on 8/28/06.

The YPSS wrecker was towing a visitor's vehicle when the transmission fell out of the vehicle and sparked on the pavement, causing a small grash/brush fire.  The fire was started about 1/2 way between the Tower Ranger Station and the turn into the Petrified Tree exhibit along the park highway from Tower to Mammoth.  Ranger Jeffrey Davis discovered the fire and used a fire extinguisher in the initial attack of this fire.  The Tower Fire Engine was dispatched to the scene and controlled the fire using water from the engine and handtools.  Fire Cache firefighters Ryan Tripp (Engine Foreman) and Case Martin checked the fire on 9/1/06 and declared the fire out.

Yellowstone Np Dispatch was advised of fire by 5H19 - Park Ranger Joe Bueter at 1724 on 4/18/2007.  Fire was initially reported to 5H19 by park visitor.   Dispatch advised Acting FMO Andy Mitchell.  Was advised by Andy that we would deal with situation on 4/19.  On 4/19/2007, Fire Use Module personnel, Phil Hayes and Jessica Page hiked into reported fire area at 0925a.  Hayes reported at 1025a the nothing was seen and given Joe Bueters phn no. Upon contact w/ Bueter, Hayes came upom a 25'(single snag) juniper tree burning at the base - 4'x6', smouldering in duff, with little smoke.  Recommended Fire Use.  On 4/20/2007, Hayes and Page monitored fire at 1353p and reported two tiny smokes, no flame, no growth.  Area was warmer and dryer than yesterday.  Mitchell and Helitack Foreman Wendy Hafer monitored the fire on 4/24 and found it to be cold.  No further activity was noted.  The fire was declared out on May 5th.  This fire was used as an ITC 5 training assignment for Fire Use Module memebers Phil Hayes and Jessica Page.

OVERHEARD CONVERSATION OVER RADIO BETWEEN COMM. CENTER AND 6W17 - PARK RANGERr TOM SCHWARTZ IN REGARDS TO SINGLE LOG BURNING ON BARNES HOLE RD. 50 YARDS FROM MAIN ROAD.  DISPATCH ASKED 6W17 TO CTC 700FOX. 6W17 CALLED AT THE SCENE AT 1456 ON 5/19/2007, STATED A SINGLE LOG WAS BURNING AT WHAT LOOKED TO BE AT A CAMPING SITE.  MONEY WAS FOUND NEAR SITE ALONG W/ BURNT PLASTIC BOTTLE AND GRASS AREA HAD BEEN MATTED DOWN AS IF SOMEONE HAD SLEPT ON GROUND W/ SLEEPING BAG.  DETERMINED THAT IT WAS HUMAN CAUSED AND PUT OUT SMOLDERING LOG.  6W17 CONTACTED BACK AT 1645 W/ LAT/LONG. AND DECLARED FIRE OUT.

Patrolman 6030 arrived on scene and surveyed the fire.  Engine 5 was called out. E-4 was on standby.  Case numbe assigned was 07-1390. Persons had been in the area recreating, playing frisbee.  The fire was later renamed Frisbee Golf on the ranger case incident report, but remains Columbine in WFMIS.  The report came in 1700 and the patrolperson was on scene,6030.  Smoldering log and small spot on the ground found smoldering.  Rangers called fire duty officer.  No lightning was found in the area for the last three days, so it was likely a human caused fire.  The scene was inspected, but no incendiary device was found.  Persons were reported in the start area. FMO Mitchell noted fire was in a suppression zone and likely human caused, so it was put out.  Suppression to mop up lasted til around 2100.  Engine 4 was on standby and released 1750.  E-5 and crew remained on scene til control time. Mark Hnat and Eric Amundson worked on the fire til it was cold to the touch in pm hrs..  The following day, E-1570 with  Blake Chartier, Devin Jones, and Bodie Tobin, returned to the scene, verified location, and hand checked the fire.  It was declared out approximately 1200 hrs. with no follow up or rehab needs.

The fire was reported by a former NPS employee who observed a lightning strike and the resulting smoke.  A squad of 5 hiked in early the next morning, 8.5 miles each way and found the 0.1 acre fire consisting of a single tree and some smouldering duff.  Rain was occurring when the fire was reported, snow was predicted that night.  It rained hard from about noon until dark on June 6 while suppression was taking place.  The IC was Blake Chartier.

The fire was reported by a passerby.  The location was Boundry Street in West Yellowstone.   The fire burned 40 yards into the park.  A passerby attempted to suppress the fire with a shovel, and later a West Yellowstone PD officer attempted to suppress it with a fire extinguisher.  Both attempts were unsuccessful.   West Yellowstone FD responded and suppressed it.
The cause and origin of the fire was investigated.  The cause was determined to be a possible cigarette left lit.

1502:  Washburn Lookout reported smoke past Pelican Cone.  Jumpers were requested-7 enroute from West Yellowstone as well as the NPS helicopter and helicopter HQK from the Gallatin NF. 1633:  Decision made to suppress fire.   1805:  9 firefighters on the ground, NPS I.C. (Wagner) 07/09:  ICT4- Tripp, identified problem areas, etc.  Continued to mop up for the next 3 weeks.  The fire would lie down for a few days then show some heat and we would send firefighters in to mop up.  Fire area received from .5 to a little over 1.0" of precip. during the time from initial attack to date the fire was called out.

The fire was reported by Mt. Sheridan lookout.  Two smokejumpers arrived at the fire at 1010 the next morning.  It was 0.1 acre, a single tree.  No other resources were needed.  The jumpers were flown out by helicopter on 7/8 at 1130.
The fire was reported by the Mt. Sheridan lookout.  Four smokejumpers arrived at the scene at 0917 the next morning.
The fire was reported by "6016".  It was confined to a snag.  Near old freight rd., 50 yards from firehole river.  Engine #5 from Old Faithful responded and suppressed it.

The Owl fire was reported by a USFS smoke jumper who was traveling on Hwy. 191.  It started just south of the WY/MT border, and quickly burned north into MT.  After the fire burned across the East Fork of Specimen Creek, it moved into much more rugged and steeper terrain.    A Type 2 Incident Management Team was ordered.  Tony Wilder's IMTeam (from the Southeast) assumed command of the fire at 0800 on July 25.  Heavy rains on or about the 27th and 28th greatly reduced fire behavior to the point of hiding most remaining heat.  Some mop-up and line construction activities proceed to contain previously active areas     Portions of the fire burned in areas previously burned in 1988.  On August 6th fire management transitioned to a Type 3 organization led by YNP AFMO, Andy Mitchell.  The fire did not exhibit further growth, however drying conditions prevailed.  smokejumpers were called in later that week to control a 2 acre flare up near the control line that threatened to spot into the green.  They were subsequently relieved on the 17th of August by a BLM T2 handcrew and Yellowstone militia to complete mop-up.  The BLM creww spiked in the area for 2 nights leaving the 19th.    Yellowstone helitack joined Yellowstone trails staff that same day to patrol and intiate fire rehab activities.  This effort continued until August 28th when the fire was put into aerial patrol status.  No new smokes had been found by either field firefighters or hand held infra-red for several days.

The fire was primarily monitored by air, with the exception of early monitoring at the Cabin Creek Patrol Cabin.  Monitors on the ground were from YNP helitack, monitors, and fire use module members.  The fire had a stage III document prepared and reviewed by the Shoshone N.F..  A RAWS station was installed near this fire due to service relocation needs and not because of the fire, Cabin Creek RAWS formerly Thorofare RAWS.  The fuels at the cabin were bucked up for pile burning and fire wood.  Crews were not able to burn the piles and that fuel treatment will require completion at a later date and an edit to this report.  Significance of this fire? The fire was allowed to burn where fires were previously put out due to alleged concerns about conducting WFU fires with the Shoshone NF, example Tyson Fire 2003 in the same drainage. Fire opened up more WFU possibilities with the SNF on the eastern boundary.  Ecological process was unhindered.  Fire was south of the Columbine Fire and burned with less intensity in the same time period.  Fuel models and precip timing accounted for less intensity on the Beaverdam Fire.  The Beaverdam Fire stayed within the Park as predicted by fire analysts, Doug Stephens, Pat Stephens, Roy Renkin, Tim Klukas, and Rick O'Connell, SNF.  The Fire was a long duration event for which no near misses, injuries or accidents occured.  The Mt. Sheridan Lookout was the primary source of daily validation for this fire meeting WFIP objectives.  Aviation was minimal and about twice weekly rotary or fixed wing, tapering to once a week for mapping updates.  Trainees John Morlock and Jeff Hickerson were supervised by FUMA Tim Klukas. Support provided by Plans Chief, Gabbert.  Fuels work provided by Mitchell.  In general, daily correspondence occured with the N. Zone FMO, Clint Dawson.  The Fire only briefly crossed the North side of Beaverdam Creek and a shower put that spot fire out. A unpredicted northwesterly flow kept the fire confined on the south side of Beaverdam Creek. This area has a bit of a micro climate and an unexpected wind flow wrapping around the Promontory. Fire was a successful WFU.

The fire was started by the wind blowing a tree into a power line.  The fire was confined to the immediate area.  An engine from Old Faithful responded and stood by until the power company responded and removed the tree from the power line.

This fire, originally known as the Promontory S. fire, started at about the same time as the Promontory NW and the Promontory NE fires.  All were on "The Promontory" in the south end of Yellowstone Lake and were started by lightning.  The three fires burned together on (08-16-2007) and were then known as the Promontory Complex.  A Stage 1 and 2 Wildland Fire Implementation Plan was completed and the decision was made to manage the merged fire as a fire use fire.  The fire only burned about 4% of the total complex acreage, most of it occurring on 8/16 and 8/17/07.  Significance of the Fire? Until 2004, the Park had been putting fires out on the Promontory.  In 2004, a moderate intensity WFU was allowed to burn.  The complex received no resistance to allow this fire to burn from area Ranger Michael Keator, or other supervisory divisions. The fire closed down several campsites for extended time periods.  The unburned control plot installed in 2004 was completely burned over in 2007. The fire was primarily managed by trainees, John Morlock and later Jeff Hickerson.  The duty officer at the MWRO was J. Duhnkrack supporting the planning level 5 approval.  Fuels work at Trail Creek was completed by Ryder and Kortge and supervised by Mitchell. Follow up work remains to be completed at Trail Creek for pile burning.  The fire report will need to be updated to reflect the costs of finishing the fuels treatment.  Monitoring work was completed by Scott Weyenberg, Becky Smith, Carla Minneti, Phil Graeve, and Devin Jones.  A new plot was put in place south of the main burn.  The old plot was read.  The monitors used the Trail Creek Cabin and canoes.  A seismic station was burned up.  The Yellowstone Volcanic Observatory equipment was known to be in the field due to the previous Promontory Fire,2004'.  Firefighters ran out of time to protect the equipment and the intense torching melted the solar panels and a power inverter.  A GPS unit, and underground seismic unit was saved with shelter wrap.  Food poles on other campsites were burned up.  A plastic toilet was saved along with a wooden toilet.  NO campsites were snagged for rehab. This will be evaluated following the winter of 2007/2008 by the area ranger. The fire growth on the Promontory was occuring on the same days the big Columbine Fire got up and running.  The column from the Promontory shaded and slowed fire growth on the Columbine Fire during a big burning period and kept the Columbine Fire from significantly trespassing into Canfield Creek.  Hobos were put out to monitor weather data.  The Cabin Creek RAWS represented conditions well.  The lookout on Mt. Sheridan provided daily updates on this fire to the FUMA, W. Neumeister.  Monitoring was by boat and air. Mapping flights were infrequent. There were no helicopter landings for this fire.  Lake Maintenance provided a lot of boat support and the fuels program packed horses in as well to reduce noise/flights.  This narrative is applicable to the other Promontory events of 2007.  This was a successful Complex of WFU fires.  Total Complex of Fires was 1638 acres.  See Other Promontory 2007 fire reports.

From 8-9 to 8-17, two of the three Promontory fires were quite active. The 200 acre figure is an approximate guess of its acreage before merging with the Promontory NW Fire on August 11.  The fire report in 2007 for the Promontory Complex details the personnel primarily involved in the incident and highlights.  200 acres burned on Promontory NE before merging.  Promontory NW burned approximately 590 acres final, but when these fire merged it was for around 450 acres and kept growing.  The Promontory S. only grew around 60 acres. The remaining +1300 acres grew on the perimeters of Promontory NE and Promontory NW.  The acreage estimate for growth on each fire was not very accurate due to a lack of aerial resources to map the fires.  Promontory S was a slow expanding fire that finally spread after August 15 and then lost momemtum.  Seasonal rains moved in on the fires, Aug. 17, but smokes were still seen in late September before the lookout (W. Neumeister) came down in early October.   Fuel Model G burned later as the fire moved down the lakeshore.  On Aug 9, Fuel model G BI was 43 at Cabin Creek RAWS.

The Huckleberry fire was reported on 8/11/2007 at 1150 hours by the Mount Sheridan fire lookout.  Air Attack 45Y from the Columbine 1 fire was dispatched to the Huckleberry fire for a better fire size up.  Upon arrival 45Y reported the fire to be 1/4 acre, smoldering and begining to torch.  Duty officer Mitchell was advised of location, size and fire behavior.  Air Attack 45Y was released to the Columbine Fire at this time.  At 1347 Mitchell advised dispatch of the decision to suppress the Huckleberry Fire.  A load of smokejumpers was ordered at 1347.  At that time, a loaded Tanker 43 was enroute back to WYS airport after weather prevented a drop on the Shoshone National Forest.  Tanker 43 was then diverted to drop on the Huckleberry by Air Attack B56, which was back in the air and over the Huckleberry at that time.  At 1425 the fire was reported to be 2-3 acres with most of the activity on the N/NE flank.  Tanker 43 was ordered to load and return, and Tanker 22 was ordered to load and return to the Huckleberry after dropping on the Columbine 1.    At 1504 Jumper 13 arrived on scene with 8 jumpers on board.  All jumpers and cargo were dropped and communication with the ICT4(T)(Stanzack with ICT3 Lannan) was established at 1603.  Retardent drops continued and a helicopter and pump equipment were ordered by the IC at 1604.  Due to unavailability of helicopters, a jumper paracargo mission out of West Yellowstone was put into motion.  At 1655 additional supplies for pump operations were ordered and passed onto the jump base.  At 1732, the IC ordered another load of jumpers or a 20 person crew, neither of which were available at that time.  The Park helicopter 0US was made available to assist with some bucket work and the jump plane completed the paracargo resource order and all aircraft were clear of the fire at 1905.  Jumpers worked the fire until 2400 and put in a resource order to double the original order.  At 0800 on 8/12/07, a load of smokejumpers was ordered by dispatch, Jumper 12 arrived on scene and had 8 additional jumpers on the ground by 0939.  Jumper 13 completed the second paracargo mission at 1020.  Helicopter 0US provided an additional resource delivery and some bucket work.  Columbine Air Attack checked the fire during shift changes and the jumpers worked the fire through the day and were off at 2200.    On 8/13/2007 the jumpers worked interior smokes and planned a demob of 8 jumpers for the next morning, the fire was estimated to be 23 acres.  On 8/14/2007, 8 jumpers were demobed mid day after completing a grid of the fire.  Their gear was slung to the South Entrance by Helicopter 0US while the jumpers hiked out.  The fire was called contained at 2000 hours that night.  Eight jumpers remained on the fire through the night.  They gridded the fire again on the 15th, then finished preparing the backhaul.  Helo 0US hauled the gear to the South Entrance as the jumpers hiked out, and the fire was put into patrol status.  The fire was monitored by the Sheridan Lookout and by Columbine Air Attack, and no smokes were observed.  It was called out on 10/05/2007, after significant precipitation on 10/04/2007.

The Thistle fire was reported by a passerby.  The decision was made to suppress the fire.  Four smokejumpers were assigned and successfully supressed the fire.  they hiked out to LeHardy rapids and were demobed to West Yellowstone Interagency Fire Center.

The Grouse fire was reported by Bill Neumeister, Mt. Sheridan lookout at 0500.  Jumpers were dispatched, but were unable to jump due to poor visibility and rain.    Checks the following day found no sign of any active fire.

The probable cause of the Lookout fire was lightning which occurred on August 19.  The fire was reported by Sheridan lookout at 1745 on August 26.  The fire was approximately 1.53 miles south of the lookout.  Due to very strong winds, it was not feasible to assess the fire on the evening of August 26.  The following morning Blake Chartier sized it up and reported it to be 0.5 acre.  The fire was monitored by Mt. Sheridan lookout, and occasionally by helicopter and firefighters who walked in from the highway.  On Sept. 1 Chartier landed nearby and walked in to the fire.  He found the lightning-struck tree.  The lat/long of the tree was entered as the location of the fire in this report:  44  14.666', 110  31.526'.   Chartier said the fire had grown very little on that date.  Renkin Flew the fire on 9/18 to declare it out.  The fire was monitored once on the ground and later flown over a couple of times.  Mt. Sheridan and the Cabin Creek RAWS were utilized for weather monitoring.

Fire was determined to be caused from lightning in the Union Falls area from BLM lightning map.  Fire had smoldered for a few days.  Aircraft spotted the fire on 9-09, commercial air.  Later on 9-10, Park bird flight survey personnel spotted the fire and called it in around 3 acres.  Midday, FUMA and HEMG flew in Park helicopter to scene.  On the ground assessment showed no litter, debris, campfire or suspect cause.  Evidence indicated the fire had crept around for 3 burn periods before on the ground monitors arrived.  Recent rains at Bechler (RAWS) indicated around 1 inch had fallen.  This constrained fire behavior.  Fire was allowed to burn due to on the ground burning characteristics.  Torching was minimal.  This was a classic pine understory burn that steadily progressed to +200 acres.  Winds and red flag days helped move the fire, however, the fire never made canopy runs or had long range spotting.  The area had old fir stands with a lodgepole stand spread evenly apart.  Perhaps earlier fires or anthropogenic burning had the stand in this conditions.  West Yell. Smoke Jumpers staffed the fire for a few days as monitors and then overlapped with Yellowstone Fire use module.  Module was pulled out on the 15th to assist with the Norris burn.  It became apparent the fire was likely to stay on the ground, so trail closure needs or the need to monitor Union Falls parking area was not needed.  Heavy bear sign indicated it was not wise to continue staffing the fire.  Fire went out naturally following November and October precip events.  Bechler RAWS was the representative station. Fuel classification could be c1p2, however the H1P3 BI was listed. Smoke jumpers installed a hobo weather monitor that was later retrieved.  On 9/26/07 activity was minimal.

The Speciman fire was reported on 9/14/07 at 1912 by a Park Ranger.  No action was taken that night.    On 9/15/07, Park contract helicopter 0US responded to the fire report but nothing was found at 0900.  At 1136, two WYS smokejumpers, Cindy Champion and Hans Oaks hiked into the fire location and were able to find it.  The jumpers worked the fire and were able to contain it at 1500.  The jumpers hiked out for the evening, leaving the fire at 1838.  On 9/16/07, Champion and one additional jumper hiked into the fire.  They finished mop-up operations and called the fire controlled at 0900.  The fire was declared out on 10/05/07 after season ending precipitation was received in the fire location.

The fire was ignited by a lightning strike. Following high winds on the 15th and 16th the fire went from 1/2 acre to thirteen acres.  Rain the week of the 17th kept the fire from growing anymore.  Monitors took fues samples and mapped the fire, GPSed ignition point,on the 17th of Sep..  On the 26th of September, observer R. Renkin flew over the fire and noted no active smokes. Following precip in early October the fire was declared out.  This was one of the later lightning caused wfu fires, along with, the Cave WFU, the Stonetop WFU, and Specimen Fire.

On 9/21, Klukas and  Canyon Supvy.Ranger Al Miller flew out to take aerial photos of the Norris Prescribed Burn completed 9/16/2007.  Miller wanted to take a look at the Fern Lake Patrol Cabin.  While flying in that direction, a slight smoke was seen by Klukas.  Pilot flew on to scene and persons observed a 1/2 dead spruce tree was hit by lightning. A punky log was burning at the base of the tree.  On sunday or Monday lightning went through the area.  A WFIP was submitted.  Some concerns were voiced about the seismic equipment due east of the fire at White Lake.  Due to the late season, it was determined the YVO equipment was not threatened.  The fire was not seen smoking later by the Washburn lookout. It likely wento out on its own that week. The Park's contract ship provided the flight.

The Cone fire was reported by a Park visitor on 9/22/2007 at 1450 hours.  The Old Faithful Structural Fire Engine #5 responded with 3 firefighters.  The fire was contained to a stump and was smoldering with flames less than 6 inches.  Upon investigation, it was determined that someone had used the stump as an ash tray, igniting the stump.  The fire was extinguished, the stump was sawed off, broken up and doused with water.  The fire was declared controlled in 5 minutes and called out after 20 minutes at 1520.  The fire was located in a lodgepole pine stand between Old Faithful Geyser and the Warming Hut.

This was one of the Promontory Complex WFU fires.  The Promontory NE and Promontory South were the other fires.  The NW and NE fires merged to make up around 450 acres at one point. The Promontory S fire grew very little, +60 acres.  These two active fires burned +1300 acres. The Promontory NE fire claimed the most acres due to some local winds pushing that fire down the east shore of the Promontory.   The fire was monitored on the ground, by boat and air.   This was a fire use fire managed by more than one FUMA.  FUMAS were Klukas, Morlock, Hickerson. Fuels treatment was initiated at Trail Creek.  No helicopter landings occured in the field.  Fire was the likely culprit of the Seismic stations burnover and damage. This fire did damage some seismic equipment that was part of the Yellowstone Volcanic Observatory network.  Fuel Model G BI was 38 at time of ignition. August 12-16 were the most active fire days on the Complex.

Lake fire units responded to a small brush fire behind Goldeneye Dorm.  Fire was reported by Lake security patrol via 9-1-1.  Structural engines responded and extinguished the fire.  Appears to be person caused - caused coule not determine source nor exact location.  Duty officer took no action.

The Aster fire was detected by fixed-wing 73B while conducting wildlife telemetry on June 26th at 0829.  Helicopter OUS was dispatched with firefighters Mike Wagner and Doung Kraus.  Firefighter Brian Nickolay and fire monitor matt Heinz flew in on the second flight to assist.  The team determined that the fire was lightning caused.  The fire was located in 1988 burn with snow and wetlands in adjacent areas.  The fire was immediately put into Fire Use status by the AMR group with the concurrence of Asst Supterintendent Colin Campbell.  A stage I WFIP completed by FUM Tim KLukas.  Since that date the fire has been monitored by the Mt. Washburn lookout, revealing very little fire activity.  On July 17, AFMO Andy Mitchell requested that firefighters Bodie Tobin and Eric Bickley hike to the fire to cold trail the burn area.  The firefighters did so finding no heat.  Mitchell declared the fire out at 1430 that day.

The fire was ignited by downed powerline from very high winds.  Local fire departments from Canyon, Lake and Grant developed areas responded.  The fire started in the powerline corridor, adjacent to the Grand Loop road.  Vehicle traffic was an issue.  The fire spotted across the Yellowstone River within 1 hour of initial report of the fire.  Aggressive suppression action was taken on the east side of the river and due to few values at risk and firefighter safety a less aggressive response was taken on the east side.
This fire was the result of an RC that overheated and caught fire.  The RV was completely destroyed, the road was damaged from the heat and only a few square feet of vegetation caught fire.

Received a call from Communications Center.  Report of a fire 5 miles N of West Thumb.  Grant and Lake engines enroute.  Initially dispatched H-0US and Engine 1570, but cancelled the helicopter. E-1570 arrived and was briefed by the IC.  Fire was under control, but still needed mop-up.  Engine departed fire at 1353.
The fire was determined to be a human caused fire due to lack of lightning data proximate to the site. Snowfall beginning 10/9 and lasting through 10/11 was the season ending event.
Fire was started by an illegal and unattended campfire.  It was reported by the visitor who abandoned the fire.

The fire was determined to be human caused by fire staff personnel Krish and Klukas who hiked to investigate and control the fire after receiving fire report on 12/1/2008 from NPS employee, Mary Wilson.  On scene it appeared that a person tore into a rotten log to acess dry tinder.  The ignitor mopped up part of the fire perimeter some broken off sticks.  It appears the person started the fire out of sight of the main trail, near a large rock that provided some wind and rain shelter. No tracks, toilet paper, or incindiary devices were found.  Broken limbs, and a few larger sticks were transported by the ignitor and left by the fire perimeter. Estimated burn time would be two days by the rate of spread in the duff.  The fire may have been started late Saturday, Nov 29 or later.  Krish and Klukas noted the fuels in the area were very damp from earlier precip and proceeded to control the fire.  The perimeter was controlled and the fire was stirred.  Upon leaving the scene, rain and sleet was falling on the fire.  NO smokes remained.

On 5/30/09, I (Douglas Kraus), was called by 700FOX and asked if I was available to check on a reported smoke between Trout Lake and Peblle Creek Campground.  I redevoused at the cache with Tim Klukas, whom would act as the IC for the operational period.  Kraus and Klukas drove from Mammoth to the Round Prairie area and met with Brian Chan, District Ranger for Lamar and befan to gather intelligence from Chan and civilians who had seen smoke and had spotting scopes on the area the smoke had last been seen.  No smoke was visible but from witness descriptions we narrowed the possivle fire area down to an area on the map south of Round Prairie across the Soda Butte creek.  Kraus and Klukas then discussed access and saf3ety issues associated with the various options.  The only bridge access was at Lamar TH which would include an approx 5 mile hike to the fire area.  Due to the distance, time of day, and an area known as grizzly bear habitat, it was deemed to be not feasible for that day but left open as an option for the following day.  The Chief Ranger stated that rafts of other watercraft would not be used to cross Soda Butte creek, so our other option would be to ford Soda Butte creek above the confluence with Pebble Creek where the creek was wider and thus possibly safer.  Kraus and Klukas then hiked to the river to inspect ir for possible spots to ford.  Chan provided PFD's and was set up donwriver with a throw line for safety.  Upon further inspection and non-emergent response to the fire Karus and Klukas concluded that the ford was not the safest option and abandoned that plan before attempting to cross the snowmelt swollen creek.  On 5/31 Kraus and Page hiked from Lamar TH to further search for reported smoke.  Upon arriving at the predetermined area based on witness accounts from the previous day, both Kraus and Page could smell the faintest odor of smoke in the air.  The winds were not srong b ut erratic and pinpointing the source was proving difficult.  It then began to rain.  After approx 45 minutes fo rain the smell of smoke was no longer detected.  The weather continued to deteriorate and storm cells began to develop in the area.  As the winde picked up in intesity and speed it was deemed no longer safe to be in the forest and the search was abandoned.

July 4, Engine 1570 w/ three f.f. enroute to fire at approx. 1620.  Fire near the YCC camp, probable lightning caused.  Crew hiked in to the fire, arrived on scene at 1640. Single snag on sloping meadow.  The surrounding grass and shrubs and soil were very wet from recent rain.  Snag was felled, bucked and mopped up, scratch line constructed.  The line was completed by 1841.  Still some hotspots, will need to return tomorrow to check. July 5.  Cold trailed fire and found no hotspots.  Dumped one bladder bag of water on fire and rehabed the line.   B. Chartier- I.C.  FMO remarks.  This fire was within the developed area near the YCC dorms.  The decision to extinguish was made by the duty officer, A. Mitchell.

Northshore Fire July 13, 2009 J. Page ICT5 N 44� 33.287  W 110� 19.520 NAD 83 Page and Nelson were dispatched from the Norris Rx unit to a reported smoke between Indian Pond and Lake Yellowstone at approximately 1500 on Monday July 13.  Engine 1570 with three (Kraus, Tobin, Jones) was also dispatched from Mammoth. After arriving at the parking area for the Indian Pond trail and not observing any smoke Nelson and Page discussed LCES and started hiking toward Lake Yellowstone on the Indian Pond trail. Once we arrived at the lake shore the smoldering tree was spotted. It was a lightning struck ~28� Doug fir with the top broken off standing 10 feet off the edge of the Lake. The surrounding fuels were very green grass in the immediate vicinity and a stringer of timber 75 yards away. The duff and litter in the timber was very damp and Indian Pond was adjacent on the opposite side. Spread potential was observed to be very low. No flames were observed at the time but volunteers said that they had seen flames earlier in the day. Winds at the time were ~20mph out of the SSW, temp was 69, and RH was 22. 	It was determined that this would be a suppression fire so it was requested that E-1570 bring a saw and pump with them when they hiked in. Once E-1570 was on scene they received a briefing, LCES was discussed and they went to work. The tree was felled and a pump was set up to mop up the smoldering rounds. The area was observed for about one half hour to determine if any smoke would pop up. No smoke showed so the crew covered the stump and cut ends of the logs with green limbs to screen them from view of visitors on the lake. All resources were released at 1800 and the fire was called contained.   FMO/Duty Officer comments:  Phone calls were made to the Chief Ranger after the initial report came in.  Information regarding location, weather, proximity to road and the lake were discussed.  We decided to wait until resources were on scene before making a decision regarding extinguish or monitor.  After size-up information was passed along to dispatch, the decision to extinguish this fire was made by the duty officer and chief ranger.  Reasons given to extinguish this fire were:  1) the fire was pretty close to a road and even though it could not be seen on that day due to high winds keeping the smoke down, this would have been a nuisance fire in terms of impacts to local ranger operations. 2) the fire was surrounded on three sides by Yellowstone Lake, a very wet bog and the road.  3) the proximity to the lake provided unlimited water and minimal exposure to risk from a firefighter safety perspective.

This fire was reported at 1541hrs on Monday, July 20, 2009 by a park visitor.  FMO Krish responded by GOV to the area, and had Nelson and Heinz, as well as E1570 with Oyler and Feathers respond to the area.  At 1837hrs, Krish reported the initial size-up.  At 1930 hrs, Krish as IC, sent in Nelson +3 for a detailed size-up.    On July 21, 2009, after a WFDSS review, it was determined that this fire would be managed for resource benefit, and an RL-1 was completed.  An RL-2 was completed and signed by Chief Ranger T. Reid on July 30.  The periodic assessment was set for twice a week.    Throughout the next four weeks the fire and surrounding area was hit by several thunderstorms that brought precipitation and cooler temps.  The last reported smoke was seen on this fire on July 27.

On 07/25/2009 at 2000hrs, the Washburn Fire Lookout reported the Moss Fire.  On 07/26/2009, a recon and size-up was undertaken by helicopter and then on foot.  Investigation found a lightning tree.  The fire was creeping through whortleberry with occasional torching and spot fires.  Ground fuels were crunchy.  The fire was managed for multiple benefits, including resource use and firefighter safety.  Fire was assessed twice a week.  On 09/10/2009 the fire was declared out after no activity was observed by Fire Lookout or by multiple helicopter recons for several weeks.

Received viable report from visitor of single tree on fire after a lightning strike.  Investigation by law enforcment patrol 12 minutes later, and Engine crew 1 hour later, found nothing.  Area monitored for sevceral days, no additional findings.

Fire dispatch received a report of a tree on fire, south of Canyon Corrals.  Engine 1570 dispatched to scene.  Single tree surrounded by very wet grass.  The decision to suppress was made due to the location to values at risk, (corrals, road, canyon district)and the low risk to firefighter safety, (open field with very wet grass).  Also, there were reports of other fires that could be seen in the area and this was one that was easily suppressed.

NPS ranger C. Urwiller was leading a hike on the Lake Overlook trail and saw a lightning strike in the Big Thumb Creek drainage.  He saw the tree flare up then led his group to shelter, south of the overlook.  Ranger Urwiller then returned to the visitor station where he passed on the info. to the supervisory interp. ranger who contacted fire dispatch. The duty officer (Krish) was notified and requested the helicopter be launched from Mammoth along with the engine. The helicopter was unable to locate any fire nor any sign of recently burned trees/ground.  The area did receive precip. shortly after the report of the fire.

August 4, 2009.  At 1555, NPS employee 6031 reports a fire on the Fern Cascade trail behind Old Faithful housing area.  At 1558 6031 reports the fire on the trail is out and will investigate further.  A very small scorched log was on fire.  The log was about 50 feet up the trail from the housing area.  A cigarette butt was found nearby.  The fire was extinguished.

Pocket Fire Narrative  On August 12, 2009 Yellowstone Helitack, Kraus and Kreutzer, responded to a visitor report of smoke in the Delacey Creek area approximately 10 miles east of Old Faithful.  The visitor reported seeing smoke and estimated the fire to be several acres at that time from the Shoshone Lake Overlook at approx. 1522 hrs.  Kraus (ICT4 trainee) and Kreutzer responded in the park ship (N230US) leaving the Mammoth Helibase at approx. 1600hrs after gathering helpful information from 700 Fox (Fire Dispatch).    Due to concerns with the visit of President Barack Obama in several days and the proximity of the fire to the designated Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) associated with the Presidential visit, it was decided before the firefighters left the fire cache that the fire would be a suppression fire.  This decision made for easier preplanning for the firefighters responding to the fire.  0US with Kraus and Kreutzer were in the fire area and conducting size-up at approx. 1630 hrs.    After completing a size-up and relaying that information to 700 Fox suppression action was initiated.  After finding a safe landing zone near the Delacey Creek trail, Kraus and Kreutzer attached the bucket to the helicopter and 0US began attacking the fire with buckets while the firefighters hiked into the fire.  LCES was discussed and implemented with a ranger acting as a lookout from the Shoshone Lake Overlook.  Communications with 700 Fox quickly became a challenge and it was decided the lookout would act as a relay with dispatch.  Escape routes were flagged to a meadow close to the fire which would act as a Safety Zone if needed.  An anchor point was established and a plan developed to cut saw line around the fire since it was burning predominantly in thee heavy load of dead and down while 0US continued bucket work.  This proved to be effective in gaining the upper hand on the fire.  The fire was then mapped by GPS and was .1 acre in size.  At 1645, 10 West Yellowstone Smokejumpers arrived at Delacey Creek Trailhead and all other responding resources were turned around.  Firefighters Chartier and Urrutia also responded from Grant developed area, and due to their fire experience, it was determined to use them as lookout/relay for the remaining daylight hours.  Once the jumpers arrived on scene, we regrouped and cleared the fire area so that 0US could safely finish his fuel cycle with firefighters clear of the drop zone.  0US was off scene at 1915 and the fire line was improved and mop-up initiated.  The crew continued to work on the fire until darkness began to fall on the area and it was deemed unsafe to continue mop-up.  The crew hooched up for a chilly, but relatively bug free coyote spike.  At first light, communications were again established with 700 Fox and mop-up continued with cold trailing and a thorough grid of the fire and surrounding area.  No lightning struck tree was ever found, but splinters from a tree indicating a strike were found during the grid.    The fire was contained at 0930 on August 13, 2009.  Jumpers left the fire area at 1100hours while Kraus and Kreutzer remained to search out any remaining smokes.  Two more smokes were found and dealt with and Kraus and Kreutzer left the fire for pickup at the Delacey Creek Trailhead at 1300 hours.   On August 24, 2009 Kraus and Feathers hiked back into the fire and the Pocket Fire was called out at 1600 hours.

Limited investigation.  IC ruled out lightning cause due to location, lack of definitive evidence, lack of recent lightning activity, and elevation of surrounding features.  Location of fire is easily accessible by trail, and there was evidence that someone had attempted to suppress fire initially, prior to arrival of crew.

Initial response was size-up from the ground. Washburn Fire Location:	N44� 45� 47.3    W110� 26� 57.2		Incident #:	1573-YNP-0913 Elevation:	8270 ft.					Time:	1325 Date of IA: 	09/01/2009 	On 09/01/2009 we initial attacked the Washburn Fire. We arrived at the pullout closest to the fire and assessed the best possible routes to the fires location, possible safety zones, suitable escape routes, and the need for a lookout. At 1210 Jessica Page and I started to hike to locate the Washburn Fire and Morgan Nelson stayed at the truck and served as a lookout and took weather observations. We found the fire at 1250 and initially thought that what we found was spots. We radioed dispatch to give an initial size up and to let them know of our status. After further investigation we determined that the three spots, which totaled about 1/10 of an acre, was the actual main fire and located the point of ignition. The tree that was struck by lightning was a mature spruce about 80ft tall which had torched out and caused two other trees to torch. The only active fire activity was at the bases of each of these trees and was smoldering in the litter and duff. At 1323 we radioed dispatch and reported our final size up and at 1349 headed back to the truck. We arrived safely back to our vehicle at 1429.  Prepared by: Matt Heinz

Initial response to Meridian Fire by Joe Krish and Doug Krause was for a size-up.  The fire was active on all sides in dead and down timber on the south face of Meridian Peak.  It was on a rock faced slope. Burning in a small pocket of timber surrounded by rock.  Possibility of addition ignition by rolling material.  Area received plenty of moisture. Over the next month, this fire was monitored from both the air and ground.  Even though the fire did not spread, there was considerable potential for it to spread due to the steepness of the slope and the heavy fuels at the base of the cliff face.

The initial action on this fire, was Mike Wagner in helicopter 2TC sizing up the fire.  At 0908 hrs on 09/05/2009 he reported the size-up information detailed above.  The fire was located in an isolated stand of timber with green meadown surrounding the area. Spread potential was limited.  Several flights over the fire area during the next few weeks as well as daily obs. from Mt. Washburn Lookout failed to spot any more smoke in the area.

On 09/14/2009, I (Morgan Nelson) was dispatched to the Rainbow Fire to conduct an aerial reconnaisance with helicopter N230US.  We arrived over the fire at approximately 1020 hours, and conducted the initial size-up.  I determined that the fire was burning in heavy timber, on the middle-to upper-third of the slope on a northerly aspect.  I estimated the fire size to be between 0.1 and 0.25 acres, and although no flame was visible from the air, there was a moderate amount of light grey smoke.  Winds over the fire appeared to be blowing down- and cross-slope.  I called dispatch with my size-up at 1027 and then we departed the fire location. Incident Commanders Log. Monday  9/14 	0930   Report of new start, Rainbow fire reported southwest of Gardiner 	0945   Andy Mitchell assumed command as ICT3, Andy Bundshuh as SOPL, and Tonja Opperman 	as LTAN 	1000   Fire Effects Monitors flew fire to size- up and confirm location 	1100   GIS shop engaged to produce briefing maps,  RL 1 completed  	1500   FSPro analysis being worked up LTAN Tonja Opperman. 	1530   �Natural Fire Do Not Report� signs posted at the Arch, Heritage Center, 			and milepost 2.7 on Hwy 89. 	1630   Information release on fire distributed to park staff and interagency partners notified.  Tuesday 9/15/09 830	Command of Fire turned over to ICT4 Wendy Hafer 1000	Confirmed with back country office signs for Sepulcher trail closures posted 1400	Monitored fire from Stephens Creek Road looks like it had grown to � acre on the ground no extreme fire behavior seen. 1530	Emailed Dan  Reinhart regarding resource concerns,  aware of historic bear trap in     	Stephens Creek drainage 1530 Tonja Opperman ran FSPRO runs 1630 Updated Press release put out. 1500 WFDSS document taken by Reid to Collin Campbell to be signed Thursday  9/17/09 830	Fire received some precip on 9/16 still smoking 1500	Picked up new information board built by carpenter shop for Al Nash 1501	Monitored fire from the Stephens Creek Road   has moved down slope maybe up to an acre in size. 9/18-9/26-2009 Fire continued to be monitored daily from the ground during the burn period.
