New map made up total acreage at 15 with no significant fire behavior or activity. 9/29  Monitored the fire from the air at about 1330.  Fire continues to creep and smolder on the ground with no change in acreage 9/30/09  Snow and rain on the fire today socked in by clouds.

On 09/17/2009 a park visitor hiking the Yellowstone River Trail reported a small fire at the 8M marker.  The report indicated the fire was of human origin.  Due to the status of resources in the park, smokejumpers were ordered to the fire from WYS.  On 09/18/2009 8 jumpers jumped the fire and suppressed it.  The cause turned out to be burning trash, specifically toilet paper which spread to the surrounding area.  The jumpers contained, controlled, and declared the fire out prior to leaving.

9/22/09 Engine Foreman-R. Tripp. Arrive at fire with engine 1570, Tripp, Oyler, and Feathers. Fire located from the Thunderer trailhead and mapped approximately 3 miles to the south east. Crew hiked in approximately 4 miles and 1900 vertical feet.  Fire approximately 0.5 acres in size on a steep >90% slope to the north west. Fire was burning actively in the ground fuels, large dead / down logs and jackpots. Some isolated torching but not much active fire movement on the perimeter. Fire was located near the top of the ridge and had no receptive fuel on the opposite slope. Only way for fire to progress was to have rolling debris ignite downhill and possibly make runs uphill and farther to the west. Not much potential for fire growth toward Cooke City with Cache creek drainage being fully burned out in 1988, as well as the fire having to go over Ampitheather Peak which is very sparcely vegetated. The fire was monitored for the better part of the burn period on the 22nd and when nothing had materialized by 1800 or so, the crew departed fire back to 1570 to return to Mammoth.  FMO: This fire was placed in the manage for firefighter safety and resource benefit status.  It was checked on a weekly basis during recon flights for the Butte and Meridian fires.

The initial smoke was reported via Washburn Lookout at approx. 1230.  A recon aircraft was ordered but not available until 1500.  Initial size up with the FMO and lead Fx placed the fire around 4 acres.  Very active fire but with lower R.O.S as there was very little wind.  Upon return to Mammoth the FMO and staff began work on an RL-2.  The lightning display map showed a ground strike in the exact area of the fire 10 days prior to the lookout calling this in.  Fire staff met with Supt. to discuss options and got the o.k. to manage this fire for firefighter safety and the benefit of the ecosystem.   Five to ten day weather outlook was calling for season ending event (snow or rain) by the 30th of Sept. A type 3 organization was established with FMO-Krish as I.C. and filling in key overhead positions with local GYA members.  ICP was established at the Lake District Office next to the fisheries compound.   Structural protection in the form of irrigation system with sprinklers was set up in the lake historic district. Type I, II and III helicopters were ordered and used for bucket work and recons.  Three strike teams of engines, one type I crew and misc. overhead were in place. The fire did get close to the bridge bay marina, but no structures were lost or damaged. The area received several inches of snow during several storms that passed through, although the fire did continue to smolder for quite some time.   Heavy equipment in the form of fallers/bunchers were brought in to mitigate the hazard tree situation along the road.

4/24.  Local resident called park dispatch advising of a fire at the base of Sepulcher Mtn.  Appears to be lightning caused.  Second call from a different party shortly after confirms location.  Park dispatch notifies fire dispatch who contacts FMO/duty officer.  Lots of lightning and rain in vicinity of fire.  Fire dispatch drove to a vantage point to confirm smoke and try and get a better location.  4/28.  After 3/4" of precip. on 4/27, plus snow all day on the 28th, FMO declared the fire out at 14:00

7/2: Off-duty park employee observed a power line in contact with a tree in the Lake Government Area.  The park's Communication Center was contacted and dispatched a structural engine.  Tree was initially smoking and then putting out small flames. The same power line also contacted a second tree adjacent to the first. Lake Structural Engine responded, along with Northwestern Energy, and extinguished the fire after the power line was shut down.

On 7/11/10 a smoke was reported in the Columbine drainage by a backcountry ranger from near the East shore of Yellowstone Lake.  Kraus responded in Helicopter 0US to locate and size up the fire.  Upon locating the fire it was quickly determined that the fire was within the Columbine fire that burned in 2007 and posed little threat in growing beyond the confines of the small stringer of green trees within the old fire.  No firefighters ever got on the ground due to safety concerns and minimal threat.  The fire was then placed in monitor status with periodic checks by aerial resources.

The Fire was originally reported by A-93A, a f/w doing resource flights.  FMO sent helitack to provide good size up info and check for ignition source.  Dep. Supt. and C.R and FMO met to discuss management strategy while helitack crew gathered intell.  Decision was made to suppress this fire.  Originally planned on managing with a T3 org. but logistically supporting crews that were spiked out was too much.  T2 team was ordered and in place on 8/22.  The fire was contained on 8/15/2010 at 520 acres.

Fire was discovered and called in from visitor.  E- 1570 was dispatched followed by H-2TC and other resources throughout the afternoon.  The lightning map did not display any close strikes, plus this fire is located near a campground.  It is likely human caused.  LEO's were not able to determine exact cause.  Helicopters dropped water and engine personnel began to suppress this fire.  I.C. ordered a T1 crew that had just completed briefing at Mammoth and were on their way to the Beach fire.  The crew was diverted to the Slough Ck. fire where they remained overnight to ensure the fire was extinguished.

Fire was discovered by 5D36 during patrol.  Concerns with launching helicopter to check out fire due to T-storms in the area.  Pilot and mgr. felt it was o.k. to launch.  Engine was also dispatched with crew.  FMO made decision to suppress the fire. All resources were pulled from the fire for the evening.  The fire was check for the next couple of days.

This fire was originally called the East fire, for the first two days.  Initial report came in from the east entrance gate personnel.  Supt. asked to have the name changed.  Approx. 1600 FMO ordered T1 engines from outside of the park as well as agency resources to get a good size up.  Shoshone NF engine was the first fire personnel on scene, followed by structural fire folks from Mammoth and eventually the North Zone FMO from Shoshone NF.  Fire reported to be "in a good place- should not get too active" 8/19-  Placed C. Marks (GRCA) as I.C.  Marks reconned the fire in helicopter.  The fire is 100% in the 1981 Arthur Fire.  The only fuel burning was the dead and down logs, very spotty fire.  Recommended not putting personnel on the fire due to remoteness, steepness, and snags. Ordered a "FUMT" to manage the fire and produce a long term plan.  Team arrived on 8/22 and demobbed on 8/24.  The LTIP was produced in conjunction with the LTIP from the Gunbarrel Fire on the SHF.  Structure protection was in place beginning on 8/19 until 9/9.  Fire received some snow and rain from passing storms over the past few months.  During the Antelope Fire, smoke was observed on the Arthur 2 fire and additional resources were placed back at the east entrance to keep an eye on the fire.

On 8/22/2010 an off duty Tower Ranger (Sprinkle)was hiking the the Lava Creek trail when he noticed a fire burning near campsite 1A3.  After taking initial action it was reported to 700 Fox who dispatched fire fighters.  Firefighters Kraus, Chartier, Oak, Clark, and Bush responded and hiked down from the Lava Creek trailhead near Undine Falls.  Upon arriving on scene a quick size-up revealed an area of duff under some Doug firs.  It was determined that helicopter bucked drops would be ineffective in aiding mop-up and that slinging in a pump would be slight overkill.  After chatting with Sprinkle it was determined that this was probably an unattended illegal fire.  No lightning tree was noted and the lightning maps showed no recent strikes in that area.  the fire was smoldering in duff so firefighters began to dry mop the fire with the aid of water transported in helmets from nearby Lava creek.  The fire was quickly controlled and firefighters hiked out that evening.

E-1570 dispatched to East Entrance to check on reported smoke near Sylvan Pass.  Some safety concerns with UXO in avalanche area.  Resources hiked into fire and provided on-scene size up information.  The area was too steep to keep firefighters on scene after dark.  Will place fire in monitor status and keep an eye on it via helicopter. Several rain and snow storms have passed over the area since the fire began.

Mt. Washburn called in a lightning strike during a thunderstorm on the 14th of Sept.  The lookout noticed the strike, saw the initial flare-up and subsequent smoke and then watched the storm bring rain over the fire.  After that initial discovery, no further smoke was seen.

The antelope fire was called in by Mt. Washburn L.O. during a passing thunderstorm.  That same storm ignited the Lookout fire, but could no longer be found after the rain passed through.  The decision to manage this fire for mulitple benefits was based upon lack of values at risk, favorable burn conditions (late season, low intensity) and a natural start.  Several T3 I.C.'s and associated team positions were filled and demobed as the fire became more active, then subsided.  At one point the Tower Store, and campground were potential immediate threats and the Tower/Roosevelt Developed Area also were potential threats.  Mitigation in the form of retardant, hoselays and structural engines were in place to reduce the hazard.  At the peak of the fire intensity, there were approx. 60 personnel assigned and 3 aircraft.  The fire was controlled after the second snowfall of the season.

Fire was reported at 1558 hours on June 8, 2011.  Joe Krish notified crew of fire and Doug Kraus, Kate Hall, Ryan Tripp, Todd Mott and Connor Vandersnick responded in Engine 1571 and a a second vehicle.  Crew arrived on scene at 1633 hours and it was decided by Doug Kraus that this would be a good fire for ICT5 training.  Connor Vandersnick was then appointed as ICT5 Trainee.  Crew had a briefing of operations and prepared equipment.  Fire was approximately 200 yards off road and crew hiked to fire for initial size up.  The fire was a single Douglas fir lightning strike with fire smoldering in center of tree.  Wind was less than 5 mph out of the southwest.  The tree was on the upper 1.3 of a 0-20% east aspect slope with grass and bush as adjacent fuels.  The area acquired approximately 14/" to 1" of rain in the past 24 hrs so it was decided that the spread potential was low.  Dispatch was given size up and it was decided to give the order to extinguish the fire at 1700 hrs.  Floating IC then assigned C Faller Ryan Tripp to fall the tree.  The tree was on the ground at 1720 hours.  Dirt was used to cool hot spots and the fire was contained at 1740 hours.  The Floating IC felt it was safe to leave the fire and then held and After Action Teview at 1815 hours.  In the AAR the crew decided that everything went as planned and the experienced personnel gave the ICT5 Trainee some pointers and constructive criticism.  The Floating IC then released the crew and all personnel were clear from the scene at 1820 hours. FMO comments:  The decision to extinguish this fire was made by the duty officer/fmo.  The reasons were:  too close to the road and a pullout, allowing potential visitors to stop and investigate the smoke.  This is a suppression zone in the original fire management plan.  Now was the time to put this out, rather than deal with the intensive management of what would amount to be a single burning snag.  The fire was checked again on 6/14/2011.  No heat was found and the fire was declared out.

The Mud fire was located in the middle of the 2008 LeHardy fire.  It was a lightning strike on a snag that also caught some of the jack strawed dead and down timber on fire.  This fire was suppressed due to:  1) in a burn where there will be limited resource benefit and 2) our ability to manage mulitple fires is limited, so we should choose how many and which fires we manage as long term events very carefully, i.e. it's very early in the year and this is not a good candidate. And 3) the fire was close to the road and had potential to be a public hazard.

Maintenance personnel traveling on the lake reported seeing smoke coming from the southern end of Yellowstone Lake in the middle of the 1988 burn on  7/12.  July 22, the FMO was able to request a helicopter from GRTE to pick him up at Grant helispot to try and locate the fire.  After a few minutes reconning from the helicopter the snag was located.  There was no smoke nor flame showing, only large chunks of debris.  This fire was called out by the fmo.

It is believed that this fire started on 7/12 by lightning.  It was not discovered until 7/26 by a fixed wing resources flight.  The fire was located south of Gibbon Falls, approx. 1 mile south of powerlines that run along the grand loop road.  By 1100 on 7/26, park staff agreed this would be a good candidate for the Use of Wildland Fire,(UWF).  Throughout the summer this fire was monitored from a webcam that was placed atop Mt. Holmes, about 10 miles to the NW.  The fire was situated in a lodgepole pine canopy that was initially fairly open but transitioned to a more closed canopy as the fire backed to the south.  Fire behavior was very benign considering the surrounding fuel loading with only occasional single tree torching.  This likely was due to the high fuel moisture content from the very wet winter/spring.  In addition to monitoring from the webcam, we would send monitors out to the fire approx. once a week to check rain guages, fire behavior, etc. The fire was declared out on 10/6/2011.

Devil Fire Dates: 8/6/2011 � 9/2/2011 Location: 44.45.83    110.25.62	  	The fire was initially spotted by hikers, who took pictures and reported to a canyon ranger. At 7:30 on 8/6/2011 morning briefing was held at the fire cache in mammoth and it was decided that Doug Kraus, Bodie Tobin, Connor Vandersnick and Randy Throop would hike into and assess the fire to determine the cause.  Throop being the IC trainee and Kraus being the qualified IC assigned to the fire. After observing the fire from the Mt. Washburn lookout, the four helitack hiked off trail and straight towards the fire.  At 11:55 the four arrived at the fire, LCES was put in place and the fire origin was found. The fire was creeping and smoldering with very little open flame, fire was entirely on the ground. It was quickly determined that the fire was started from an Illegal campfire and through dispatch it was decided to suppress the fire using M.I.S.T. tactics.  The fire was 1/10 acre in size burning in a lodge pole forest, primarily in the duffy soil. Line was dug around its perimeter, allowing the interior fuels to burn themselves out. Dry mopping proved very effective. Shift ended at 2200 with the fire being in contained status.	 	Morning of 8/7/2011 Throop, Kraus, Tobin and Travis Clark hiked into the fire from Inspiration Point.  The interior of the fire had a few hot spot which were cooled using a backpack pump.  No further heat or smoke was observed and the fireline was rehabbed. Shift ended at 2000 with the fire being in controlled status. 	The Devil Fire was monitored from the Mt. Washburn lookout until 9/2/2011, at which time it was declared out by IC trainee Randy Throop.

Fire was detected by Tower rangers and Mt. Washburn lookout.  Due to the condition of the fuels (wet grass) and time of day (1600), it was decided to wait until tomorrow to hike into the fire. ICT4- Chartier plus 2 f.f. hiked into fire on 8/8.  No action was taken as there was minimal smoke and fire activity.  The grasses were very green and no rates of spread were observed.  By 1300, the decision to manage this fire was made and no further action was taken. 8/9- Signs were placed along the Coyote Ck. trail to warn visitors of the fire.  Firefighters stayed in the area to educate and inform trail hikers, if needed.

The Junction fire was reported on the evening of August 7th.  Due to the hour it was decided to not take action until the morning of the 8th when three firefighters, Vandersnick, Tobin and Heinz hiked in.  Vandersnick was appointed as the ICT5 trainee and Tobin as the trainer.  The location was pinpointed on the map in conjunciton with Cataldo.  The crew arrived on scene of the fire at 1052 hours.  Then junction fire size up was reported at 1108 and was reported as follows, single tree lightning strike in a douglas fir.  The fire was smoldering with light and variable winds.  The adjacent fuels are grass, sage and sparce Douglas Fires.  The fire is a West aspect with a 5-10% grade apptroximately in the middle 1/3 of the slope.  Spread potential was decided to be low due to rainflal the night before and the condition the dajacent fuels were in.  Weather was slung every hour.  The Crew was notified at 1420 hours that the fire would be a management fire for multiple objectives and the crew monitored the fire until 1540 hours when weather moved in and forced the crew to leave the fire and return back to Mammoth.  The crew returned to Mammoth at 1730 hours.  The fire was checked again on 8/15, no heat or smoke were observed and the fire was declared out.

The Bighorn Fire was reported by Canyon district personnel the afternoon of August 20.  Canyon Structural Fire personnel responded and extinguished the fire at approx. 1300.  The helitack crew was then directed to respond by the AFMO to gather information about the fire.  The crew was enroute at 1312 hours and met D. Page (5C13) at Canyon Maintenance area and was on scene at 1414.  The fire's GPS coord. were confirmed at the elev. was 7,396.  The fire was cold trailed by the crew and the decision was made to call the fire controlled at 1441.  The crew departed the scene at 1444 and returned to Mammoth by 1533.  The Bighorn fire was called out on August 28.

On August 24 A fire was reported just outside one of the group campsites at Grant Campground.  Hafer and Vandersnick reported to scene and met with Structural Fire Chief Gray as the fire was reported to have arson like properties.  The fire was on a 20 to 40% slope near several social trails just outside the campground boundary.  The fire had been washed down by structural personel but had burned a 8�by 1� area following a decayed log up the slope.  There was no sign of heat or source of ignition.  Assumed to be man caused due to proximity of campsites and social trails.  No heat was found so Hafer and Vandersnick departed leaving Structural fire to continue their investigation.

The heart fire was discovered on 8/25 and added to the list of 6 other new starts from a passing lightning storm.  These small fires were complexed to consolidate logistical and planning efforts which is the reason no single fire report was completed.  The fires in the complex were checked via helicopter numerous times over the next month.  A recon on the 28th of August came up with no visible smoke while another recon on the 31st noted minimal fire activity.  This fire continued to be monitored from the air until declared out on 9/6.

The sour fire was included in part of a 7 fire complex that resulted from a lightning storm around 8/24.  This fire was called in the Mt. Washburn lookout as a single tree along the Wapiti Lake trail, east of Canyon Village.  Over the following week, aerail recons could not detect any visible smoke.  On 9/4 firefighters hiked into the fire and located the fire scar and declared the fire out.

The Huckleberry fire was part of a 6 fire complex resulting from storm passing through around 8/24.  The fire was located south of the Snake River and South Boundary trail, 2 miles from the s. boundary of the park.  Burning in heavy dead and down LP fuels.  Moderate to high potential for growth but due to high fuel moisture content the fire did not appear to grow any larger than one acre.  Due to terrain, fuel loading and remoteness we were not able to put anyone on this fire.  We monitored from the air and occasional hikes along the trail to the base of the mountain.

The Point Fire was the largest fire within the 2011 Heart Complex.  It was allowed to play its natural role in the ecosystem.  Most of it's acreage was achieved in one large run of about 1400 acres on 9/5/11.  The fire was naturally confined on most sides by Yellowstone Lake and the East and Grizzly Fire scars from within the past decade.  It was monitored by a combination of aerial and ground forces throughout it's life.  Additionally, structure protection measures were put in place at the Clear Creek Cabin.  The Thorofare Trail was closed from 9 Mile Trailhead to a mile south of the fire area for several weeks while it was being impacted by the fire.  No significant impacts to the East Entrance Road or Cody, WY were verified however signage and increased patrols were initiated to monitor for impacts during moderate to high fire growth days.  The hard copy fire report folder has more detailed daily accounts of actions on the Point Fire.

The prospect fire was reported on August 26 and was sized up by W. Hafer:  fire perimeter was 100% active with flame on the ground.  Winds were 0-5 and variable directions.  Fire was burning in duff, lodgepole and whortleberry.  Adjacent fuels were the same.  The fire was on the middle 1/3 of a less than 5% slope with spread potential as moderate.  On August 27, 3 f.f. arrived on the fire around 1045 via helicopter and began cutting line.  At 1050 an order for 5 backpack pumps was requested but the delivery was delayed.  At 1113 an order for bucket drops was requested.  the crew finished saw line and began bone piling and mop up.  Fire was contained at 1316 hours and the order for backpack pumps was cancelled.  At 1652 the crew was off the fire and the fire was called controlled.  The crew was picked up at 1720.

This fire was discovered from a fixed wing air attack flying in Idaho.  It was described as .1 acre and crawling around in the duff.  No flames were visible and a light smoke was described. Throughout the summer, recons were conducted via helicopter and this fire area was also visible from the remote camera placed atop Mt. Holmes.  At times the fire showed some light activity, even some single tree torching.  This fire was called out on 9/6.

Incident Commander: Connor Vandersnick (ICT5)  Summary:  The Weasel Fire was reported on the morning of August 29, 2011. Helicopter 2TC with Hafer on board took off from Mammoth to scout the fire out and size it up. Meanwhile Vandersnick, Kraus, Moore and Heinz left mammoth on the ground to the fire at 850 hours. Hafer called in size up as follows, the fire was smoldering in grass, log and duff on a south aspect slope. Adjacent fuels were were the same as fuels smoldering. Winds were 0-5 mph out of the Southeast and the spread potential was moderate to high. Hafer estimated 3-5 to control. Hafer also got exact coordinates of the fire wich was, N: 44�29.25 W: 110�26.52 and relayed them to dispatch and ground units. Hafer also spotted the route into the fire and gave ground units coordinates to a pullout. Ground units arrived at pullout at 1030 hours and were on the fire at 1000 hours. Weasel IC Trainee then ordered Heinz and Moore to cut saw line around the fire. Weasel Fire IC Trainee decided that more recourse�s were needed and ordered 2 more firefighter plus saw and backpack pump at 1135 hours. Firefighters Hollaway and Leckie arrived on the fire at 1230 hours and began mop up of the fire. Crew continued mop up until they left the fire at 1700 hours. Fire was contained at 1530 hours and controlled at 1700 hours. Crew was back at the truck at 1718 hours and was back in mammoth at 1850 hours. The Weasel Fire was declared out on September 1, 2011.

This fire was discovered by a visitor hiking along the Pitchstone Plateau Trail.  Fire was adjacent to trail.  Unable to positively identify cause.  Fire was in very patchy fuels.  It was monitored by aerial recon flights in conjunction with the Ouzel Fire located to it's west several miles.  This fire persisted for several weeks but did not spread beyond the small patch of vegetation that it was located in.  No trails were closed because of it.

IC: Bodie Tobin  This fire was about 0.6 miles down slope form the park's northern boundary with the Gallatin NF.  Smoke from this fire, if it were to be managed long-term for multiple objectives, would likely flow down into the Cinnabar Basin community.  Additionally, the majority of the final fire acreage would be on the Gallatin NF.  After consultation with Gallatin NF Fire Staff the decision was made to suppress this fire.  At the time, the nearby Bull Fire was already being managed long-term on the Gallatin NF and was having some smoke impacts on the residents of the Gardiner Basin, and Fire Staff did not want to add to that impact.  Bodie Tobin (Helitack) + 1 flew upto the fire in our contract helicopter N23OUS with a portable pump and controlled the fire in one operational period.  A nearby small  creek facilitated making quick work of this fire.

Fire was suppressed with 16 Smokejumpers from West Yellowstone Base due to likelihood of smoke from fire being impactful on Old Faithful area for multiple weeks.  Another fire burning in the park, Point Fire, had the potential to be impactful to the East Entrance road and management was reluctant to be impactful to 2 high visitor use areas simultaneously if it could be avoided.  No chemical retardents were used to control this fire due to it's location in the headwaters of the Firehole River.

An abandoned campfire at site 4R1 was reported to dispatch.  It was suppressed by to helitack crewmembers (Chartier and Clark) and was controlled at 4' by 12' in size.  They were delivered by our contract helicopter N23OUS.  The entire operation was 2 hours in length.

This fire was called in via FAA air traffic and confirmed by Mt. Washburn L.O.  At the time it was not clear if this was a new start or possibly the Trishman Fire had re-ignited.  The Duty Officer requested the assistance of the Gallatin NF. exclusive-use T2 helicopter that was sitting at the helibase used for the Boone Pk. Rx burn.  The helicopter arrived over the fire at approx. 1615 and confirmed this was a new start.  The park staff decided to suppress this fire due to the significant number of visitors known to be in the backcountry and the difficulty in locating and evacuating them.  The T2 helicopter dropped off helitack and began bucket work supporting firefighters on the ground.  There were numerous spot fires and the main fire stayed active throughout the first night.  For the next several days, bucket work and supplies were delivered to the fire and steady progress was made.  Firefighters continued to construct handline, mop up and grid for hotspots and the fire was controlled on 10/2.  All firefighters were flown out of the fire.

This fire was posted on the YNP unofficial facebook page by a resident of Bozeman.  This posted information was then passed along to the FMO who, with the Fire Ecologist skied out to the area and found the burned area.  There was very little heat left and only burned what was directly beneath the large fir canopy.  The snow line began at the edge of the canopy and stopped the fire.  There was no evidence of any recent lightning and the location was ideal for getting out of the wind/snow and was close to a ski trail.  I felt confident the cause of the fire was a person and that it was likely a warming fire.  The fire was mopped up and controlled within 45 minutes after arrival.

5H13 investigated reported smoke. Area smoking was approx 2 ft in diameter. Upon investigation the next day, FC personnel were unable to locate the exact area, but there was no smoke showing and heavy rain.

Summary of Actions:  Beaver Fire June 6 2012 1400 Fire reported 1440 Hafer (I.C.),   Koel and Wines hike to fire. Along the hike, I contact 3 parties of visitors confirming smoke and location of fire. 1557- Arrive at fire and observe 6 inch flame lengths with active burning.  A visitor has been working to suppress the fire with little success. He reports people were sitting where the fire started he heard them cough.   Call in assessment and brief 2 firefighters. Fire looks to be man caused as I could find no lightning marks in surrounding trees. Start building fireline and suppress the fire using one back pack pump that we re-filled in a nearby pond.  The spray bar on the backpack pump did not work because of weeds in water so we dumped backpack water onto fire and refilled 6 times. Complete line around fire and cold trail the interior of the fire. Final fire size is approx. 10 x 10. 1652 call fire contained. Monitor fire for heat and smoke. 1715 depart fire. 1820 back to cache.  6/6/12, Smith narrative: Fire was discovered and initial attack was performed on 6/5/12.  On 6/6/12 Smith and Koel hiked to the fire to check on it.  Smith was incident commander, while Koel was along as a hiking partner.  We left the fire cache at 0945, and arrived on scene at 1035.  Smith dug around in the fire, and cold trailed the edges but did not find any heat within or outside of the burn perimeter.  At 1055 a small film canister was found two feet away from the fire perimeter.  Smith opened it up, and found a few rolled joints and loose marijuana.  Smith called 700Fox via cell phone to determine best course of action.  Smith was told to carry film canister down to fire cache where Mammoth Patrol would pick it up later that afternoon.  We departed the fire at 1100 due to snow, wind, and lack of heat within the fire; we arrived back at the cache at 1145.  Eric Morey retrieved the film canister at 1300 that afternoon.  6/11/12 Smith narrative,  Becky Smith and Jess Page hiked in to the Beaver fire on Monday, June 11th at 1400 hours.  Upon arriving, we cold trailed the entire fire and found no heat.  After it was deemed the entire fire was cold, we pulled the fireline back into place and rehabilitated the fire area.  We were on scene for a total of one hour before hiking out.  The fire was called out at 1600 as we left the area.

Discovered and extinguished by NPS park ranger and passersby. Lat-long verified by physical description and Google Earth.  At approximately 16:15 on July 3, 2012, I arrived at the Floating Island Lake pullout and noticed a small amount of smoke rising from the grasses on the south edge of the road at the west end of the pullout.  After parking my government vehicle, I approached the site on foot and stamped out the small (3 inch high) flames I saw at the base of that clump of grass and wild rose.  The fire barely covered an area of 1 square foot.  There was a smell of sulfur when the area was inspected more closely.  A few passersby stopped and offered water bottles to help extinguish the fire.  I also poured water from my personal water bottle on the site.  A guide from Yellowstone Tourguides (Jim) drove up to the area and assisted with more water and by disturbing the earth at the scene, as well as pulling out some of the grasses to remove fuel from the area.  Bill Wengeler

Blacktail Fire Narrative 7/12/2012 - This incident was reported by recon ship 71D during a detection flight over the Park  @ 1509 hrs. on 7/12/2012 as a .25 to .5 acre fire between the Yellowstone River and Park Road, located generally North of Blacktail Drive entrance.  Incident was reported as burning on the ground in timber with isolated single-tree torching.  It was reported as having burned through light fuels and moved into the timber and heading uphill with the wind. Based on the time of year (early July), spread potential (high), proximity to USFS lands (2.5 miles), resource scarcity (PL4) and fuels conditions (Mammoth 1000�s under 5%) and after consultation with Deputy Chief Ranger Herring the decision to suppress the fire was made by 1549 hours.  8 Smokejumpers and a Type 2 Helicpoter 34CH with bucket and module (HEMG + 4) were ordered.  The air Attack platform that detected the fire was retained as well.  Upon consultation with A/A a heavy airtanker was requested and made one drop on the head of the fire.  All resources safely engaged the fire in an anchor and flank direct attack and good progress toward containment was made.  Additional helitack crewmembers associated with 34CH travelled to Gardiner to RON and await assignment on the incident. Fire size by end of shift was estimated at 15 acres via handheld GPS.  7/13/2012 � Additional 34CH helitack (8 more) were shuttled into the incident to support control operations, as well as, 2 resource advisors (READ Nedved and Graff (t)).  Fire size at 1400 hrs estimated at 28 acres via handheld GPS.  Bear boxes and misc. water handling equipment were flown into the incident.  A cache order for miscellaneous equipment was placed and is documented in the fire folder.   Public Affairs office placed information and �Do Not Report� signs in locations along the Park road from where the fire may be visible to visitors. Fire is 45% contained at end of shift.  7/14/2012 Fire is 85% contained at 1600 hrs.  Logistical support of the incident (backhaul, MRE, Cubitainers) performed today by helicopter 34CH.  IC(t) concurs that the 2 READ + 4 SAGU WFM will be adequate starting tomorrow for staffing the incident. SAGU WFM advised of this plan @ 1500. 7/15/2012 Mop-up and patrol continue.  All 8 Smokejumpers and 34CH with module of 10 personnel extracted from fire and released from incident.  SAGU WFM (4 personnel) inserted to continue command and operations.  SAGU WFM assistant crew leader is the new ICT4.  7/16/2012 95% containment reached.  READ extracted from fire via 9TA. Mop-up and patrol continue.  5 personnel total remain on the incident.  7/17/2012 6 cubies of drinking water delivered via 9TA.  Final demob planned for 7/19 based on conversation with IC.  ICT5(t) is in place.  Mop up operations continued, end of shift containment 95%.  7/18/2012 Mop up operations with Graff and SAGU crew continues.  100% percent contained by end of shift.  Crew rehabbed camp fire pits, made sure that all flagging was pulled off of incident and scattered cooking fire wood.  7/19/2012 All personnel and equipment extracted from the fire by 9TA.  Fire will be monitoring from the Park road by intermittent road patrols and from the air by opportunistic fly-overs during other operations.  South side of the incident is the dirtiest burn.  Note: there was no growth of the fire after initial GPS on 7/13/2012. 8/11/2012 Helicopter 2TC did aerial reconnaissance of the fire and found no smokes. (about � hour flight time) 8/14/2012 Helicopter 2TC flew a squad of three to the fire.  The squad patrolled the Blacktail fire and declared the fire out at 1330.  There were no smokes showing and green grass growing up through the black.  We performed rehab work on cup trenches and scattered the brush. (about 1 hr flight time)
I.A. by Yellowstone National Park Fire Department, Old Faithful Engine 6 and Truck 51. YNP Engine 1570 also responded. Suspicious origin- NPS LE Rangers investigating. Unable to find LE report.

Other: Range Fire was monitored daily by the Mount Washburn Lookout (Ed Stark) which substantially  decreased the need for aerial recons during the life of the incident.  Range Fire Narrative 27 July 2012 - WY-YNP, 1573-G3TU-E11  Resources Assigned: Becky Smith ICT4, Jack Yancick ICT4 (T) (Wilderness First Responder, Jason Thivener FEMO (Wilderness First Responder, Gabby O�Connor FFT1 (Wilderness First Responder), Alex Spannuth FFT2. Module will break into 2 separate IA    groups to assist with recon of the new starts. 0900 - Saguaro A will be assigned to hike to Observation Peak to try to get eyes on the Range Fire, Becky Smith (Fire Ecologist with YNP) assigned as Chief of Party. 1000 - Range fire Resources are en-route to Cascade Lake trailhead to begin hike into Observation Peak.  ICT4 (T) Yancick makes radio contact with 700 Fox relaying that information. 1100 � Range Fire Resources arrive at Cascade Lake trailhead and inform 700 Fox of status.  H-44D is flying in the vicinity of the reported Range Fire but is unable to locate any smoke. 1115 � ICT4 (T) Yancick briefs resources on intended action. 1125 � Resources depart trailhead (700 Fox is updated on status). 1200 � Arrive at Cascade Lake.  A weather disturbance containing lightening is in the general vicinity.  Resources take a lunch break to allow the storm to move on 1230 � Lunch is concluded and weather has improved to allow resources to continue on to Observation Peak 700 Fox informed of status.   1330 � Resources arrive at Observation Peak and inform 700 Fox of arrival.  We open up the Lookout; it appears to be in good shape.  No smoke is visible from the Range Fire. 1500 � Resources continue to try and locate the Range Fire, Smoke still not visible. 1630 � Smoke still not visible, Resources have closed the lookout and depart Observation Peak, 700 Fox is notified. 1800 � Resources arrive back at Cascade Lake Trailhead, load vehicles and depart for Mammoth Fire Cache, 700 Fox is notified. 1915 � All resources arrive safely at Mammoth and 700 Fox is updated, Group has an AAR of the day�s events.  7/28/12 � 7/30/12 � No activity visible from Mt. Washburn lookout.   8/24/2012 - Acreage confirmed with aerial recon at 50 acres plus spots ahead.  08/24/2012 � Minimal fire activity on fire since previous recon. 08/26/2012 � No significant increase in fire size.  Mostly backing to the west toward the Tower Creek Drainage.  Updated GPS mapping puts the fire at 140 acres.
