Fire was spotted by Backcountry Ranger 7S39.  Due to the location, time of year, fire danger, and available resources, the decision was made to fully suppress this fire. Smokejumpers were ordered and 8 were dropped on the fire. It was fully suppressed using MIST. Shoshone Fire Narrative 8/4/2012  - ~1330 hours. Park employee (reports a new fire/smoke west of Shoshone Lake generally near campsite 9D4 to 700F dispatch.  Mt. Washburn confirms the smoke and estimates at 0.1 acres.  Duty Officer consults with Chief Ranger and both concur to suppress it.  Decision was based on continuous green fuels from fire all the way to Old Faithful and 2 full months of fire season remaining.  2 starts (Trischman and Headwaters) in 2011 adjacent to this start and 4 to 6 weeks later in the season were not supported by management for resource objectives and were also suppressed.  Smokejumpers are ordered and our Park ship is dispatched directly from a recently completed SAR in Cooke City to this new start.  Decision to suppress made in less than 15 minutes.  Exact location is plotted and smokejumper operations commence at 1430 hours.  9TA  shuts down at Shoshone Lake while jumpers get onto the ground.  Smokejumper Jam is the IC.  Location is 44 19.918 x 110 49.669, 1.5 acres or less, 1-2� flames, low rate of spread creeping in down and dead fuels, less than 20% slope, low spread potential, very spotty burn, and white smoke.  4 more jumpers ordered at 1615.  No bucket work requested as 9TA stands-by near Shoshone Lake.  All jumpers safely to the fire and begin control operations.  No other resource requests. 8/5/12 � Suppression operations continue by the 8 smokejumpers with no other support. 8/6/12 � Backhaul completed by 1100 by helicopter 9TA.  Fire contained at 0755, controlled at 1455, and declared out at 1615 hours.  8 smokejumpers hike out to Old Faithful area via Howard Eaton section of the Continental Divide Trail 8/10/12 � Voicemail to Mayer at 1145 from Jumpbase in West Yellowstone.  He said that one Jumper did have a hard landing on the fire, was checked out by EMT on scene and OK.  Stayed on fire with light duty and flew out.  Checked out by Dr. in Idaho Falls and had a compression Fracture in his lower back.  All things considered to be a minor injury.  406-646-7691.

Other = 1 packer for 1 shift to pack in spike camp.  Narrative...8/7/2012 � Fire reported to 700F at 1250 hours by John Richardson who discovered it hiking out from backcountry campsite 2Y1 along Agate Creek Trail at 0900.  0.1 acres located at �first big switchback up from campsite�.  Fire was smoldering in duff, little smoke, with two blown apart trees nearby with low spread potential.  Thivener + 1 from SAGU WFM sent by DO to try and monitor incident from Park Road.  Reid notified of new start at 1320 by 700F.  Initial review indicates good candidate for Fire Use due to limited downwind improvements or values at risk, no control action taken as of 1400.  1408 Backcountry Office (Ivan Kowski) notified by DO (Cataldo) of threat to campsite and trail.  1409 DO confirmed with 700F that District Ranger (Lamar DR Chan) had been notified.  1505 decision to monitor is made by DO and Chief Ranger Reid.  Chan notified that no fire cache personnel will be hiking into the incident this day, but may tomorrow.  1535 Chan notified DO that he and Kevin Dooley (Lamar BC Ranger) are not going to attempt to contact the party of four that has a one night reservation at 2Y1.  They have left a note on the party�s car requesting a call when they are back to the trailhead.  YELL email notification sent out at 1715.  8/8/12  - 2 SAGU WFM crewmembers hike into fire supported by a pack string (Ranger Dooley).  They confirm the original size up of 0.1 acre smoldering.  They will remain based at campsite 2Y1 and monitor the fire until Monday the 13th.  They have signs and posts to warn visitors to stay out of fire area as trail remains open.  They also have signs for a closure if that occurs later on. They report light precipitation  over the fire today.  8/9/12 � Not much to report.  The fire did move somewhat, up to 0.5 acres.  It has transitioned into the heavier fuels and did not receive any precip. Or lightning from the passing storms. 8/10/12  - Less activity than previous.  Still .5 acre.  Smoldering in heavys.  At 1640 Fire did receive about an hour of steady rain.  No other activity other than light burning in heavies. 08/11/12 � Received significant rain over the evening.  A few smokes in the heavies. 08/13/12 � Still smoldering in heavies.  With some drying in the next few days, the fire could stay alive and get into the ground fuels.  The Fire suburban was shuttled to the Speciman Ridge trailhead to the firefighters when they hike out today.  Kevin Dooley was packing out their gear today.  Transfer command to Lewelling ICT3 and Cataldo ICT3(T) Cygnet Complex.  Hard copy fire folder has field notes from 2 SAGU WFM members whom staffed the incident for 5 days. 8/14-16/2012 � Minimal fire activity.  Cataldo confirmed plan not to staff the incident with Lamar District Ranger Brian Chan.  Chan is ok with that plan based on the fact that Mt. Washburn Lookout can see the fire if it increases in activity and will notify the IC immediately.  The campsite remains closed.   8/17-24/2012 � Minimal fire activity.  Fire not visible from the Mt. Washburn lookout. 08/28/2012 � Kraus hiked into the fire and checked it.  Fire declared controlled and out. 08/29/2012 � Notice sent out to fire notification list that campsite 2Y1 is now open.  Called Chan and backcountry office direct to notify.

8/7/12 � 2 small fires detected by a SMKJ aircraft (Jump 13) passing through the area.  GNF DO consulted and mutual decision with YELL DO to suppress is made.  No SMKJ available.  4 Rappelers inserted by nightfall by Helo 6HX.  They disengage at midnight for rest.  They advise two very spotty fires of 0.25 and 0.5 acre � mile apart.  They request a 20 person crew due to large amount of saw work. Rappeler *** is the IC. 8/8/12 � A Supply order is flown into fire.  6 persons from SAGU WFM are inserted, as well as, 8 SMKJ.  Later the crew order is filled with Blue Ridge IHC (22 persons).  They are briefed by D.O and YCR rep, given an IAP, and inserted along with 2 YELL resource advisors.  The 4 rappellers, 8 smkj, and helo 6HX are all demobed and released by end of shift.  Command is transferred to Blue Ridge IHC.  At end of shift 30 persons remained assigned. After meeting with the Type 4 IC, *** accepts the training assignment of Type 4 IC (t).  8/9/12  Little to report.  Good progress being made on line construction and mop up.  The staffing is sufficient. One squad from the Blue Ridge IHC is made avaliable for initial attack.   8/10/12  -  Contained at 1017. Update from ICT4(T). Thinking about rehab.  Specs to include pulling in berm and spreading debris along fireline.  Waterbars where necessary on steep sections of line.  They did find one spot fire 1/10 acre about 400 yards from the main fire on 8/9/12.  They thought that it was a spot and not a new start.  Blue Ridge is available as whole crew for IA as necessary.  Otherwise will maintain full staffing today and tomorrow.  Would like to make sure no heat with some sun on the fire.  Mostly overcast, light rain today.  Plan on removing everyone from the fire on the 12th. 8/11/12 � IC trainee recommending removing all personnel on Sunday the 12th.  Significant rain overnight. Fan 1 and Fan 2 fires rehabed as per YELL READ crewmembers specifications.  8/12/12-0800 Fan Fire IC and IC trainee agree that the Fan fires 1 and 2 are controlled and out. Crew shuttle to Gardiner airport begins at 1020.
I.A. with 4 GNF rapppellers.  Being engaged in combination with Fan 1 Fire.

08/10/2012 � Helicopter  was going to check a smoke report from public that was visible from the entrance of Virginia Cascades Drive.  They could not locate that smoke but did discover a smoke to the east.  They called in a size-up at 1550. Location 44 40.02 X 110 38.31.  Size: spot, smoldering and creeping in heavies dead and down Lodgepole spruce fir stand.  The terrain is mostly flat with moderate to high spread potential.  88 burn was mostly to the north and east of the fire.  Helicopter returned to helibase for a decision to be made on suppression.    Meeting with park superintendant office and chief rangers office decided to wait 48 hours to gather more information to make a final decision. 08/11/2012 � Sent crew of 3 in to ground truth fire.  Jess Bryers ICT5, Greg Oyler ICT5(T), Tyler Kulla.  Saw evidence of some small trees torching from yesterday.  Fire mostly smoldering in surface fuels.   At 1130, crew of three landed at helispot on the North end of Cygnet Lake (at: N 44 40. 390� X W 110 37. 153�). Hiked into fire and flagged the way in with orange flagging. On the way in, crew placed a HOBO temperature sensor at: N 44 40. 279� X W 110 37.632�. At 1300 crew arrived at the Cygnet fire (at: N 44 40.046 X W 110 38.308). At that time, fire was smoldering and creeping in litter, duff, and heavy fuels around the fire. Fuels were still wet from last night�s rain. The whole perimeter was active. No significant growth occurred since discovery.  Crew took fuel samples and weather observations around fire area. By 1430, the fire activity increased. Open flame was intermittently observed and smoldering and creeping activity increased. Fuels are continuous on all flanks of the fire, but are especially heavy on the South West side. Crew left fire by 1600. No significant growth occurred while crew was observing fire.  08/12/2012 � Met with Dep. Supt. and Chief Ranger regarding managing the fire.  Reviewed FSPro runs and highlighted concerns regarding values at risk.  Powerlines to the north are a big concern, but we discussed options to continue to support Canyon if the power goes out.  Generator at Lake should be sufficient to run Canyon, especially if the tourist season begins to wind down in two weeks as it usually does.  Decision was made to go ahead with managing this fire to continue to meet resource management plan objectives.  FMO worked with SOPL (Lewelling) to update WFDSS to include preliminary management action points (maps).  Discussed plan to transition SOPL to ICT3 for the complex of fires being managed and have Cataldo be ICT3(t).  Entire area in YELL was very thick with smoke from CA, NV, and ID fires.  Visibility was less than 2 miles. 08/13/2012 � Transfer of fire command to LewellingICT3 and Cataldo ICT3(T). 08/15/2012 � FMO Krish has a conversation with the Structural Fire Department and requests that they pre-position irrigation pipe and the pump truck at Norris as contingency for protection of infrastructure values in the Norris to Canyon area. 08/14-16/2012 � minimal fire activity. 08/17/2012 - Fire is finally visable from Mt. Washburn Webcam.  Estimated at 1 acre at 1400.  By 1645 fire is exhibiting group tree torching and is estimated from the webcam at 20 acres.  Lewelling goes on a recon flight to verify behavior and size, while Cataldo starts ball rolling on closing the Cygnet Lakes Trail.  By end of shift the trail has been closed, and the fire is likely at least 10 acres.  08/18/2012 � Updated acreage is 30 acres via webcam estimate.  Some group tree torching is evident with activity beginning around 1400 hours.  Resource orders for crews, PIOF, and misc. overhead are placed and begin to get in place.  A cabin protection kit for Mary Mountain Patrol cabin are assembled but not yet deployed there. 08/19/2012 � Updated acreage is 78 acres via aerial recon.  Group tree torching continues with increased activity starting around noon. One Type 2 IA crew and 2 GNF engines begin preparations to make utili

Narrative: The Beach 2 fire is located within the black of the 2010 Beach fire, the fire was discovered during a recon flight of the Cygnet fire.  There are no ground fuels and the fire is isolated to dead down fuels, there is little potential of fire spread.  The fire is surrounded by black, the nearest green is � mile to the N., � miles to the W., and 3 miles to the E.    During discussions with Chief Ranger, Tim Reid, the decision was made to confine the fire to the black of the 2010 Beach fire.  His concerns were: 1) Location of the fire to the Cygnet fire 2) Number of fires already burning in the Park 3) Red flag conditions predicted in the upcoming week.   The decision was made to confine the Beach 2 fire to the black of the 2010 fire.  My concerns of suppressing this fire were the amount of snags located in access to and area of the fire.  We decided that it would be added to the Cygnet Complex.  On 8/28/12 the decision was made to fly out to the fire and conduct bucket work to cool off the fire and keep in check, 23 drops were made.  The fire will be monitored from the air during recon flights of the Cygnet Complex.   8/27/12 1605 � Fire detected by recon flight of the Cygnet fire. 1612 � Duty officer, Fulton Jeansonne, makes decision to not insert fire fighters at this time, will meet with chief ranger.  1624 � Email notification sent out to park notification list. 1745 � Decision made by chief ranger to confine the fire to the 2010 Beach fire.  The fire will be added to the Cygnet Complex upon agreement with IC. No fire fighters will be inserted due to snag concerns.  Will make decision on action tomorrow morning. 8/28/12 0710 � Fire added to Cygnet Complex, will send 2TC out to conduct bucket work. 0920 � 2TC leaves Mammoth.  0939 � 2TC begins bucket work, 23 buckets dropped.  1220 � 2TC back in Mammoth.    9/20/2012 � Fire was checked by Lead Fire Effects Jess Page and declared contained, controlled and out at 1734 hours.

Narrative: The Canyon fire is located behind the Canyon Bison Dorms, approximately 50 yards down the trail from the parking lot.  In 2011 a fire of the same size was ignited in the same exact location.  The fire was discovered by a visitor who reported it to a maintenance worker.  The maintenance worker then applied a fire extinguisher to the active area.  Lauren Hamilton of the Canyon Ranger district responded initiating herself as the Incident Commander.  Canyon engine E85 was then called to respond, along with E4 from Lake.   This fire was 1/10 of an acre in size, smoldering in PINCON roots, Logs/duff and litter.  Adjacent vegetative fuel components apparent: PINCON, PICENG, PINALB, and ABILAS.  Substrates adjacent are: CARGEY and VACSCO.  The primary carrier of this fire is rotten dead/down 100-1000 hr fuels.  Event Log:  9/21/12  1700 � Fire detected by visitor and reported to maintenance worker. 1730 � Cygnet resources on scene (Keith Krause, Greg Oyler, John K., Michael Franke-Rose). 1715 � Engines apply �big water� to the smoldering spot. 1745 � MFR bucks smoldering log, while rest of crew opens up the area with tools. 1800 � Deputy Chief responds with code. 1830 � Reported contained. 1844 - E85/E4 leaves the incident.  9/22/12  1333 � Cygnet resources cold trail fire and ICT5 (t) MFR calls Canyon fire Controlled/Contained and out.

On 10/16/2012 at 16:30, I (Tim Panley) was dispatched to a smoke report along with Bill Mayer,  Bodie Tobin, Blake Chartier, Travis Clark, Greg Oyler, & Randall Throop.  I performed as ICT 5 trainee under Bill Mayer, and Bodie Tobin. 17:00; We arrived at the Elk Plaza Communication Towers approximately 1.5 miles west of Mammoth (the road requires 4 wheel drive).  I gave a briefing, & we began hiking in approximately � mi. SW of the comm. Towers at a heading of 240.  We arrived on scene at 17:25.  The coordinates are: N 44 58.953� by W 110 43.505.  It is located between Beaver Ponds Trail, & Sepulcher Trail.  LCES was in place before we engaged the fire. The size up is as follows:  30� x 60 (spot) wild fire with 1� flame lengths, smoldering, & creeping through deep litter & duff, burning 100s & 1000hrs., & burning out roots, and at the base of 4� to 10� diameter  trees (spruce & fir).  Winds were out of the west (down slope down valley) 5-20 mph.  The adjacent fuels are cured out (though wet) grass (Mammoth had recently received .13� of rain), 1000hr. dead & down, and live spruce & fir.  The potential was low to moderate.  The fire had a predominately east aspect with a 0-20 degree slope.  The origin of the fire is unknown (the lightening map does show a couple strikes in that vicinity the previous day).  However, no sign of a lightning strike was observed.  A 2� x 2� fire circle that appears to be reminiscent of a possible unattended �warming fire� or �user fire� was evident.   We confirmed coordinates at 18:00 with dispatch. At all times, we were in radio contact.   We attacked  the fire:  removed several hazard trees, cut burning trees into pieces, cleared the perimeter of the fire, and put a line around it; consolidated the heavies (bone piled), and dry moped.  We exited the scene at 18:30. Returned to the vehicles, and were back in Mammoth & out of service by 19:30.  An AAR was conducted. On 10/17/12 at 09:30 we re-engaged the fire after ensuring LCES was in place.  The cold had knocked the fire down considerably.  The bone pile was consumed entirely.  We had the same crew, and two bladder bags.  We worked the stump holes, and other hot spots.  We utilized a nearby pond to refill our bladder bags.  At 12:00, I called the fire �contained�.  At 15:00, I called the Elk Plaza fire �out�.  We hiked out, returned to the vehicles, and were back in Mammoth by 15:45.  An AAR was conducted.

6/13/13 Lewis Falls Fire Wagner and Tobin dispatched to Lewis Falls fire at 1200. After arriving at the Lewis Falls parking area at approximately 1345 we observed smoke southeast of the falls. After arriving at the fire we found it to be a dead, twin top, single tree lodgepole lightning strike with low spread potential. We called in a size up to 700 FOX and were advised to take lots of pictures and take no action to suppress the fire. After taking pictures we returned to the road at 1550 and departed for Mammoth.  6/14/2013 Wednesday � Regina Bilbrey 10:45 Arrived at Lewis Falls parking area with no visible smoke from the parking area or when approaching from either side of the bridge.  Began hike into the fire which required crossing Aster Creek. 1200 Arrived at fire (N 44� 15. 665� W 110� 37. 802�).  Fire character was smoldering in stump hole with little smoke and no significant spread from the previous day�s reportable size (0.1 acre).  Snow mounds observed SE of fire about 40 yards uphill.  Fuel samples taken by all 3 of crew included: carex(3), wortleberry(3), live lodgepole needles(3), little(3), 10hrs(3), 100hr cookies(5), and 1000hr cookies(5).  Weather observations were taken at 1245 by Bilbrey, 1315 by Williams and 1330 by Oyler. 1430 Began hike back to truck.  1515 Arrived and truck and returned to Mammoth at 1645.  1700 Fuel samples weighed and put into oven.   6/17/2013 Becky Smith 1400: arrived at Lewis Falls parking area and hiked into fire with Throop and Tobin. 1425: arrived on scene of Lewis Falls fire. 1430: FFT1 Randy Throop called in a fire update to 700FOX. No observable smoke and entire fire area was cold trailed and found cold. 1500: Hiked back to truck, removed fire signs from road and headed back to Mammoth.   6/25/13 Greg Oyler Fire was checked by Oyler, Bilbrey and Page.  No observable smokes and no heat found on fire.  Fire was called out.

7/3/13 Slough Fire Narrative IC. Ryan Tripp At approximately 1225 on 7/3/13 I received an order from John Cataldo FMO to head up to a fire reported up Slough Creek by campsite 2S2. I requested to take Engine 1570 up the trail/road and he conferred with Chief Ranger Tim Reid and Deputy Superintendent Steve Iobst, and gave me the OK to drive the engine up Slough Cr. We loaded up in 1570 with Tripp, Kulla, Fleming and Bilbrey. Met Tower rangers 5D35 and his partner at the trailhead and let them know we�d report anyone we thought suspicious as this fire was an escaped illegal campfire. We arrived at the confluence of Plateau Creek and the Slough Cr. Trail at 1445 and were met by Dave from the Warriors and Whitewater program.  He walked me into the fire about 300yds from the engine. Present at the fire scene were about 10 men most of whom are wounded war veterans or employees of the Silver Tip Ranch. They had smelled and then spotted the smoke from the horse wagons as they passed by and taken action. They had put about 20 cooler drops of water from the nearby creek on the fire and halted its progress.  Dave told me that some of the guys were stomping out the fire with their prosthetics until he reminded them that they couldn�t feel their plastic feet and should stop. But they caught the fire, there was only three or four small smokes when I arrived. They had preserved the origin and gave me a description of a guy that had walked in �from out of nowhere� to the fire scene and then just turned around and left. They said he was a fisherman packing a Sage rod case and wearing a GoPro camera on his chest. We had seen and briefly spoke to the same individual on the drive in, so I called 5D35 on the radio and relayed this information. I then thanked all the men on scene and they went on their way up to the Silver Tip Ranch. 1500. I called to Kulla to bring the rest of the crew and a portable pump off of 1570 to the fire and they arrived 10 minutes later. Fleming and Bilbrey got the pump set up and we went about mopping up the rest of the fire. I took pictures of the origin and the rest of the scene and collected the material/ garbage around the makeshift fire ring. There was an empty isobutane/propane mini stove canister and some garbage next to the fire. This evidence was delivered to the Tower Ranger station.  1600. Fire is contained 1700-1830. Re worked fire and no heat was present. 1900 Called Slough Fire controlled and OUT, and returned to 1570. 2130. Arrived back at fire cache.

7/4/2013.  ~1100 hours 700F received notification of a fire in Northwest portion of the Park.   Fire initially reported to be on Gallatin N. F. Gallatin Duty Officer requested recon of fire by on-call helicopter #0BR prepositioned at the Park. H0BR performed a recon with Wagner and Jeansonne on-board. GPS reveals that fire is inside the Park.  Size-up .25 to .5 acre with isolated torching and surface fire in subalpine fir on a southwest slope.  HOBR returns to Mammoth Helibase. Chief Ranger Reid contacted regarding fire and need to determine a strategy ASAP. Gallatin Duty Officer (Battalion 7, Anna Anderson) contacted to the same effect. 1155 Park decides to suppress the fire due to time of year and proximity to values in Tom Miner basin. T1 helicopter 314 (k-max) ordered to put water drops on fire to keep it in check until ground resources arrive.  Buffalo horn Lakes is dip site. E-1570 crew (Tripp + 2) flown up to fire. Tripp IC.  Gallatin readies 5 personnel for shuttle to fire from Dailey Creek Trailhead on west side of Park. 1400 Tripp requests 10 more personnel.  Cody Dispatch pledges to fill order.  Crew will RON in Mammoth, and be inserted tomorrow. Bear boxes, misc supplies, and a READ (Nedved) will be inserted this afternoon. Bill Mayer will be POC for Cody Crew as they arrive tonight. Fire is holding at ~1 ac. due to H314 drops.  Suppression efforts over the next 2 days are successful and without incident.  Fire is declared controlled on 7/6.  8/13/2013 Fire declared out.  No detectable activity for 5 weeks and extensive, intermittent moisture across the Northern range.

Weber Fire  IC Tobin 1500 I was sent to the Weber Fire in the canyon area from mammoth with Koel and Yellin. Before arriving on scene the fire was reported out. We continued to the fire to investigate. Mike Schell was in the canyon area and stopped by the fire, he stopped us on the road and informed us that Xanterra employees had poured water on the fire and dug it up. Schell also informed me that a tourist party was seen grilling in the area the previous night and had dumped out there ashes in the approximate area. Upon arriving on scene at 1600 we found the fire to be between two Xanterra cabins on the G loop, it was approximately 2ft by 2ft. We cold trailed the entire fire and found no heat. We found an area nearby that had stumps cut for sitting. We also found several cigarette butts in the area, no butts were found in or around the black. We then rechecked the fire. The fire was controlled and out at 1615. We departed the fire at 1617.

1610 - Report of fire started by dumped coals at site E188 in Fishing Bridge RV Park 1611 - Duty officer Cataldo advised, requested Patrol check report 1628 - Gleason (Structure Fire Department) on scene, requested page for Lake Structural fire for service call,Comm Center completed Page. See below for narrative from Structure Fire report completed by Gleason.  GLEASON'S REPORT:  Lake Fire Company was requested by Gleason to respond for a service call to Fishing Bridge RV Park E Loop Site 188 for a fire (NO fires allowed in FBRVP). Gleason on scene established IC and requested the Comm Center notify the Fire Chief and Deputy that E4 had been requested for a service call the FBRVP. With E4 on scene Gleason requested FF Allen and FF Fontaine to deploy the handline, stage and wait for water. With handline charged the crew soaked the burned log. IC Gleason took over for ENG Ross at the pump panel and requested Ross use the chain saw to cut the log to be rolled to fully soak the underside. With the log cut, the crew of FF Lindsay, FF Quall, FF Allen and FF Fontaine rolled the log. FF Allen and FF Fontaine further soaked the log to prevent rekindle. With the log saturated the Lake Fire Company was clear. All Lake Fire units back in service. Fire was extinguished by park visitors and reported to Xanterra campground staff. Request by 700FOX for photos and Lat. Long. N44.56828 W 110.36182 Initial investigation done by Gleason and having questioned park visitors who extinguished the fire. Fire was human caused, evidence for charcoal briquettes remained after the fire was extinguished. Photos to follow.

7/30/13 � 1700 hours. Fisherman reports seeing a lightning strike and a torching tree at the base of Quadrant Mountain on the east facing slope.  Lightning data confirms lightning in the area.  Fire Management staff unable to locate fire on foot.  7/31/13 � 1500 hours, another fisherman reports seeing smoke from a fire at the base of Quadrant mountain on the east facing slope that puffed up and then stopped.   Fire Management staff unable to locate fire on foot.  8/1/13 � Recon from helicopter 9TA during project work in the vicinity is unable to locate exact location of fire.  8/2/13 - Recon from helicopter 9TA enroute to a fire assignment in Washington  is unable to locate exact location of fire.  8/13/13 � Fire is declared out due to lack of activity and heavy wetting rains over the fire area over the past 2 weeks.
See file folder hardcopy for full report from responding units (Hebgen Fire Dept.)

8/5/2013 � Snake fire is reported at around 1600 hours to 700F Folts and passed on to Duty Officer Cataldo.  Chief Ranger Reid and Deputy Supt. are conferenced along with Fire Ecologist Smith.  Size-up is performed by Chris Vero in BT H25, Bridger Teton Zone Duty Officer, as ownership is in question and he is closest resource.  NPS/BT co-ownership is confirmed with origin likely on NPS.  Management team elects to manage fire under monitoring and point �protection strategy.  Size is 200 acres, spotting � to � mile in front of itself.  Heavy timber, 75% slope, upper 1/3 of slope, 9000� elevation, 44 08.83�, 110 36.8� Michael Curtis, South District Supervisory Backcountry Ranger is contacted re: trail closures, site closures, and public/employee safety concerns. Boyers is committed elsewhere to an MVA.  The South Boundary Trail east of the south entrance and sites 8C1,2,4,6,7, 8B2  are identified as immediate concerns.  Curtis will coordinate closures with Backcountry office.  Hasty evacuation deemed riskier than threat of fire reaching trail or visitors.  Fire across the snake river will be the trigger point for closing 8B1,3,4,5, and 8C5.  Email to file has particulars about closures as Curtis has assembled them.   Resource concerns include: Snake River Lookout site, AIS transport by helicopter, bears at potential spike camps (8C7 packer site) Hazards: cable across the snake river near fire. Info: Nash and Hottle are handling releases, coordinating with BT/GRTE, and posting info/signs. 2TC: prepared for crew shuttles and long-line missions into Harebell.  Bring an assortment of helmets and suits for backcountry evacuation if needed.  Bring Nomex for Curtis 36 long, XL long. Southern helicopter operations based temporarily out of south entrance helispot 44 7.982, 110 39.988. 8/6/2013 � 0800 Briefing. Smith is IC. Plan for day�Helicopter 2TC on loan from GNF.  First, transport Michael Curtis at 1000 for trail closures.  Then, SOA 1 repeater, then insert 4 from Storm Peak plus gear into Harebell Cabin for structure protection. Balance of WFM to staff E-1571 and monitor fire from road.  Fire fx to collect onsite fuels and weather data for spot forecast and FS PRO/LTAN runs.  8/7/2013 � 0700 Briefing.  Smith is IC.  Helicopter 7TA with module from the Black Hills is assigned to the fire.  All resources and ICP are moved to Grant.  Insert 2 Storm Peak Alpha members to Sheridan Lookout.  Transfer command to Lewelling ICT3 and Mayer ICT3(T), Smith planning, Kortge logistics, McAdams Finance. 8/8/2013 � Recon fire with Lewelling/Mayer.  Harebell Cabin group extracted and returned to Grant.  Structure Protection Group in place with Tripp as Supervisor.  Begin structure assessments of South area.  Discuss backcountry closure with Bowers and Curtis.  Discuss opening the Snake River Trail, the South Boundary Trail, Campsites 8C1, 8C7, 8C6, 8C2, and 8B2.  We chose to go with this for 8/9 and have an off trail area closure and keep 8C4 closed.  The backcountry rangers would develop an evacuation plan for the event that the fire threatened the trail.  The backcountry office would produce new maps to post.  The structure protection plan for Flagg Ranch is unavailable. 8/9/2013 � Plan mission to fly into backcountry and post new backcountry closure information and install RAWS on fire.  New fire start, Druid Fire, 7TA flew w/Throop to size-up fire.  Light rain over area.  Install RAWS at South Entrance.  Assess structures at flag ranch.  Work on structure protection plan and meet with Chief Grey re: structures etc.  Sign posting mission finally happened in the afternoon. 9/10/2013 � Fly FX crew of 3 in to Harebell cabin to read monitoring plots.  We planned on flying a mission for Druid fire, but it was cancelled.  PIO Weaver was called to respond to a fire in ID with her type 1 team.  Matt Spring was called to respond to AK with a R2 type 2 team.  The Black Hills was sending Josh Morgan to replace him.  IC + (T) flew recon on fire:  little act
Managed as part of the Druid Complex.  See hardcopy folder and firebox located in Mammoth Fire Cache for more info.
Managed as part of the Druid Complex.  See hardcopy folder and firebox located in Mammoth Fire Cache for more info.
Managed as part of the Druid Complex.  See hardcopy fire folder and fire box in Mammoth Wildland Fire Cache for more info.

Small fire in 1988 fire scar detected during recon operations on Druid Complex.  Included in the complex for management by monitoring.  Minimal fire spread due to depleted fuels in fire area, and intermittent moisture.

Single tree fire was detected east of the Yellowstone River during Alum fire operations following a lightning storm.  Fire was included in Druid Complex and monitored from the road.  Fire showed no activity after the first 2 days following detection.  Numerous rain showers fell over the fire area after detection.

On 8/30/2013 at approximately 1355 hours Yellowstone Dispatch paged the OF Fire Department for a report of a campfire that had escape the campfire ring.  They advised the fire was in a picnic area approximately 5 miles south of Old Faithful.    Upon arrival I contacted 2 visitors (John Ferko and Kathy Paulson) in the Spring Creek picnic area who advised that they had put water on a smoldering fire that was inside a campfire grate.  They added that other visitors had seen the fire and were the ones who called 911.  The campfire grate contained hot coals and had small whisps of smoke coming from it when I arrived on scene.  The campfire grate was a cooking grate style and would not contain the fire if not monitored.  Upon arrival of Truck 51 the crew deployed the water extinguisher and used a shovel to extinguish and cool the smoldering coals.  The fire and smoldering coals were cold to the touch and the fire declared out at approximately 1422 hours.  The scene was photographed and information was forwarded to the Wildland Fire Cache.  See attached photo log.  All units cleared at approximately 1430 hours  No further action taken

The Shoshone fire was discovered by the Mt Sheridan Lookout , Richard Jones, on September 17, 2013, at 1455 hours.  It was reported to be NW of the Shoshone Lake geyser basin.  The small smoke was described as being blue.  As the helicopter currently assigned to the Druid Complex was responding to a search on a nearby county, and the weather was increasing in severity, the fire was not flown at the time of the report.  The fire received significant precipitation over the next 24 hours and was not spotted again.

Dispatch Narative: At 1345, dispatch received a report from Ranger Allan Bush regarding an illegal campfire. At 1100 am he located  the fire at an illegal campsite while rescuing an injured camper at the site. There was spread potential as the logs extended past the ring into unburned fuels. He put out the fire out as much as he could using his water supply, and hiked out to report the fire.  The information was passed on to the duty officer and ICT5(T) Wines, and two other firefighters responded.  IC 5 Trainee: Morgan Wines   1400: Received a call for a fire up Rescue Creek Trail   1430: Contacted dispatch about reported fire  1440: Arrived at dispatch to receive further information   1502: Wines, Franke-Rose, and Trout en route to Blacktail Trailhead  1524: Wines, Franke-Rose, and Trout left Blacktail Trailhead en route on Rescue Creek trail to fire   1705: Wines, Franke-Rose, and Trout arrive on scene to size up fire   1717: Wines reported size up and estimated time to control to dispatch   1720: Stirred fire up and poured water on to cool down   1730: Wines called fire contained   1743: Wines called fire controlled and out   1745: Wines, Franke-Rose, and Trout en route on Rescue Creek trail to Blacktail Trailhead  1900: Wines, Franke-Rose, and Trout arrived back at Blacktail Trailhead and en route back to Mammoth

7/4/2014 0100 � Several different reporting parties from town of Gardiner, Montana report seeing  a fire �involving a few trees� flare up on the far northern end of Sepulcher  Mountain.  The area received significant rainfall in addition to the lightning on the night of the start.  Eye witness report from a wildland firefighter stationed in Gardiner, MT confirms this.  7/5/2014 Air and ground resources attempt to locate the fire via helicopter overflight and glassing from nearby vantage points, but are unsuccessful in doing so.  7/15/2014 No smoke or flame is visible in the reported vicinity of the fire so it is declared controlled and out by the Duty Officer John Cataldo.

Specimen Fire 2014 7/5/14  IC Matt Abell Engine 691 with, Abell, Bueter, and Schell responded to report of fire at east end of Lamar Valley. Crew attempted to hike up to fire but unable to cross Lamar River. Fire showing light smoke, lat/long approximated, hike back to engine to return to cache and address fire the next day. 7/6/14 IC Regina Bilbrey At 1038, 2TC flies Hafer, Bilbrey (IC), Bueter, Harris to fire with approximated lat/long from previous day�s size-up.  No smoke visible from the air.  1050 Decision made to land in clearing above location of fire and have Bilbrey, Bueter and Harris search for fire on the ground.  2TC back to Mammoth with Hafer and pilot. At 1100 fire located and new size-up given to dispatch, saw work and line construction initiated.  1145 saw work completed.  1235 line completed, 2 backpack pumps emptied on fire by crew, request made to dispatch for 2TC bucket work. 1300 3TC at fire, 3 buckets completed and mop up phase continued.  1410 relayed to dispatch that fire is controlled and contained, hiked back up to LZ.  1420 Difficulty reaching 2TC on radio, dispatch attempting communication.  1506 Communication established with 2TC and informed that crew is ready for pick-up.  1544 2TC landed back at Mammoth with Hafer, Bilbrey, Bueter, Harris.    7/15/14 No smoke or heat showing on fire since IA on 7/6.   Fire is declared out by Duty Officer Cataldo.   DUTY OFFICER NARRATIVE Specimen Fire 7/5/2014 Duty Officer: Ryan Tripp Reported by Doug McLaughlin in the Lamar Valley at 1005, report was light smoke on east end of valley looking south east.  700F had 5D35 head to the area to get a better idea of what�s going on. 15 minutes later he had smoke in sight and gave us a rough lat long that put the fire on the E slope of Amethyst Mtn. 1058 DO sent text out to chief ranger, superintendent. Supt said �Thanks� @ 1157 .Heard back from chief ranger @1148, she is in Ashton but in cell service. At 1100, 691 dispatched to fire to get a good size up,  Abell ICT5, Bueter, and Schell. Once they arrived at the Lamar River Stock Trail Head 1207, IC was able to confirm lat long and location. DO was unable to get a face to face with management, so made the decision to suppress,  also due to the time of year, limited staffing, visibility and proximity to the NE corridor of unburned fuels leading directly to the NE entrance, Silver Gate and Cooke City.  IC and crew made their way to the fire across Lamar Valley at 1300 and were unable to ford the Lamar River at the Specimen Ridge trail ford. DO/700F instructed IC to get a better size up and lat long and photos and make their way back to the trailhead and we would figure out how to get them across on 7/6.  7/6/14 Bilbrey IC, with Bueter and Harris in 2TC, out to locate fire and find LZ and engage with suppression action.  Located good LZ from the air, in an area above where they thought the fire would be, as they could not see it from the ship. Landed and did a grid down the hill and found the fire a short distance away. Found the fire in an old douglas fir log on the ground, it appeared to have been burning for a while. It appeared to be a natural ignition. They took suppression action and had 2TC drop a couple of buckets on it and mopped up the stump. They then called the fire contained and controlled and walked off the hill to the lower LZ next to the river.

The Line Fire 	The Line Fire was ignited on 7/24/2014 by a downed powerline north of the Fishing Bridge developed area.  The powerline ignited a dead and down log that was lying on the ground beneath the powerline.  The fire became established in the down and dead log with mostly smoldering and creeping but would not burn the surrounding vegetation due to high moisture content in the grass.  The general public was the initial reporting party and also walked up to the fire(which was only 100 yards from the road)to see if they could put it out.  The public proceeded to disperse portions of the dead and down log so in their opinion it would go out.  Lake patrol(L16) was the second party on scene and instructed the general public to head back to the road and then he piled the logs into one area because some grass was beginning to burn with the burning logs laying directly on top of the vegetation.  Lake structure Engine 16 was next on scene and easily brought a hose to the fire and put roughly 300 gals of water on the burning logs.  E 16 also dug line around the burning material and made sure all hotspots were out and cold.  Wildland Fire Engine 691 from Mammoth was last on scene about 2.5 hrs from initial report.  E 691 tied in with L16 and E 16 and determined the fire out.  In the end the fire was about a 10th of an acre and burned mostly the dead and down log with a little grass being burned where the public had dispersed the logs.   FROM STRUCTURAL FIRE INCIDENT REPORT Lake Fire Company was paged to a fire caused by a downed power line at LeHardy Burn. E-5 responded with a crew of 2. E-4 responded with a crew of 2. Northwest Energy had arrived on scene prior to our arrival and cut power to the lines and advised us that the area was safe to begin fire suppression. The fire was approximately 5 yards wide by 15 yards long and actively burning in grass and downed wood. The fire area was approximately 200 yards uphill from the roadway. A hand line and hotel pack were deployed off E-5 and charged. FFs Amundson, Kelsey, and Fragua formed an attack team. The hose line was charged and the fire area was swept with water several times. FFs Fragua and Kelsey used hand tool to cut a fire break around the area. FFs Kelsey and Fragua turned the ground several times and smoldering was extinguished with water. All fire activity in the area was extinguished by 1500hrs. Lake Fire Company remained on scene and monitored the area until Mammoth Wild Land Fire arrived on scene at 1615hrs. All units were clear at 1637hrs. E-4 and E-5 were rehabbed and available at 1720hrs.

Grouse Fire Narrative (#1405)  8/14 /2014    An off-duty GRTE Ranger (810) detects and reports a fire south of the Trail Creek Trail in the Grouse Creek Drainage 3 miles southwest of the south arm of Yellowstone Lake. The ranger includes the coordinates in the size up as 44 14.79� 110� 22.05.  The fire is burning in base of one 24� DBH downed snag, and had low spread potential due to being surrounded by green grasses and forbs.  Additionally, imagery suggests that the fire is located in the 1988 fire scar.  This fire scar is still only carrying fire under fire weather conditions on the very high to extreme end of the spectrum, such as sustained LP4 crown fire under a consistent 5 to 10 mph wind entering the edge of the fire scar.  There are few values at risk in the fire planning area. Pete Webster in CRO and Superintendent Dan Wenk are consulted and both concur with FMO/Duty Officer Cataldo to manage this fire long term for natural ecosystem processes and not to suppress it.  Fire is entered into WFDSS, and the YNP wildfire decision support tool is completed, signed, and scanned into WFDSS as well. Plans are made to monitor the fire with a remote camera on Mount Sheridan.   8/15-17/2014  Ongoing SAR priorities and unfavorable flying weather have resulted in the camera not being mounted on Mount Sheridan yet.  Plans are made to fly to the fire the next day and see if it persists and still has spread potential.  If so the camera will be mounted on Mount Sheridan. If the camera cannot be mounted then a lookout may be placed in the Mt. Sheridan Lookout to monitor the fire area for activity. 8/18/2014 Checked the fire with Helicopter 9TA.  No smoke or flame visible.  UTL fire.  Plan is to opportunistically monitor the fire area for activity with research aircraft that all already in the area so as not to incur additional risk.  9/1/2014 After no signs of activity for two weeks, the fire is declared out.

IC Bill Mayer At 1650 on May 3rd, 2015, Engine 692 with Mayer and Smith responded to report of fire along the Firehole River across the river from north end of the Firehole River Dr. where the road meets the river. When E-692 arrived on scene at approximately 1753, Old Faithful Ranger Matt Lovingier had command of the scene and was monitoring the fire from Firehole River Drive.  Old Faithful E-6 with McCoy and Derene were on scene and sprayed limited water across the river to keep the fire in check until fire investigation could be completed and qualified wildland personnel could suppress the fire.  The fire was suspected to be human caused.  Fireworks were found on the south side of the river along the road.  There was a report of 2 individuals across the river earlier in the day.  The fire was reported by a Canyon Maintenance worker and Dan Urie was second on scene.  Jessie Pike arrived on scene to help provide investigative the cause and provide subject matter expert guidance dealing with the swift water to be dealt with in crossing the firehole river.  Command was transferred to Mayer at approximately 1800. Mayer, Smith, and Pike scouted a suitable river crossing for accessing the fire utilizing hip boots.  Pike advised due to the current that PFDs should be worn due to the volume of water, the weight of the gear that we were carrying and the added weight of water that would be trapped in the hip boots if we were to fall.  Jeremy Ropp was called to bring additional PFDs from Old Faithful.  Pike located 2 PFDs in the Patrol cars on scene so Mayer and Pike crossed the river to access the fire. Once on scene, fire activity was minimal and size was approximately 30� X 40�.  We searched the scene and located 2 large bottle rockets, one in the fire perimeter and one in some rocks adjacent to the fire scene.  A collapsible bucket was used to bring water from the river to suppress the hot spots.  The perimeter was cold trailed.  All hot spots were 100% mopped up and cold trailed.  Due to the risk crossing the river, no chainsaw was on the fire scene, so no logs were bucked up, but mop-up was still adequate. The fire was declared contained and controlled at 1945 and the crew crossed the river and performed an AAR. The fire was assigned IMARS case number NP15038264. The fire was declared out on 05/14/2015 at 1615 by Mayer observing the fire from across the river with binoculars.

Powerline Fire 2015 5/16/15 IC Bill Mayer At 1937 on May 16th, 2015, a report came in to 700 dispatch that �south of LeHardy Rapids, a tree on the powerline, not more than 10 inches in diameter on the west side of the road.�  700F and Northwestern Energy Pederson were advised of the situation.  700F said patrol should check the situation and get pictures and a good location if possible.  5C32 and 5C34 responded at 1948. Northwestern Energy arrived on scene at 2010 and cut the tree off the line.  The tree was cold to the touch by 5C32.  All units clear at 2020. On May18th Mayer was assigned IC of the fire and on May 20th he traveled to the site to confirm location and that the fire was out.  The fire was declared out at 1500.

7/4/15: IC Benke and Stenvers (t).  This narrative is based on the incident organizer and associated events: Benke, Braun and Stenvers hiked into fire from Eagle Creek based on the initial fire report from 7/3/15 of fire being near campsite 1Y1.  Once a more accurate location was determined, they hiked further east of initially reported location and found the fire just west of campsite 1Y4.  They arrived on scene at 1400, completed securing the perimeter at 1600, and called the fire contained at 1630.  At 1730 they started hiking out to the Blacktail TH and reached the vehicles at 2100.  7/5/15: Smith and Page hiked into fire from Blacktail TH at 1100.  Smith was ICT5.  Arrived in fire area at 1245 and searched for fire.  Determined fire coordinates were wrong, and in process of hiking back to the trail they found the fire roughly 30� off of trail, west of the western spur trail to campsite 1Y4.  No visible smoke was seen during duration of time on fire.  The entire fire was cold trailed, and called controlled and out at 1400. They began hiking out of fire at 1420, and arrived at the trailhead at 1630.

8/15/15 Fire reported at 22:22 by Linda Daws, who reported seeing �campfire� size flames near the second switchback on Bunsen peak. Another person at Yack camp reports seeing fire through spotting scope and takes a picture. Dispatch attempts to contact Cataldo/Opperman, does not make contact, tries again next day.  8/16/15 Dispatcher Blaine Hoppe reports seeing fire driving to work.  At 0800, Cataldo assigns Hafer, Crouter, and Stenvers to locate the fire in E692, Hafer as IC, Crouter as trainee. Crew makes contact with Blaine Hoppe at dispatch to get an approximate location. Hoppe puts the fire on west side of Bunsen Peak, roughly halfway between the top of Cathedral rock and tree-line. At 0830, E692 sets up at Yack camp with spotting scope to try and locate fire. No signs of smoke, but made contact with locals who all report seeing fire in same location. E692 returns to base 1230. Hafer and Crouter make contact with Joe Beuter for a more detailed location. Beuter puts it in same spot, but closer to the top of the ridge. At 1500, Hafer and Crouter return to Yack camp to try and locate fire again, but see no smoke or signs of fire, return to cache at 1700.   8/19/15 At 1200, Cataldo assigned Allen as IC and Wallen as IC trainee and tasked us with hiking Bunsen Trail in search of fire. At 1330 we begin hiking Bunsen Trail. At approximately 1415 we locate a side trail with some soil disturbance at the third switchback facing Mammoth. At 1417 we located a small burn spot and then a few feet away a pile of rocks that covered a campfire. The campfire was ringed in small rocks. We checked the fire for any indications of heat and found none. One can of beans was left in the fire and we packed it out. Upon further scouting of the site we located some small bits of string and a single led pen light. It did not appear that the individuals that made the campfire slept on the ground but slept from hammocks suspended from nearby trees. We also located two uprooted saplings (<4�) but could not locate where they originated. Photos were taken of the campfire ring and surrounding area. We determined this to be the fire that was reported on 8/15/15 as no other campfires were discovered from further scouting of the surrounding area all the way to Bunsen Peak and with the freshness of the burned material and ground disturbance. We departed Bunsen trail at 1622 for cache.  Campfire GPS location is N 44 degrees 56.172� W 110 degrees 42.601�

Pumice Fire IC Narrative  8/21/2015 Single log on fire within 2 feet of Yellowstone Lake reported to 911 at 17:38. At 17:46 700F requested patrol to investigate and is on scene at 17:47. At 17:48 DO Tripp instructs for structure engine to put out fire and that 692 will be enroute shortly.  Roper is on scene and becomes IC at 17:51 and lightning fire is extinguished and controlled at 17:54. All resources depart scene at 18:02.  692 cancelled.  8/22/2015 At 09:30 Allen and Chartier depart for Pumice Fire in 692. Arrive on scene and locate fire at 11:30. Chartier is IC. Investigate fire and determine it to be cold and out. Fire could potentially be human or lightning caused but is documented as a lightning strike. There was some wood chips scattered about that were either pulled off from the responders on the 21st or were blown off from a lightning strike.                                                                   Fire GPS location is N 44 27.379� W 110 30.554 Depart scene at 12:30.

5L4 Fire IC Narrative  8/24/2015 At approximately 1140 fire is reported to dispatch, trees torching at campsite 5L4 on the South Arm of The Promontory. At 1202 per Cataldo, a helicopter with bucket is requested but none are available. At 1215, 7L15 has a boat ready for firefighter transportation at Bridge Bay Marina. The assumption is that the fire is human caused because of location at a campsite. Suppression will be aggressive. At 1300 Allen, Stenvers, and Bueter leave Mammoth for Bridge Bay Marina and then depart on vessel for fire. Allen assumes IC of fire and arrives on scene at 1555. Single and group tree torching is observed with south flank of fire most active. Fire is mosaic in pattern with fingers and smoldering/creeping on north flank. Estimate 1-5 acres. Winds are 1-10 and steady from the south west and fire is in Lodgepole, Spruce/fir with regen and very dense. There are numerous snags with very heavy dead and down jackstraw. Navigating fire is difficult due to dead and down. We investigate the campsite and determine that the fire did not originate there. Fire ring is cold. No evidence of anyone having been there for days. There are no trails leading from campsite to fire location. Fire perimeter is approximately 3 to 4 chains from campsite but moving towards campsite. Ember wash from torching is creating small spot fires ahead of fire. Scout the interior of the fire looking for potential origin/lightning strike but fire consumption prevents this, none located. While we are on the north flank of the fire, the intensity picks up on south flank and fire spreads to lake shore and 5L4 campsite. At approximately 1635 Grand Teton ship 38HX is enroute to fire and at 1650 arrives on scene and does a size-up of fire and determines fire to be 3 acres with spot fires ahead of fire. We determine that it will take multiple crews and air resources to suppress fire. At 1708, 38HX is released and returning to GRTE. Fire is now to be a managed fire, no suppression actions to occur and fire is disengaged. IC and crew are ordered to return back to Mammoth and depart scene at 1715. Fire is putting up decent column, much more visible now and can still be seen from a far distance across lake.   8/25/2015 Smith took over as IC of fire on 8/25/15.  Smith, Stenvers, and Bueter left cache at 1100 and drove to the Fishing Bridge area.  Stopped at the Fishing Bridge Visitor Center, Fishing Bridge General Store, Fishing Bridge RV Park, and the Lake Hotel to drop off maps and inform of fire.  No one was aware of the fire, except the Visitor Center who had only heard rumors of it as they do not have phones or internet at this time.  Drove down to Gull Point Drive to find a decent place to observe fire; Frank Island was in the line of sight and therefore the fire was not visible.  Tried parking near Indian Lake with decent view of fire, but ended up on the beach near the Visitor Center at 1400 with the best view of the fire.  At 1405 3L65 (fisheries employee) reported group tree torching on the fire.  There were a large amount of thunderstorms passing through the area all afternoon, and when fire would get solar radiation (i.e., wasn�t covered by a cloud) it would start putting up some smoke indicative of single and group tree torching.  Left area at 1730; fire is estimated to be between 10 and 100 acres.  A press release went out today, and a boat ride was set up for 8/26/15 to get firefighters on the ground and assist with gathering of fire acoustics.  8/26/2015 Boat ride to fire with Smith, Bueter, Stenvers, Jerrett (audio) and Herbert (film) was canceled today due to weather.  No monitoring took place, and no reports came in about smoke or flames visible.  8/27/2015 At 1100 a fisheries boat in the South Arm of the Lake reported some smoke from the fire, but no active flames visible.  Smith updated PIO Bartlett and Campbell of current fire situation (or lack thereof) and of upcoming IC change on 8/30.  The Cabin Creek RAWS part showed up tod

Frisbee Fire IC Narrative 8/25/2015  At 19:12 reporting party notifies Yellowstone Communications Center of a fire in a stump on the Frisbee disc golf course behind the east parking lot at Old Faithful, behind the employee housing.  19:15 Old Faithful Fire Company dispatched and arrives on scene at approximately 19:30 and 4F82 is IC.  Reporting party is a group of Xanterra employees. They state that they passed through the area about 30 minutes before  while playing disc golf and saw or smelled nothing. Then upon coming through again they saw 1� flames from three arm-length logs and a stump. It did not look like a campfire to them. They notified YCC and before firefighters arrived, they picked up the burning logs and carried them to the Firehole River and extinguished them. They also located a bucket and doused the stump with water and dirt. At 19:36 firefighters see no smoke or flames, just smoldering, site is so disturbed that no evidence can be found as to cause. Firefighters take gps coordinates (N 44 27.522 W 110 49.35) and pictures and at 20:12 call the fire contained. At 20:18 firefighters leave the scene.  8/26/2015 Allen contacts Kate McCoy-Fire Protection Specialist, to gather more information on fire and to see if it is necessary for Fire Cache personnel to come to Frisbee fire to investigate. Kate believes that is it not necessary and Fire Cache personnel concur. Past lightning maps indicate that no lightning has occurred within the vicinity since 8/15/15 and none of the lightning received then was near Frisbee fire location. Fire determined to be human caused.

Spruce Fire Narrative 9-9-15  Fire discovered by park helicopter while enroute to Grant for project work.  1/10 acre and probably been there for several days. In thick spruce/fir with not very good access.  Mt Washburn LO was able to locate the fire after called in by the helicopter.  Due to remote location and no resource values currently threatened, decided to manage the fire for resource benefit and not to put in any ground resources of firefighters. 9/10/15 Little fire growth with smoke increased at 1700. 9/11/15 Afternoon helicopter recon mapped the fire at 52 acres.   YELL duty officer contacted the NPS regional office to request PIO help.  Requested an FSPro run for the fire.  Talked with Riverton NOAA office.  Weather would be fire growth favorable till 9/14 when a very wet weather system would move in.  Briefed the Chief Ranger and Deputy Park Superintendent.  Talked with YELL and GRTE public information officers for fire support.   9/12/15 425 acres at 1300 from helicopter recon.  Ordered 6 PIO�s and a SITL to act as type 3 plans.  Had ground monitors scout for observation locations with no luck. 9/13/15 Put in place a type 3 organization of a ICT3, ICT3(t), a DIVS for operations, TIME and Lloyd and Jerry for logistics.  Started to develop a structure protection plan for the Lake developed area.  2115 acres from afternoon helicopter recon. Put structure wrap over historic cabin (four logs high ruin) that was north of the fire. 9/14/15  Wet weather system moved over the fire area resulting in little fire growth.  2500 acres. 9/15/15 Rain / snow.  Demob of resources. Fire continued to lightly smoke for another month with no real fire growth. Fire called out 10/29/2015 after several rain/snow weather events    INCIDENT OBJECTIVES	1. INCIDENT NAME Spruce	2.  DATE 9/14/2015	3.  TIME 1900 4.  OPERATIONAL PERIOD (DATE/TIME  9/14/2015  0700-2000 5.  GENERAL CONTROL OBJECTIVES FOR THE INCIDENT (INCLUDE ALTERNATIVES) Leader�s Intent:   The highest priority will be focused on minimizing risk to firefighters and the public.   It is the expectation that every person assigned in any type of leadership role does a risk assessment and provides the appropriate mitigation measures prior to engaging in any activity.  If a hazard cannot be mitigated to an acceptable level, the issue will be elevated to the next level.     Management Requirements: 1.	Ensure firefighter and public safety is the first priority in every operation.   Incident Objectives 1.	Allow the fire to play its natural role in the ecosystem as a process to the greatest extent possible. 2.	Protect resource values, natural, and cultural resources. 3.	Plan for medical care and extraction when placing firefighters in the backcountry.  6.  WEATHER FORECAST FOR OPERATIONAL PERIOD                                 *See attached

Plumber Fire IC Narrative 9/10/2015 At 1246 a grass fire was reported 30 yards behind the plumbing shop. The fire was paged and within two minutes 5A20 arrived on scene. At 1248 Yellowstone employees working close by came over to assist putting the flames out with rakes and shovels. At 1251 E1 +4, E691 +2 (Mayer and Bell), Hafer and Chartier arrived at the incident. E1 rolled out hose and began putting water on the fire while Fire Cache personnel wet mopped the area with tools. The fire was small enough that no additional resources were needed and the existing personnel were able to put it out themselves. At 1308 the fire was 100% contained and 1500 the fire was reported out per command. The Plumber fire started due to a Yellowstone employee cutting metal pipe and sending sparks into the area of dry grass. The employee immediately made a phone call to dispatch and recruited other employees working close by to assist in putting out the flames.

Initial and only action taken by NPS Fisheries employees by throwing snow on the burned logs.
Fire reported by visitor.  Smoldering fire in wood chips.
Fire reported near trail head.  Assumed human start, so the fire was suppressed.
IA was recon only.

Fire reported by visitor.  Due to fire being near private land and early in the fire season, the fire was suppressed.  Access was by helicopter and smokejumpers from a plane.  Steep slopes and lots of snags.
Single tree fire reported by NPS employee on days off.  Photos submitted to duty officer.  After one solid month of no reportable activity the Bighorn fire is declared out.

This was a log near Spasm Geyser along the boardwalk. On 07/20/2016 at about 1340, it was reported that there was a smoldering log burning near Spasm Geyser at the Fountain Paintpots area.  This was reported by 3 different visitors.  Mayer was notified to respond with E-691.  Smith was temporarily unavailable so Chartier responded with Mayer at 1414.  Anderson returned to the Fire Cache so they switched out so Chartier could be available if a helicopter need arose.  E-692 was on scene at 1602 and began looking for the smoke.  After braving the heavy pedestrian traffic on the boardwalks, a burnt log was found about 5 to 10 feet just east of the boardwalk near Spasm Geyser.  The burn marks were fresh, but the log was cold and wet like someone had dumped a water bottle on the log.  We cold trailed the log to make sure it was out.  We continued to search the area as we returned to the truck in case there was another smoke nearby.  Nothing was found.
Escaped illegal campfire area. Suppressed by Ranger Anderson while on routine patrol.

See fire packet located in Mammoth Fire Cache for additional detailed report:  8/5/2016 A new fire was reported Thursday august 4th in the Fawn pass area by an outfitter.  On Friday Aug 5th a recon flight was conducted by YNP hellitack at 08:00 hrs.  Helitack confirmed that there was a fire in the area and reported it at around 1 ac and burning with minimal fire behavior in a stand of spruce.  At 11:30 the three person YNP Fire Effects team was flown into the fire and arrived on scene at the fire at 12:30.  Flying into the fire the team also observed minimal fire behavior with a couple torched trees.  Arriving on scene FX reconed and GPSed the fire perimeter.  The GPS tracks showed the fire perimeter at 1.1 ac.  Also the team found that the fire was burning in a predominantly douglas fir and true fir stand with creeping and smoldering fire in the duff and litter with individual immature firs torching, the fire was extinguishing in live green fuel.   The team estimated there to be actively creeping and smoldering fire on 60-75 % of the fire perimeter.  The team collected fuel samples from the representative fuel and observed that fire behavior diminished from 12:30-1600 as cloud cover increased.  At 16:00 the team hiked back to the LZ for their 17:00 pick up.  While at the LZ waiting for pick up the team observed the fire column increase in volume and lift and change from white to black indicating increased fire behavior and sustained torching of live trees.  Upon pick up the team conducted on more fly around of the fire and confirmed the increase in fire behavior with a sustained flame front in the dead and down and numerous mature fir trees torching, green meadows appeared to continue to retard fire spread.   Helitack also flew into the Fawn Pass cabin and performed a ground recon of effort and equipment needed to protect the structure.  It is included in fire folder.  Supplies are cached together in the fire garages for easy access. 8/6/16 Significant fire activity and growth today commencing around 1600.  Estimated fire at 500+ acres as of 1830.  Cataldo initiated coordinating ordering of PIO support with Park PAO Morgan Warthin.  Availability of logistics support checked for Jerry Ryder and Lloyd Kortge in the event that PIOs need a base camp established due to lack of rooms in local commuting area.  Coordination with Central Backcountry Office on campsite and trail closures continued.  Recommended closing WB 1, WB3, WB4, and WB6 sites, as well as, Fawn and Bighorn Pass trails for several miles on either side of the fire.  Hard copies of emails in fire folder. Cabin Protection Kit and personnel (Clark +3) dispatched to the Fawn Pass Cabin area around 1730 hrs.  Unable to fly into cabin due to passing afternoon thunderstorms. 0.16 of precipitation fell at Quadrant RAWS.  Transition to ICT4 Plovanic from ICT5 Clark tomorrow morning at 0700. 8/7/16 Nick Plovanic is now Fawn ICT4.  IC plus 3 into Fawn Pass cabin to implement protection measures.  PIO support ( 4 personnel) on a  resource order.  Monitoring camera to be ordered tomorrow morning, cache is closed today.  Dan Warthin unavailable to assist.  Checking availability on misc. Type 3 support personnel (Jeansonne, Taber, Kortge, Ryder).  Fire info signage approved for purchase.  Local PIO support (Cudmore and Reid) helping incident today along with Morgan Warthin.  Cabin crew elected to overnight at cabin and has made good progress on protection plan.  0.29 24-hour total rainfall on this fire.  Minimal spread today, burning in heavy logs mostly. 8/8/2016 Plovanic +3 flown out of fire.  Minimal fire behavior or growth.  Cabin prep is complete.  Will return firefighters to the cabin if/when burning conditions change towards more active. 8/9/2016 Washburn webcam can see Fawn fire if it shows significant activity.  None reported or seen by the Lookout today. 8/10/2016 Fire activity picking up in mid-afternoon.  Occasional light white smoke visible from Mammoth and Mt. Washb

8/7/16.  Fire 1 mile west of campsite 3P1 reported by an NPS employee. Dispatched 9TA with IA squad of 3.  Beisner +2 to suppress due to proximity to NE entrance/Silver Gate/Cooke City.  Fire is on East aspect in heavy old growth timber.  White smoke, no flame at time of dispatch. 0.1 acre. Challenging access.  Dropping firefighters off, putting on the bucket to check fire spread, and will engage the fire once we have all 3 IA crew ready to hike.  Fuel truck to Buffalo Ranch to reduce ferry time. Beisner plus two FFTR RON at fire.  Copious amounts of bucket work while they were enroute should facilitate control by end of shift tomorrow. 8/8/16 Fire is declared out at end of shift and IA crew hikes out.  One sling of blivets in and overnight gear out in the morning was needed to complete the task.

8.17.16 - Lightning was observed by two firefighters setting up a camera on Mt Holmes for the Maple Fire and 20 minutes later they notices smoke in the same location on Grayling creek. The fire was reported to be at the base of a green tree in old '88 burn. The medium ship assigned to the Tatanka Complex was assigned to conduct bucket work to knock the fire down and hold it in check. Bucket work was successful and the fire was knocked down.  8.18.16 - Two fire fighters were inserted into the fire in the morning. The IC's size up reported it at a 1/4acre in litter, grass, and down and dead with moderate spread potential. They requested 3 additional firefighters. Three additional firefighters were inserted along with overnight gear and supplies. Bucket work was conducted for two fuel cycles. In the late afternoon tow additional firefighters were inserted bringing the total to 7. The fire was lined and mop-up was started.  8.19.16 - Firefighters continued to mop-up, fire was contained at 1148.  8.20.16 - Crew cold trailed fire, and was extracted from the fire. Controlled and out at 11:18.

Fire lined and mopped up. resources released for the evening to be checked tomorrow.  8.20.16 - Fire checked by BTP E-461, cold trailed, no smokes or hot spots detected. Fire controlled.  8.21.16- Fire checked by BTP E-461, cold trailed, no smokes or hot spots detected. Fire called out at 1310 and rehab of fireline and fire area completed.

/13/2017:   Fire was reported on Saturday may 13th by Lake LE rangers.  Arson start with rangers apprehending individual who started fire.  Fire was reported to be creeping through grass and had torched a tree it was also semi contained by snow pack.  Since it was a wildland fire, fire cache personnel were requested for the next day to check the fire.  5/14/2017:  Engine 691 with Joe Anderson and Doug Kraus, departed Mammoth fire cache at 0700 and arrived on scene at 0930.  The fire was still smoldering in some duff and heavies with < 10% of the fire perimeter and area actively burning, fire was < .1 ac.  Some open flame was observed.  Given the time of the year and fire size personnel did not install hand line and instead cold trailed perimeter and used the readily available snow pack to mop up the 3-4 hot spots.  Fire was called contained, controlled and out by fire personnel at 1130 on 5/14/2017.

Observed lightning strike, controlled by T6 Engine and 4 FF.   Potts Basin Fire, Fire Code: LA 29, WY-YNP-001706 Location: LAT 44,25.6151 N, LONG 110,34.5479 W; Elevation: 7,786 Incident Commander: Patrick Reck (T), Brent Fleming  08-29-17 At 1400, Engine 692 was contacted by fire dispatch (700 Fox) over the radio while working on a thinning project near the Northeast Entrance. Smoke and flames were reported by visitors and a park ranger near the West Thumb of Yellowstone Lake. 700 Fox identified the approximate location based upon a lightning strike map. Coordinates were relayed and Engine 692�Plovanic plus three�was dispatched to the location. The crew stopped at Pumice Point to scout the fire from across the lake. No smoke was visible, so they continued on to the given coordinates. Driving past the identified location, they smelled smoke, though none was visible, and pulled off the road to hike in and investigate. Approximately 100 yards from the road in Potts Basin, the crew of Engine 692 found the fire. They arrived on scene at 1645 and identified four shoebox-sized pockets of heat in dead-and-down and timber litter in a mature lodgepole-spruce-fir stand. The fire was less than a tenth of an acre with 50% of the perimeter still active. It seemed to originate from a lightning strike near a snag and a 40ft fir that torched but were now cold. Wind was light, less than 5 mph, coming from the East. The fire was located on the eastern aspect of a mild slope (approximately 5%). The surrounding grass and reprod fuels were noticeably moist. With the size-up and LCES completed, the crew radioed information to 700 Fox and got permission to engage and suppress the fire. A hose lay was established from Engine 692. The crew mopped up the four spots. Once they were cold, the fire was called in contained at 1800. The crew gridded the surrounding area and failed to find any other heat. They called in the fire controlled at 1830, packed up their equipment, and drove back to Mammoth. 08-31-17 The crew arrived back on scene at 1330, found the spots completely cold, and called it out at 1400.

The Ray Fire was reported by visitors to the Pebble Creek Campground host on 8/14/18 as approximately a half mile North of the Pebble Creek campground and adjacent to the trail.  Due to its proximity to the downwind communities of Silvergate and Cooke City, MT the decision to suppress it was made by Duty Officer Opperman. An NPS Type 6 engine crew hiked into the incident and controlled it with no additional support. It was declared out on 8/15/2018.

The Terminal Fire was reported on 8/14/2018 by USFS personnel assigned to the Bacon Rind fire.  It was suppressed due to time of year and location east of highway 191 which had been determined by NPS and USFS management as too close to USFS protection values to manage with any strategy except full suppression this early in the fire season.  Keeping the Bacon Rind fire west of highway 191 was an objective of that incident. CWN Helicopter 2TC and a crew of 4 personnel were shuttled into the fire and contained it before nightfall.  One crewmember was evacuated after dark by a life flight due to excessive cramping.  Crew was swapped out with smokejumpers, who hiked in, the next day due to fatigue associated with the medical incident in the middle of the night.  Excessive PT during that day prior to the IA, steep conditions, and lack of hydration were identified as potential causal factors precipitating the medical incident. The fire was controlled on 8/16 and declared out on the 21st after wetting rain over the area.

H-3BH is launched for a recon, 0.1 acres smoldering despite exposure to wind, 5 miles SW of Tower Junction.  Management supports use of a monitoring and zone protection strategy based on incoming cool, wet weather.  Good potential exists for the fire to move towards Tower/Roosevelt if substantial drying occurs after rain on 8/27. 8/25/2018.  Two �Managed Fire Do Not Report� signs are put along the Chittenden Raod to reduce redundant fire reports.  2 monitors report minimal fire activity again today.  Cataldo and Plovanic recon Tower /Roosevelt area and reexamine the state od defensible space there and the 2016 structure protection plan for the area.  Area will close to public on 9/3 (9 days).  Robust type 3 organization as identified in the plan can be effective if this fire moves towards Tower. 8/26/2018.  2 monitors observe the fire from Chittenden Road again today.  Minimal activity once again.  Sprinkler systems continue to be checked at Mammoth for ready deployment if need be. 9/3/2018  No smoke visible from Chittenden Road so the �managed fire do not report signs� are taken down by E-691 crew. 9/11/2018.  Still no smoke visible from this fire since moisture on August 27 and 28 over that location.  Fire Danger is very high and ERCs have been over 50 for well over a week.  Based on that this fire is declared a Natural Out by the duty officer (Cataldo)

Smoke was reported by off duty officer 5H11, at 10:25 near Elk Plaza above the Mammoth sub power substation. Mammoth Structural Fire was dispatched to respond due to E692 being out of the area in the North East area of the park with a long response time. Nearby Xanterra employees responded with a fire extinguisher while structural fire arrived and set up a hose line. Approximately 1000 gallons of water was used to successfully suppress the fire. E692 with IC Plovanic, IC trainee Koehler, and Fitzgerald arrived at scene and was briefed by 5H11 as command was transferred. The fire was checked by E692 and found to be cold.  The incident was less than 1/10th of an acre in grasses, and had escaped from a known employee campfire ring. The fire had creeped South East downhill towards a small creek, and burned the perimeter of the area. Fire potential was high, due to high winds, dry fuel, steep aspect, and proximity of power substation and Mammoth Village. The campfire ring was scattered, and bench logs cut and dispersed to prevent future incidents. The Fire was declared contained, controlled, and out at 13:00.
