7/22/2023.  Yellowstone has our first confirmed wildland fire of 2023.  The "Pup Fire" is located between Little Cottonwood Creek and Hellroaring Mountain in the Park's Northern Range (45.043'N x 110 27.78'W).  

It was ignited by lightening on 7/20 or 7/21, and detected on 7/22 by a visitor, and confirmed by an NPS Ranger.

is approximately 0.1 acre in size.  One standing tree and several logs on the surface burning.  It was suppressed by four smokejumpers from West Yellowstone , Montana over the course of 7-22-24.  They parachuted into the fire area without incident.

The jumpers had assistance from the NPS packers from Stephen’s Creek Corrals in extracting all their gear.

Controlled and out: 1730 hours on 7/24/2023.

Yellowstone has detected it's second wildland fire of the 2023 season. The Hitching Post fire was likely ignited by lightning on the 25th of July and first detected on the 26th by a visitor.  It is located approximately 5.5 miles south of the Northeast entrance road and 1/2 mile east of the Lamar River trail (44° 47.7'N x 110° 07.16'W).   

The fire is currently estimated at 1/2 an acre in size and smoldering in duff and Douglas fir. On the morning of the 27th, six Yellowstone firefighters attempted to access the incident on foot, and a fixed-wing fire detection aircraft was launched out of Bozeman, Montana to assist in pinpointing its exact location. The detection flight finally spotted light smoke at around 1300 hrs, but due to steep inaccessible terrain the ground forces were unable to access the incident yesterday.  

On morning of 28th of July, an NPS helicopter GRCA 8PA) and 3-person flight crew currently based out of Grand Teton National Park flew into the fire area, and obtained a more complete size-up of the incident. Based on the location, time of year, terrain, and low spread potential a confinement strategy is being employed to manage this incident.  The Helitack personnel will use minimum suppression tactics today commensurate with the low fire behavior and spread potential to maintain the fire at its current size.  

The helitack crew reported no perimeter heat and some heat remaining in the duff/litter underneath interior douglas fir.  They walked the perimeter and used MIST tactics to secure anything that may pose a threat to the fire remaining within it’s current perimeter.

No personnel remained on the incident overnight on the 28th, and we do not intend to staff the incident again unless additional activity is detected.  There are no closures anticipated in association with this incident.

7/29 Fire crew (Janecko +1) monitored fire from NE Entrance Road, no activity was able to be detected.
7/30 Fire crew (Bealka +2) monitored fire from NE Entrance Road, no activity was able to be detected.
8/5 Helitack with 4BH flew the incident and reported no visible smokes, they then landed and walked the fire and found no heat. The incident was controlled and called out on 8/5. The fire gained no acreage from first size perimeter reported.

8/12/2023 1600 hours.  Visitor report to Comm Center of small vegetation fire across Slough Creek at campground near Site 9.  DO Cataldo, Tower Structural Fire, and Mammoth Structural Fire all responded.  Mammoth cancelled upon DO arrival at scene.  Tower company arrived first, forded creek, and extinguished fire with plastic ice cream buckets of water from creek and handtools.  6’x8’ spot smoldering and creeping in log and root wad of fallen tree in Bison Fire from 2016. No spread potential due to green herbaceous cover.  Lightning ignition, no sign of human-cause.  Mopped up then all resources released by Cataldo.  Declared confined at 1800.  Controlled at 1900.  Tower Rangers will monitor area for any smoke in coming days. 

8/20/2023 No smokes detected on the fire by patrol rangers over the previous week.  Following nearly an inch of rain at Soda Butte RAWS over the past 2 days the fire is declared out.
Single tree incident naturally confined to a small tree island by absence of available fuels and high fuel moisture levels.

Around noon on 10/1/23 we received a smoke report near Petrified Tree. In the initial report, 700F relayed that 5N31 was the reporting party. By way of "rock, paper, scissors" I was the ICT-5 trainee for this fire with Harms as actual. Lynch, Hulse, Harms and I drove to a pullout near Petrified Tree where we met up with 5N31. We could see what appeared to be a single tree smoking from the road. While speaking with 5N31 another park employee arrived and led us to a parking area closer to the fire. 

Once parked, we put on our funky yellows, slid into our packs and lumbered to the fire with sawyer Harms leading the way. When we arrived it was clear our snag had been struck by lightning. The trunk had a defined mark and tree bits were spread like confetti on the ground. The tree was mostly smoking with whispers of orange flames every now and then on the lower 1/4. I called 700F and gave an update and quick size up. At that point, the overcast sky started to loom. I radioed 700F for Duty Officer's plan of action and a weather update. The answers were; try to get the tree on the ground or dig line around the tree and we were on the edge of a cell. We established safety zones and escape routes and got to work. 

While Harms fell the tree, Hulse was weather watch. As harms got the tree on the ground we began to hear thunder. While Harms cut some smoldering rounds off the tree, we noticed some duff and bark at the base burning. We quickly dug line around the base and Harms low stumped the tree. At this point, the lightning had started. We hot footed it out of there as the rain began

On 6/9/24 at 1630 a report of a smoke was received by Yellowstone Helitack. 4BH launched with an I.A. load consisting of Harms, Propst and Brueggerman-Hulse. The fire was detected from the air and the ship landed at a helispot. A storm was moving over the area and the decision was made to return to Mammoth Helibase.
Lat 44 deg 52.5962 N, Long 111deg 3.8280
Roles: Harms – Helicopter Manager, Ecker – HECM, IC-5, Marquez - IC-5(t), HECM, Lampe - HECM(t)
On 6/10/24 Harms, Marquez, Lampe and Ecker lifted from Mammoth the Mile Post 17 fire. The helicopter landed at Helispot 1. Once on the ground, Marquez, Lampe and Ecker hiked to the fire approximately 1.25 miles downhill. The terrain had snow, inescapable downed trees and spiderwebs between standing trees at regular intervals. The party arrived at the fire in just under 3 hours and did a quick hike around the fire which appeared to be mostly cold. The fire was started by lightening that struck several trees and a downed log approximately 15 feet away.

At this point, Lampe and Ecker began improving a helispot closer to the fire and Marquez proceeded to the fire. Marquez called in a size up to 700F then began cold trailing the fire. After approximately one hour the helispot was finished and Lampe directed 4BH for landing. Once on the ground, Harms joined the cold trailing effort with Marquez, Ecker, and Lampe. Approximately 3 hours after arrival to the fire Marquez called it in as “contained” to 700F. After one last look at hot spots by Ecker, 4BH lifted from Helispot 2 for Mammoth Helibase.

7/19 – The fire was located on a detection flight by helicopter 4 N234BH.  Initial size up was called up and helicopter returned to mammoth helibase after recon of potential landing zone and water source.  Duty officer instructed the IC to suppress the fire.  Helicopter 4BH was used to shuttle four personnel to fire.  At the helispot bucket was hooked to helicopter to begin ops but 4BH had to return to helibase with bucket issues, 4BH would return after swapping buckets putting approximately 4000 gallons on the fire in close coordination with the ground crew.  Ground crew constructed an anchor at the heel and began stopping forward progression and securing the flanks.  Ground crews where able to stop any further growth of the fire successfully with the fire staying at about 0.5 acres in size.  After growth was stopped crews put in saw line, got all heavy fuels on the ground and put in hand line where necessary.  Ground crews were then shuttled out with 4BH.
7/20 – Ground crew was shuttled into the same helispot.  Thanks to the previous shifts work the fire had not grown at all and showed no obvious heat or smoke.  Saw and hand line was improved and the whole fire was cold trailed.  Finding no heat or smoke the fire was called contained at 1400 and controlled.  Ground crew continued to monitor the fire for any heat or smoke in direct sunlight until 4BH was able to shuttle the ground crew back to helibase.

On 7/23/24 at 15:35 a call from Dispatch was received by Abraham Harms informing us of a smoke report along highway 191 on the west side of the road. 
4BH Launched with Abe Harms (HMGB), Kat Janecko (IC5) and Curtis Propst (IC5-T). 
The Smoke was sighted at 1547. 4BH Circled the fire for a few moments to build a proper size up given by Propst (IC5T). A Dip site in Grayling Creek was located by the crew at 1600. An LZ was identified at 1603. The Crew unloaded and reconfigured the ship for bucket work. The Crew hiked uphill towards the fire while waiting for approval to suppress or manage the fire as well as dip site approval. At 1630 the word came back that the dip site was approved, and the fire was to be suppressed. Abe Harms began plugging in and cutting saw line in the timber while Kat and Curtis Anchored at the bottom of the fire at a rock face and began to wrap the fire with handline. A Small spot (2’x3’) was addressed by the grubbers. 
At 1719 while looking for more spots Propst noticed a new start a few miles away on the other side of the highway. It was called in to 700Fox and approval was given to send 4BH to the area to look at it and give a quick size up to dispatch while the crew continued operations on the MP 18 Fire. Approval for 4BH to utilize the bucket and dip site on the new fire was given at 1730 and 4BH was released to knock the New Start down. After puttin’ a hurtin’ on The New Start 4BH returned to MP 18 and continued bucket work until 1930. The Ground crew called dispatch and declared the MP18 Fire contained at 2000 then reconfigured the ship for the return shuttle and flew back to helibase. 4BH was back on the ground and shut down at 2030.
7/24/24
Yellowstone helitack sent a short squad consisting of Abe Harms (IC5), Curtis Propst (IC5-T) and Caitlin Marquez to continue engaging the MP18 Fire at 1030. Boots were on the ground and plugged back into operations at 1103. Saw Line was buffed and improved as well as handline. Mop-up operations began with crew members Gridding for heats and checking probable areas of heat and heavies throughout the early afternoon. Some Bone piling was done to burn some heavies down to a manageable mopup size.
4BH was released by a nearby Incident at 1330 to assist MP 18 with a few buckets before the fuel cycle was too low. 4BH delivered two buckets to assist with Mop-up before dropping the bucket off at the LZ down the hill and returning to Mammoth for Fuel. After evaluating the need for water, the crew decided to release 4BH until they would need a pickup to leave. Mopup continued and heats were declared out. A weather report was requested from Dispatch due to Cumulus build up to the North and West. The Weather report showed storms moving in. at 1445 IC5-T requested 4BH to return to the MP18 to begin a shuttle off the hilltop back to mammoth. The Crew hiked to the LZ and met 4BH, loaded up and was back on the ground in Mammoth at 1532. The fire was declared contained and controlled at 1545 by IC5 and IC5-T.

7/23 – Fire was located by Propst while on the Milepost 18 Fire.  Fire was reported and helicopter N234BH was sent to recon it and started bucket work on it at 1729.  4BH worked it with buckets until 1830.  No boots where on the ground at the fire on 7/23.
7/24 – At 0930 a morning recon with the IC5(t), squaddies and the DO took place due to concerns about the safety of inserting personnel into an environment with potentially poor or non-existent safety zone.  Adequate safety zones and escape routes were found and the decision was made to insert 6 personnel in 2 loads into a large wet meadow, which would be the helispot and our safety zone.  The helispot and safety zone were about 1/3 of a mile from the fire.  The first 3 were inserted at 1130 and engaged at 1145.  At 1215 the second load landed.  When they arrived at the fire we stopped for a full brief.  Bucket work started at 1240, we shared the bucket ship, 4BH, with the Milepost 18 Fire for a full bucket cycle.  Fire was contained with saw line, bucket work and water from the nearby creek using bladder bags.  The fire consisted of 8 separate spots totaling to about .5 acres.  The given coordinates are of the largest spot.  The rest of the spots extend north about 100 yards on both sides of the creek.  Around 1500 the decision was made to leave both Milepost 18 and the Camp Creek Fires due to weather.  The first load left the fire at 1600 and the second was away at 1630.  The fire was called contained later that evening.
7/25 – Lynch, Jenecko and Lampe flew out to the helispot, landed at 1120 and were at the fire by 1137.  Gridded and cold trailed the fire finishing and calling the firing controlled at 1152.  Crew monitored the fire for about on hour and had left the fire by 1300.

Origin is approximate, never definitively located during suppression efforts.  Fire burned well through open meadows and parks which accounted for majority of growth.  Fire behavior moderated considerably when the fire reached lodgepole pine regeneration and shaded areas.  A helicopter with bucket drops, Type 2 hand crew, and misc. engine and fire effects personnel were utilized to contain this incident.

The Lovely Fire was called in as a smoke report on 9/4/24. The park ship 4BH gave a size up, but did not engage the fire. The following day 9/5/24, Yellowstone Helitack was dispatched to the Lovely Fire. 4BH departed Mammoth at 0831 with a crew of 3 plus pilot. The fire was located and was .1 acres and was smoldering in dead/down and grass. Once the fire was scouted 4BH began looking for a dip site. The dip 
site of Tern Lake was identified and a request to dip out of it was made. 4BH then landed and shut down about .5 miles down hill from the fire at 0941. Noah Brueggeman-Hulse was IC 5 trainee with Matt Mason as actual. Helitack then hooked up the bucket and began to hike in. A radio was left with the pilot to order bucket work if needed. Helitack arrived at the Lovely Fire at 1014. Dispatched was notified and the IC established and assigned tasks and objectives. A ground size up was given by IC Bruggeman-Hulse at 1018 and is as follows:
Fire name: Lovely Fire
Location: 44°38.812 by -110°7.212
Perimeter Active: 10%
Size: .1 acer
Wind: 0-5 mph
Wind Direction: SW Variable
Fuel Type: Slash, Grass
Adjacent Fuels: Slash, Grass, Lodgepole
Aspect: West
Position on Slope: Upper 1/3
Spread Potential: Low to Moderate
Estimated Number of Personnel to Control: 3
Estimated Commitment: 3 Hours
Equipment Needs: None
Structures Threatened: None
Special Information: 4BH Standing by for bucket work
The fire consisted of mainly one large down tree, smaller dead and down, grass and a stump. Next 
Helitack engaged the fire by bucking heavies, cutting smaller trees near or in the black and securing the perimeter. Sections with heat were put in the black and scraped. Once all the fuels with heat were found and moved into the black, the decision was made to order 4BH for bucket work at 1040. The dip site was 7 miles away and the turn around time was 10 min +. Helitack was able to work in between drops and mix. The drops proved effective at cooling the heat. Due to fuel considerations 4BH landed and shut down after 3 buckets where dropped, 2 were on the fire. Mop up continued with Helitack cold trailing and looking for heats. No major heats were found after the bucket drops. Helitack then began to monitor the fire and see if any heats stood up. After 30 minutes without finding and further heats the decision was made to call the fire contained (Later Changed to Controlled) at 1230. Helitack then hiked 
off the fire and tied back in with the ship at 1256. 4BH with crew were back in Mammoth at 1347.

Agency employee spotted this single tree incident from the park's east entrance road.  It subsequently went out naturally without intervention.  Fire Management resources attempted to relocate the incident to suppress it, but it was undetectable subsequent days after the initial report to dispatch.
Lightning ignited fire reported by member of the public and suppressed by 4 NPS firefighters with minimal resistance to control.

Likely trespass fire due to location in frequent out of bound unpermitted camper location along boundary, but origin and cause undetermined.  Hebgen Basin Fire and local NPS ranger suppressed it initially and NPS firefighters completed control later that day, and declared out.

FinalFireReportNarrative:
Gibbon Picnic Fire (FC: 000003)
6/8/2025
Narrative:
Smoke report at Gibbon Meadows picnic area lodged at 07:40. RP described a small fire at the base of a tree across the road from the vault toilets, also made efforts to extinguish. At 08:12 Clulow, Marquez, & Pittenger were en route from Mammoth Springs, arriving at 08:51. A grid was conducted on the east side of grand loop road, no relevant findings. At 09:16 the fire was located, directly adjacent to the Gibbon Meadows pull out . Minimal smoke, pockets of heat in the duff were distributed across an approx. 2' by 2' square at the base of a lodgepole pine. No trunk or root damage detected. 3 bladder bags worth of water were introduced to the hot spots and concentrations of heat in the soil were eliminated with minimal disturbance. A cigarette butt was also found in the direct vicinity of the start. Before departure from the scene at 09:59, the fire was determined contained and controlled. Back at station at 10:30.

The Riverdance fire was reported on 6/9 to dispatch as a battery fire right off the road. We soon saw video of park visitors stomping the fire out hence the name. The location of the incident wasn't well known so it took awhile for a search to find it and once found it was determined to be contained and controlled. The fire burn about a 10x10 ft chunk of meadow grass.
Car fire that spread into the wildland a short distance from the vehicle.
Abandoned campfire that met terms for qualification as a wildland fire due to spread potential if no action taken.
Escaped, unattended campfire is most likely cause given location.

7/8/2025 
1400 – Trail Creek fire reported by fishing boat. 
1500 – Decision made to suppress fire due to the early time of year and length of commitment for a long duration fire.
1530 – Bridger Teton T3 helicopter with 4 FFT’s landed and started IA with Eligah Fedosov as IC and Bruce Burns as IC(T). YELL FX crew with 3 FFT’s were boated into Trail Creek cabin and started their hike in at this time. The fire is estimated at 7 acres with 70% of the perimeter active.  The helicopter worked 2 cycles of buckets.
1650 – Bucket work is completed, and crews anchor on right flank. Crews work on check line around the head of the fire to limit spread and spot fires. Order placed for hose, pumps and fuel to be flown into the fire the next day. 
2100 – Crews complete check line around Northeast side of fire and hike back to Trail Creek Cabin.

0600 – IA crews in service and at fire by 730, continue hand line construction and securing spot fires. Kraus and Krause leave Mammoth with hose order and drive to Bridge Bay marina.
0800 – Arrive Bridge Bay marina and load equipment on boat and are shuttled to Trail Creek cabin.
0900 – Krause and Kraus arrive at cabin, unload equipment. Krause hikes into the fire to take over as IC while Kraus stays at cabin to build the cargo load.
1000 - Krause arrives at the fire, is debriefed and transitions as ICT4. Seven FFT’s from the Custer Gallatin NF are shuttled from the marina to the cabin to hike into the fire. The 4 helitack gather their gear and fly back to base. 
1200 – CGF FFT’s arrive, are briefed and assigned to construct saw line on the left flank. The YELL FX crew along with Krause and Kraus continue line construction on the right flank.
1600 – Spot fire flares up with continued growth to the Northeast, a pump and hose lay is installed to stop spread. 
2000 – Crews stop line construction for the evening and hike back to the cabin with saw line complete around 60% of the fire. Fire behavior is smoldering with the fire mapped at 11 acres.

0600 – IA crews in service and at fire by 800, continue line construction and securing spot fire. Fire activity is greatly reduced overnight with continued burning heavies near 50% of the fire edge.
1200 – Saw line is completed.
1430 – Handline is completed around the fire and hose lay is extended up the left flank to secure the edge and start mopping up. 
1900 – Crews hike off the fire with the only activity remaining being logs burning near the heel or 25% of the fire edge.

7/11/2025 
0600 – IA crews in service and at fire by 800. Fire activity is minimal with only a few smoldering logs and one burning snag near the line. Snag is cut down and crews start mopping up the remaining visible smokes.
0900 – YELL WFM is boated into the cabin with 4 CGF fire fighters boating back to the marina due to prior commitments. 
1200 – Krause and Allen transition with Allen taking over as ICT4. The YELL FX crew, Kraus and Krause hike out to the cabin to be boated back to the marina. YELL WFM and 3 CGF FFT’s remain at the fire to continue mop up. 
1800 – Crews off the line, fire is 100% contained.

0600—Crews in service and at the fire by 0800. Continue mop-up of heat and smokes throughout the day. Shuttling of fire apparatus to Trail Creek Cabin occurs throughout shift. 
1800—Crews off the line.

0600 – Crews in service and at the fire by 0800. Gridding of fire finds only one stump hole with heat. Fire lines are rehabilitated, and fire area monitored through end of shift. All remaining large fire apparatus is ferried by canoe to Trail Creek Cabin. 
1800 – Crews off the line. Begin preparations for departure of camp/incident.

Cliff Fire Narrative 
7/17/2025 
1538 – Smoke Check 4BH
1552 – Initial size up
1600 – 4BH lands at helispot, crew hikes in and begins suppression. 
1615 – Fire effects and Mod ordered. 
1715 – Fire effects on scene of Cliff Fire.
2000 – Fire effects depart Cliff fire on 4BH.

7/18/2025 
0700 – Yellowstone Mod arrives at trailhead pull-out and begins hike into Cliff Fire. 
0840 – Crew is briefed, weather is read and felling operation (Ecker and Allen) begins to mitigate 2 snags with fire in them, one of the snags has potential to be the lightning affected tree.  
0910 – First fire update given to 700F, significant heat and heavies actively burning. Transmissions remain scratchy. 700F informs that 4BH has been committed to the SAR. 
0945 – Crew engages fire. Improving and cutting more handline up the right flank, knocking back brush and fuels in rocks on upper left flank. Pump and water being utilized on heavies at heel of fire and up the right flank. 
1000 – Helitack ordered for assistance on fire. 
1050 – 4BH over fire, Ecker in place at Cliff Fire helispot to receive crew and give vitals, 4BH drops off 2 helitack personnel (Rawlins and Page) and returns to mammoth for fire investigator shuttle. Tyler and Page remain at Helispot to receive next shuttle and Ecker hikes back to the line. 
1135 – 4BH back over fire, recon with fire investigators, 3 investigators on ground at Cliff helispot at 11:40. 
1150 – Three fire investigators arrive at Cliff fire. IC and IC trainee give them briefing and answer questions. Informed investigators there were not visible indications of human caused fire. Described the snag hung up in another tree and the standing snag to investigators. They begin their investigation. 
1235 – 4BH over fire, lands and shuts down with second shuttle of Helitack personnel: Mason, Lynch, and Clue. Decision is made to hold ship at Cliff Helispot for bucket work, which will begin once the investigators have completed their investigation. Ecker walks the wildfire perimeter utilizing field maps for upload and fire update size.  
1240 – Cliff fire 50% contained, 
1600 – Crew shuttle back to Mammoth is requested for all personnel on the Cliff Fire, 700F copies. Crew disengages fire and begins hike to helipsot. At this time the fire is behavior has decreased greatly with heat remaining in heavys and duff. 
1610 – 4BH is over fire, lands at Cliff Helispot and loads first shuttle hot. At 1622 the first shuttle lifts enroute to Mammoth. The second shuttle lifts off Cliff Helispot at 1637 enroute to Mammoth. Final shuttle lifts to Mammoth at 1700 and is on the ground shutting down at Mammoth Helibase at 1706.

1148 – 4BH is requested for buckets and recon. Fire behavior has begun to pick up with isolated torching. 
1220 – 4BH on scene, configures for buckets along scree. 
1630 – Crew hikes to helispot and departs fire.

0920 – First 4BH crew shuttle: Allen, Ecker and Sents are on scene. No visible smoke showing from air recon. Hike in and begin mop-up. 
0950 – All of Yellowstone Mod on fire. Crew shuttles complete and 4BH is enroute back to Mammoth. 
1245 – Signs previously posted for trail closure and backcountry site switch are removed. A group of packers are discovered camped past the closure sign by Allen. 
1250 – All hose and pumps are pulled. Final check for heat completed, no heat found. 
1255 – Cliff fire is called controlled, pick-up via 4BH hotel is requested, and crew begins hike off line. 700F Copies all. 
1315 – 4BH at helispot loads first shuttle enroute to Mammoth. At 1330 second shuttle off Cliff enroute to Mammoth. 
1350 – 4BH on the ground in Mammoth. All resources off fire.

0710 – Informed of smoke found by fixed wing in morning briefing. Discussion of fuel loading in that area and potential for fire to carry through it.  
0955 – 4BH hotel lifts off Mammoth Helibase, enroute to cliff fire. Recon flown, Ecker gives ariel size up.
1015 – 4BH on ground at initial helispot. Marquez, Ecker and Becker configure ship for buckets. 
1025 – 4BH lifts for buckets and Ecker and Becker begin hike into fire.  
1040 – Ecker (Q) and Becker (t) arrive at fire. 4BH is doing buckets, dipping out of Wrangler Pond with a 3 – 4 minute turn around. In between buckets IC and Trainee scout fire to form size up. Fire is currently smoldering with lots of dead and down and snags surrounding. The buckets are doing a good job of cooling it off. 
1100 –Size up read to 700F.  High fire potential, but moderated fire behavior observed currently. Additionally, requested weather specifically a wind radar as the winds were forecasted to begin gusting to 35 after 1200 and the area was experiencing frequent switches.  With remote location/access, fuel loading and hazards present (snags) the aircraft being able to fly would inform firefighting tactics. 700F follows up at 1120 with a wind radar forecasting consistent SW winds 10-15 mph. 
1140 – 4BH hotel drops final bucket, returns to Wrangler helispot to remove bucket and returns to Corral to refuel and begin crew shuttle. Ecker and Becker begin to engage fire. 
1225 – 4BH back over fire performs recon for Allen and Sents. At 1232 4BH drops of 2 crew members at Wrangler helispot and returns to Corral Helispot for second crew shuttle.   
1235 – 4BH on ground at Corral Helispot and Allen and Sents begin hike in. 
1240 – 4BH off Corral Helispot enroute to fire. Landing attempted at original helispot, but due to winds and weight the pilot is unable to land. 4BH recons potential LZs then lands at what would become the new Wrangler Helispot and drops off Marotto. Flies back to original helispot and drops other two Yell Mod crew members then shuttles Marotto over.  Bucket is then packed up and 4BH hotel relocates to new helispot and shuts down at 1300. Instructed to hold. 
1320 – Three remaining Yell Mod hike in (Hertz, Jaffe and Marotto)  
1345 – 4BH lifts for buckets.   
1355 – All Yell mod members arrive at fire. 700F informed all resources arrived and additionally informed that the lightning tree had been located and cut. 
1405 – Crew brief on fire, weather. Main hazards are the numerous snags. As this brief is occurring, Allen and Ecker begin felling operation to eliminate snags with heat and potential. 
1435 – 4BH drops the final bucket for a total of 34 for both fuel cycles. Instructed to fuel then hold at Wrangler Helispot.
1500 – With buckets and snag felling complete Yell Mod crew engages the fire and begins to put in line around the fire. This update is given to 700F at 1510. 
1630 – Line tied in around the fire.  
1642 – Wrangler Fire is 100% contained update given to 700F. 
1750 – Yell Mod hikes off Wrangler fire to Helispot for crew shuttle. The fire behavior has moderated with heavies maintaining heat which have been bone piled interior, shuttle is requested. 700F copies all. 
1810 – Yell Mod arrives at helispot. At 1815 first shuttle lifts, second shuttle lifts at 1822 and the final shuttle lifts at 1833. Ecker and Becker are on this one and perform a recon of the fire. No smoke showing.
1900 – 4BH on the ground at Mammoth Helibase. 


7/20/2025 
0955 – 4BH off Mammoth Helibase
1030 – Arrived at Wrangler Helispot, no smoke seen on recon. 

1512 – Wrangler Fire is 100% controlled, 4BH hotel requested for crew shuttle, and crew begins hike off. 700F copies all. 
1535 – Crew arrives at helispot for pick up. 
1550– 4BH lifts for Mammoth.
1603 – 4BH on the ground shutting down in Mammoth.
Lightning fire inside the 1994 Robinson Fire scar spotted by a Life Flight passing through the area.

CUTOFF NARRATIVE AND PHOTOS
The Smoke report was received early in the morning and Yellowstone Helitack went down to stage at Old Faithful helispot. 4BH was down for maintenance, so the helitack crew (Williams, Clulow, Marquez) picked up by Pocatello helitack in helicopter 9GF. 9GF flew over Cutoff fire, I completed an ariel sizeup and sent it to 700F. 9GF landed at LZ, and we began the hike into fire.  We arrived on scene and notified 700F. Clulow began digging line around fire, I mapped and began a more detailed sizeup. Sizeup was completed and sent to 700F. The fire consisted of three separate wildfires, each being labeled Cutoff 1, 2 & 3. Trees were dropped around cutoff 1 and line construction continued, focusing on cutoff 1. Cutoff 1 was the most active with creeping and smoldering, some visible flame. Each fire was 30ft x 30ft, with cutoff 3 being 45ft x 30ft. All three spots were circled by handline by the end of the day. Containment continued, and the weather reading took place. Hiked back to camp, which was next to LZ. We had dinner, and food was hung in a bag to prevent bear incursions.
The crew woke up at 0600 and had breakfast. We hiked to the fire and continued mop up. All three spots called controlled by 0900. We requested exfill and supplies, but there were no aircraft available. We continued to mop up but made a plan that by 1600 we would filter a nearby water source. 1600 rolled around, and 4BH came and picked us up. Returned to mammoth helibase.

The Moss Creek fire was reported on 8/4/25. Helitack was engaged on the South Pitchstone fire in the Southern area of the park. The Moss creek fire was East of Mt. Washburn right below Joesph’s Coat geological monitoring station. Marlee was the IC(t) and Abraham Harms was the IC actual. Marlee sized up the fire from the air, it was about .5 acres burning on the edge of the Broad Fire scar in a Spruce, Lodgepole mix forest. There was heavy dead and down with moderate spread potential. We landed above the fire in the saddle we use to get to geological monitoring station. We also ordered a load of jumpers after we landed. 
The helicopter started bucket work immediately and knocked down most of the fire concern by end of shift. There were a few areas of single tree spotting and it had potential to get up and be a larger problem but we were able to manage it. The jumpers arrived and were briefed by Marlee and plugged into working the fire. 
We had a minor green medical when one of our firefighters somehow impaled his arm with the pointed end of a chainsaw file. Marlee being an emt determined that it was better to remove the object in the field than leave it in. It was about an inch into the outer layer of skin on the forearm. Marlee bandaged him up and we had him take it easy until we could get him out of there, since it was deemed a green medical. In hindsight we should have just flown him out as soon as we could.
By end of shift on day one all other Helitack personnel flew off the fire and it was just myself, Marlee, and 6 smokejumpers. We camped near the fire and observed minor fire behavior into the night. 
8/5/25
Mop up and bone piling started. Moss creek was nearby and I scouted to it to see if we could get a hose lay from it. (Jumper’s idea) I found that there was water and so we put together a pump order and sent it in to dispatch. Once we received the pump and hose order the jumpers put in a P line to the creek and we plumbed it. After getting water to the fire we were able to fully mop up and by end of shift there were only a few areas of heat left on the fire. 
8/6/25 
We continued to mop up and monitor the fire and determined that it was contained/ controlled. We packed up the hose and pump kits and worked on getting them back hauled. All resources were flown off the fire by end of shift and the fire was placed into contained/ controlled status.

Contained in 9 days at 22 acres, and controlled on the 12th.

On August 18th, 2025, the pilot and I were dispatched to the Osprey fire. The arial size up revealed a single tree lightening strike fire that was approximately 1/10 of an acre in an area thick with lodgepole regen. The fire was smoldering and creeping in the duff and the stricken tree that fell.
We landed at an unnamed pond nearby and reconfigured for buckets. While the pilot was performing buckets, I hiked into the fire. The hike was about a 7-minute walk from our helispot. Upon my arrival at the fire, I began directing bucket drops.
After 19 buckets, I called the fire contained. My generous estimation was that 3 people with a chainsaw and 3 hours could get this start into control status. We left the incident for the next one.
The following day myself and Curtis Propst flew to the Osprey Fire. An aerial size up revealed no smoke or other indications of heat. I estimated we would need 20 minutes to put the fire into controlled status.
We were dropped off and began hiking to the fire. At the fire we discovered a completely cold site! Not an iota of heat anywhere.
I called it controlled, contained and out within 20 minutes of drop off, as estimated.

Petrified Fire Report
The Petrified fire was reported around 1500 on Sunday, September 21st.
Resources arrived at the parking lot at 1540.
At 1545, two firefighters began the hike into the incident.
Firefighters arrived at 1550 and provided a size-up to dispatch.
At 1600 a C-Sawyer was ordered.
Helicopter 4BH was ordered at 1630 for bucket work on the fire.
At 1730, a C-Sawyer arrived on scene.
Additionally, 4BH was engaged in bucket drops by 1730.
4BH disengaged and returned to Mammoth at 1815.
An additional C-Sawyer arrived from the West Yellowstone Smokejumper base at 1900.
All resources disengaged from the fire line at 2000.

Firefighters arrive back on scene at 0840, September 22nd.
At 0850 firefighters reengaged and began constructing saw line and bone piling heavy fuels in anticipation of felling the remaining ~60 feet of the tree.
By 0945, saw line had been completed and bone piles were fully constructed.
Hand line was completed around the fire perimeter by 1010.
At 1020, firefighters disengaged from the fire due to inclement weather and returned to the trucks.
By 1120 the inclement weather had subsided, and firefighters reengaged on the fire line.
IC got in contact with DO at 1200 to clarify DO’s timeline for suppression.
At 1220, the B-Sawyer provided a tree size-up and cut plan to IC. Felling operations began shortly after.
A drone intrusion occurred at 1330 and was reported to dispatch.
The tree was felled and on the ground at 1340.
By 1405 the tree was bucked, bone piled, and handline was dug around it.
From 1405 to 1645, firefighters held and monitored.
Firefighters disengaged and began the return trip to Mammoth at 1650.
The fire was called contained at 1645.

Firefighters arrived back on scene at 0830, September 23rd.
By 0840, firefighters reconstructed bone piles and began bucking the remainder of the trunk.
Firefighters held and monitored bone piles from 0845 to 1655.
All resources off the line by 1700.
The return trip to Mammoth began and called the fire controlled and out at 1715.
